**PRESENTATION OF FINANCIAL AND OTHER INFORMATION**

**Presentation of Financial Information**

We present in this Offering Memorandum certain financial information for the Parent and its subsidiaries, including historical
information for the Group, which consists of the Parent and its subsidiaries. The financial information presented in this Offering
Memorandum includes certain audited and unaudited financial statements, non-IFRS and non-GAAP financial information,
operating segment information and other information, each as set forth below. For an overview of the entities in the Group, see
“Summary—Summary Corporate and Financing Structure.”

The Issuer is a subsidiary of the Parent with no revenue-generating activities of its own or material business operations, and its
only earnings have been amounts received in respect of the offering of the Murray Notes and the offering of the Existing Cirrus
Notes. Following the Offering, the Issuer will not have any material assets and its only material liabilities will be its liabilities
under the Existing Notes and the Notes, each as described elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. The Issuer was
incorporated on March 20, 2019.

conversion ratio, adjusted cash conversion ratio adjusted for the Pre-Offering Transactions, pro forma adjusted cash conversion

ratio, capital expenditure measures, as adjusted pro forma first lien net senior secured debt; as adjusted pro forma cash interest

unamortized financing costs) to Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA before IFRS 16; ratio of Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA before
IFRS 16 to as adjusted pro forma cash interest expense; leverage ratio (in each case, as defined herein) and other measures and
ratios that are not required by, or presented in accordance with, IFRS or any other generally accepted accounting standards.
Unless otherwise specified, all figures presented on a pro forma basis have been presented as of or for the twelve months ended
June 30, 2023.

We present non-IFRS measures because we believe that they and similar measures are widely used by certain investors,
securities analysts and other interested parties as supplemental measures of performance and liquidity.

The non-IFRS measures may not be comparable to other similarly titled measures of other companies and have limitations as
analytical tools and should not be considered in isolation or as a substitute for analysis of our operating results as reported
under IFRS or any other generally accepted accounting standard. These non-IFRS measures and ratios are not measurements
of our performance or liquidity under IFRS or any other generally accepted accounting standards and should not be considered
as alternatives to revenue or net profit for the period or any other performance measures derived in accordance with IFRS or
any other generally accepted accounting principles or as alternatives to cash flows from operating, investing or financing
activities.

The non-IFRS measures we present may also be defined differently than the corresponding terms under the Indenture. The
non-IFRS measures have limitations as an analytical tool, and should not be considered in isolation, or as an alternative to, or
a substitute for, profit/(loss) for the period or other financial statement data presented in our consolidated financial statements
as indicators or financial performance. Some of the limitations of these non-IFRS measures are that:

  - they do not reflect our cash expenditures or future requirements for capital expenditures or contractual commitments;

  - they do not reflect changes in, or cash requirements for, our working capital needs;

  - they do not reflect the significant interest expense, or the cash requirements necessary, to service interest or principal
payments on our debt;

  - they do not reflect our tax expenses or the cash that we may be required to pay our taxes;

  - they are not adjusted for all non-cash income or expense items that are reflected in our statements of cash flows;

  - they do not reflect the impact of earnings or charges resulting from certain matters we consider not to be indicative of
our ongoing operations;

  - although depreciation and amortization are non-cash charges, the assets being depreciated and amortized will often
need to be replaced in the future and EBITDA-based measures do not reflect any cash requirements that would be
required for such replacements;

  - some of the exceptional items that we eliminate in calculating certain EBITDA-based measures reflect cash payments
that were made, or will in the future be made;

  - other companies in our industry may calculate these measures differently than we do, limiting their usefulness as
comparative measures; and

  - certain adjustments made in calculating EBITDA-based measures contain estimates that management believes reflect
the underlying results of operations and therefore are subjective in nature.

Furthermore, you should carefully consider the risks and limitations of the non-IFRS financial measures, as they are based in
part on management’s assumptions regarding the future impact of actions that have not yet been implemented. For example,
there is a risk that the synergies that we seek to achieve may not be realized in the anticipated time frame and that the magnitude
of cost savings may be less than expected.

**Foreign Currencies and Functional Currency**

The individual financial statements of each subsidiary of the Parent are prepared in the currency of the primary economic
environment in which it operates (its functional currency). For the purpose of the EG Group Financial Statements, the results
and financial position of the Group are expressed in U.S. Dollars, the presentational currency for the Group and its consolidated
financial statements.

The assets and liabilities of the Group’s foreign operations are translated into the Group’s presentational currency at exchange
rates prevailing at the balance sheet date. Profits and losses are translated at average exchange rates for the relevant accounting
period. Exchange differences arising are recognized in the Group statement of comprehensive income/(loss) and are included
in the Group’s translation reserve. Transactions denominated in foreign currencies are translated into the functional currency
at the exchange rates prevailing on the date of the transaction. Monetary assets and liabilities denominated in foreign
currencies are retranslated into the functional currency at the rates of exchange at the reporting date. Exchange differences on
monetary items are recognized in the income statement. Intragroup loans are translated at the year-end exchange rate with the
resulting exchange differences recognized within finance costs. Goodwill and fair value adjustments arising on the
acquisition of a foreign entity are treated as assets and liabilities of the foreign entity and translated at the closing rate.
Exchange differences arising are recognized in other comprehensive income.

Unless otherwise specified, non-U.S. dollar amounts referenced in this Offering Memorandum have been converted to a U.S.

£1.00 and AUD/USD exchange rate $0.66264 per A$1.00, as applicable, based on the spot rates as at June 30, 2023, as reported
by the European Central Bank.

**Overview**

We are a leading independent global convenience retailer that served over 1.1 billion customers worldwide in the year
ended December 31, 2022 (over 3 million customers per day). We have a diversified portfolio of sites across three
continents, which consists of 5,937 sites after giving effect to the Transactions. Based on our site count (after giving
effect to the Transactions), we are the third largest independent convenience retailer chain globally, the fifth largest
in the United States and the second largest in Continental Europe and Australia.

Our total fuel volumes sold was 17.7 billion liters for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023 (16.1 billion liters after
giving effect to the Transactions). Our global operations span six of the ten largest fuel markets in Europe by fuel
volumes sold, namely Belgium, France, Germany, Italy, the Netherlands and the United Kingdom, all six states in
Australia and 30 states across the United States. Our Fuel operations are complemented by our Grocery & Merchandise
and Foodservice operations, under which we offer our proprietary brands as well as partner with attractive third-party
brands. We seek to deliver a modern and convenient customer retail experience by providing a “one-stop shop” retail
destination that offers a broad range of products and services to address evolving customer needs, which increasingly
revolve around conveniently located stores offering one-stop solutions. For the twelve months ended June 30, 2023,
we generated revenue of $26.2 billion, gross profit of $3.8 billion and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA before IFRS 16
of $1,147 million, in each case after giving effect to the Pre-Offering Transactions.

**Industry Overview**

The global C-Store industry has three primary components: fuel, grocery & merchandise and foodservice. The industry
is large and highly fragmented, and in recent years has experienced a number of divestitures from major fuel producers
and/or refiners, grocery retailers, independent operators and chains.

In recent years, C-Stores have improved the range of non-fuel products and services, such as grocery & merchandise
and foodservice offerings. In 2022, in the countries in which we currently operate, the grocery & merchandise market
had sales of $276 billion and the foodservice market had sales of $1,008 billion. We expect that non-fuel sales will
continue to grow as consumers remain focused on convenience and “one-stop” shopping solutions. During 2020 and
the beginning of the COVID-19 pandemic, convenience sales in the countries in which we currently operate increased
2.0% and saw continued growth into 2021, growing at 2.9% according to Euromonitor International. During 2020 and
the beginning of the COVID-19 pandemic, foodservice sales in the countries in which we currently operate decreased
by 24.7% due to COVID-19 pandemic-related restrictions, but saw subsequent increases of 15.9% and 25.9% in 2021
and 2022, respectively, according to Euromonitor International.

Retail fuel consumption in the countries in which we currently operate totaled 668 billion liters in 2022, showing yearon-year growth but not matching or exceeding volumes before the COVID-19 pandemic. The fuel market experienced
volatility recently due to macroeconomic events, including the COVID-19 pandemic and Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
During 2020 and the start of the COVID-19 pandemic, retail fuel consumption in the countries in which we currently
operate totaled 607 billion liters, a 13.7% decrease from 2019. As COVID-19- pandemic-related restrictions eased in
2021, retail fuel consumption in the countries in which we currently operate totaled 660 billion liters, an 8.7% increase
from 2020, before reaching 668 billion liters in 2022. We expect fuel volumes within our current operating geographies
to decrease slightly in the near future, largely driven by anticipated vehicle efficiency improvements, an expected
decline in average vehicle travel distance (which we believe is due to changing consumer behavior after the COVID19 pandemic) and an increase in the number of electric vehicles. This decline is expected to be partially offset by

Fuel prices at the pump can experience some volatility depending on macroeconomic factors, such as inflation and
global oil prices, and this occasionally causes short-term fluctuations in the gross margin we generate per liter of fuel
volume sold. Our long-term gross margin for fuel has been consistently increasing over time, offsetting the impact of
decreasing fuel volumes, the inflation-linked increases in site operating costs and the extreme oil volatility seen in
2022 driven by the Russian invasion of Ukraine. High margin Grocery & Merchandise and Foodservice operations
tend to contribute to increasing customer traffic to our sites, supporting sales volume and margin expansion and
diversifying our profits away from fuel operations.

Our business is highly cash generative and we benefit from limited working capital requirements, with a strong pro
forma adjusted cash conversion ratio of 83% for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023 after giving effect to the PreOffering Transactions. Our typically well invested sites require only limited maintenance capital expenditure, which
amounted to $127 million for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023.

We believe that our resilience was demonstrated during the COVID-19 pandemic. As our operating countries
experienced lockdown restrictions at different times, we kept operations running in the remaining locations and
applied what we had learned at the affected sites across our network by sharing best practices. We believe this softened
the aggregate financial impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on the Group as a whole and strengthened our ability to
adapt to the developing stages of the pandemic.

**Established business models with high percentage of stores owned and operated business by the Group**

Our operating business model has powered the growth of our site network from a single UK site in 2001 to 5,937 sites
across three continents and ten countries (after giving effect to the Transactions). Our growth journey has been
facilitated by our acquisitions and our new-to-industry (“NTI”) opening program. A significant proportion of our sites
are company owned and company operated (“COCO”), which is our preferred model in most countries, and our sites
are typically larger than the average site size in most of the markets in which we operate, allowing us to generate
greater revenue per site. The table below shows how the average annual volume of fuel sold at one of our sites

**Attractive fuel and non-fuel offerings underpinned by long term relationships with key brands**

A majority of our sites have branded retail “one-stop” backcourts that seek to satisfy the multiple needs of our
customers. In addition to fuel, these sites offer a wide range of food and non-food products specifically tailored to
address the everyday household needs and preferences of its local customers.

We continuously review our brand portfolio and evaluate opportunities to partner with additional leading Fuel,
Grocery & Merchandise and Foodservice brands. Our offering is further complemented by a portfolio of our own
brands, including Cooplands, the UK’s second largest bakery business, Go Fresh, which is present mainly in the
Benelux region, and Cumberland Farms, Fastrac, Certified Oil, Sprint, Kwik Shop, Loaf ‘N Jug, Quik Stop, Tom
Thumb, Turkey Hill and Minit Mart, which are present in the United States.

The Cumberland Farms brand in particular is central to our US strategy, since its brand value is underpinned by the
sizable retail space available at most Cumberland Farms sites. Also, its large warehouse and distribution facilities are
in close proximity to our other US sites providing opportunities to grow this brand. Following the Cumberland Farms
Acquisition in October 2019, we have been able to leverage Cumberland Farms’ food production capability and private
label brands, including its Farmhouse Kitchen brand, to expand our capacity to offer our customers competitively
priced alternatives to global and regional brands, increasing the attractiveness and variety of our fresh food offerings
and providing us with a greater number of products that are exclusively available from our stores to further
differentiate us from our competitors. As part of our efforts to leverage this brand, we took the decision at the end of
2021 to commence a rebranding program of a number of sites in the United States from our Tom Thumb brand to our
Cumberland Farms brand, with 26 being completed during 2022 and an additional five in the six months ended June
30, 2023.

We proactively engage and work with well-known regional and global retail brand partners to deliver Fuel, Grocery
& Merchandise and Foodservice offerings that satisfy our customers’ evolving expectations. Brands are deployed on
a site-by-site basis through a selection process driven, in part, by local and regional tastes and preferences. As a result
of the scale and quality of our network and our strong track record as convenience store operators, we are able to
attract well-recognized global and regional brands to partner with us. For instance, we partner with Fuel brands such
as Esso, BP, Shell, Texaco and Ampol, well-known Grocery & Merchandise brands such as SPAR, Carrefour and
Louis Delhaize, and globally recognized Foodservice brands such as Starbucks, KFC, Burger King and Subway, as
well as strong local foodservice brands such as Greggs and Pomme de Pain. We continue to strengthen our brand
partnerships with our Foodservice brand partners with 102 new sites opening in the year ended December 31, 2022, a
demonstration of our commitment to expand the brand offerings.

As direct operators of the third-party branded stores, outlets and concessions located at our sites, we act as brand
ambassadors for our partners, which we believe reflects the trust our partners have in our operational capabilities. We
believe these valuable and well-known brands increase customer confidence in our products and services, leading to

**High quality real estate portfolio**

Our retail network consists of 5,937 sites after giving effect to the Transactions across the globe, many of which are
strategically located in high traffic areas. These include 3,719 company-owned sites after giving effect to the
Transactions, comprising freehold sites, leasehold sites, as well as sites that are partially freehold and partially
leasehold and concession sites. Our concession sites give us the right to develop these sites according to the terms of
the development proposal we provided to the respective seller during the open bid process.

A large proportion of our real estate portfolio in the United States and Europe consists of freehold or long leasehold
sites. As of June 30, 2023, after giving effect to the Transactions, 30% of our property portfolio based on the number
of sites was freehold, comprising 1,795 sites, 56% of our property portfolio based on the number of sites was leasehold
(including long leasehold), comprising 3,342 sites, 1% of our portfolio based on the number of sites was a hybrid of
freehold and leasehold, comprising 68 sites, 9% of our portfolio consisted of third-party sites, comprising 545 sites,
and 3% of our portfolio based on the number of sites was concessions, comprising 187 sites. While the value of our
real estate portfolio fluctuates depending on market conditions and other factors (see “Risk Factors—Ownership and
_leasing of a broad portfolio of real estate exposes us to potential losses and, liabilities and fluctuations in market_
_price”), we believe that our global real estate footprint including a large number of freehold and long leasehold sites_
provide us with long term stability. Despite current market conditions and the interest rate environment leading to
depressed valuations for commercial real estate across Europe and the United States, we still have significant real
estate value underpinning our business. According to the Real Estate Reports, based on current interest rate levels and
market conditions, the aggregated sales price of our properties (after giving effect to the Transactions) is more than
$4.0 billion (equivalent) on the basis that they are fully equipped operational entities and taking into account their
trading potential and EBITDA generation. See “Business—Property—Real Estate Reports.”

The quality of our estate is also complemented by our portfolio of 263 highway and highway-like sites in Europe
(including seven in the United Kingdom after giving effect to the Pre-Offering Transactions). Our highway sites tend
to have higher fuel margins and include Grocery & Merchandise and Foodservice offerings. Most of our highway sites

operate under our COCO model, allowing us to benefit from the full margin on Fuel, Grocery & Merchandise and
Foodservice offerings.

Our valuable real estate portfolio also provides a potential source of liquidity. Over the last few months we have been
able to, and in the future may continue to, selectively monetize portions of our real estate portfolio to take advantage
of favorable trading conditions and pursue our strategic priorities, including deleveraging on attractive terms. See “—

**Strong management team led by our co-founders**

We have an experienced and dedicated management team focused on sustainable and profitable growth for our
business, with a number of team members having over 25 years of experience with the Group or in the industry. Our
global managers include our visionary founders and co-CEOs, Zuber Issa and Mohsin Issa, who both have extensive
expertise in the convenience retail sector. Following the Issa family’s acquisition of their first site in 2001, they have
led the business to become one of the leading global independent convenience store operators. We believe that the
entrepreneurial spirit of our management team creates a culture focused on long-term, profitable growth and cash
generation.

As disclosed in “Recent Developments,” upon completion of the potential sale to Zuber Issa of the majority of the
Retained UK&I Business, he intends to step down as Co-CEO, remaining on our Board as non-executive director.
Mohsin Issa would then become our sole CEO and would continue leading our strategy going forward, supported by
our strong senior management team responsible for day-to-day operations, including John Carey, President and CEO
of EG America, Imraan Patel, Chief Strategy and Business Officer and Michael Bradley, Chief Financial Officer. John
Carey was appointed President and CEO of EG America with effect from October 1, 2023, with a mandate to drive
forward our growth strategy in the United States, our largest market by both revenue and sites.

Our decentralized management structure is composed of seven country or regional managers, each with extensive
industry experience. They are responsible for day-to-day operations in Australia, the Benelux region, France,
Germany, Italy, the United Kingdom and Ireland and the United States. The Nomination Committee of our Board
ensures a robust leadership talent pipeline and succession plans for the Board and senior management are in place,
taking account of risk areas, gender and diversity.

**Our Strategies**

Our strategy is to continue our disciplined approach to growing our market share, enhancing our profitability, ensuring
that our business is run sustainably and generating robust cash flows to drive further deleveraging and investment.

**Focus on growing our market share and optimizing our existing operations and asset base**

We aim to continue to optimize our operations to ensure that we are deriving maximum value and market share from
our existing asset base. We aim to achieve this through organic growth, developing NTI sites in strategic locations
and redeveloping certain sites as part of our KDR program, as well as through continuing to extract synergies from
past acquisitions and, where an attractive opportunity presents itself, undertaking strategic acquisitions or divestments
and realizing value from our real estate portfolio on a disciplined basis. The map below shows our current global
footprint (after giving effect to the Transactions).

8

United States

In the United States, we operate across 30 states and are the fifth largest independent convenience retailer in the
country, with a scaled coast-to-coast national footprint and various avenues for additional growth.

We believe the U.S. market provides a significant opportunity to focus on our operating initiatives, strengthen our
core business and drive sustainable growth. Going forward, we believe it could provide a blueprint for our global
initiatives to improve performance while minimizing capital spend to support our financial policy goals, focusing on
the following value propositions:

  - Winning Offer: Expand offerings with a focus on dispensed beverage, food and margin enhancing private
label while maintaining a hyper-localized approach to enhance the customer experience.

  - Winning Fuel: Drive volume growth through investment in growing segments (diesel/ B2B) while
maintaining the Group's focus on a premium offering to maximize margin.

  - Winning Customer: Engage with our active customer base through an enhanced omnichannel experience
with a focus on loyalty.

  - Winning Efficiency: Continue to focus on our expansive cost reduction measures to drive enhanced
profitability.

A key aspect of our U.S. strategy is to capitalize on the brand equity of Cumberland Farms, which we plan to do
through store rebranding initiatives as well as expanding Cumberland Farms’ well-developed private label offerings
and food production capacities. As part of these efforts, we have already commenced rebranding a number of our sites
in the United States from our Tom Thumb brand to our Cumberland Farms brand, with 26 such rebrandings being
completed during 2022 and an additional five being completed in the six months ended June 30, 2023. In addition, we
believe there are opportunities to increase the Grocery & Merchandise and Foodservice contribution from our sites
through actions such as price book optimization and reduction of product waste.

We plan to increase our Foodservice offerings in the United States, which accounted for only 3% of our gross profit
in the region for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023. We aim do this both by expanding our proprietary brands as
well as leveraging our existing partnerships with established third-party brands. We also plan to expand our SmartPay

9


-----

mobile application, as well as deploy our proprietary brands, throughout our non-Cumberland Farms estate. The
SmartPay program is a mobile application which allows us to offer and promote lower retail prices to SmartPay users
in a targeted manner through payment programs and marketing and customer savings promotions. Launched in 2013,
this program has already reached $6 billion in fuel sales and saved members more than $200 million, and we believe
it has significant potential for further growth. In addition, we opened 13 NTI sites in the United States during 2022,
while a further two NTI sites opened this year.

Europe (Continental Europe and United Kingdom and Ireland)

We are the second largest independent fuel and convenience store business in Continental Europe, with a strong
presence in key markets and a significant opportunity for additional growth.

A key part of our European strategy is to invest in our Foodservice and non-fuel offerings in the region. Our efforts to
achieve this include a rollout of well recognized Foodservice brands and outlets across Continental Europe, with 277
such outlets open as of June 30, 2023. Our growth strategy has historically also included pursuing inorganic growth
when the appropriate opportunity presents itself. For instance, we completed the acquisition of OMV’s German
forecourt business, consisting of 285 sites in southern Germany on May 1, 2022, of which 24 were divested as part of
obtaining regulatory approval for the transaction (in addition to 24 of our existing German sites). While we intend to
remain disciplined and focused on reducing net leverage, we continue to follow a disciplined approach to acquisition
opportunities both in existing markets as well as potential new ones, with a focus on driving competency, capability,
scale and balance sheet efficiencies. We also continued our expansion in Europe through additional NTI sites, with
three such sites opening in 2022 and a further four so far this year.

In addition, we recognize the accelerating shift towards alternatively fueled vehicles in Europe and the rest of the
world and plan to accelerate the roll-out of ‘evpoint,’ our proprietary electric vehicle charging proposition throughout
Europe. We had 470 EV chargers across the United Kingdom and Continental Europe at the end of 2022 and have
added a further 192 chargers as of June 30, 2023.

Our European estate also represents the highest proportion of CONCO sites, with 2,202 dealer, franchisee or retailer
operated sites at the end of 2022, largely across Italy and Germany. A key part of our growth strategy for Continental
Europe is to review and identify dealer‑operated sites which we can convert to our preferred COCO model. During
2022, 52 conversions took place and a further 20 took place in the six months ended June 30, 2023. We typically incur
little to no costs in connection with COCO conversions, unless we decide to convert CONCO sites to COCO sites
before our contracts with the relevant dealers, franchisees and retailers expire, in which case we may need to pay early
termination fees.

Australia

We are the second largest independent convenience store retailer by site numbers in Australia and aim to further
consolidate our presence in the region.

Our 525 COCO sites in Australia already include Fuel and Grocery & Merchandise offerings, however, we have been
transforming the network through continued upgrades and rebranding. In 2022, we opened seven NTI stores and have
eight sites currently under construction. We also recently rebranded from Woolworths to EG in our Grocery &
Merchandise stores and from Caltex to Ampol for Fuel.

We are focused on expanding our offers to our customers in Australia and have launched a delivery service across our
network with our delivery partners such as UBER, Menulog and DoorDash. These partnerships have allowed us to
expand our Grocery & Merchandise online offers to include virtual stores under brands such as Eats2U, Olivers and
Ben & Jerry’s. We have also expanded our B2B partnerships and have entered into partnerships with motoring
associations and large consumer organizations such as electricity providers. Through these partnerships, we provide
targeted online fuel offers to these organizations.

**Enhance Foodservice offerings and continue to grow, invest in and realize identified synergies from proprietary**
**Foodservice brands**

An increasingly important part of our strategy is the development of our Foodservice business, especially in light of
the secular growth this sector is expected to experience over the next few years, driven by changing lifestyles and
consumer preferences. Our scaled, global footprint across the Foodservice market, driven by our strong international
brand partnerships and strategic acquisitions, provides us with a strong platform from which to capitalize on this
growth trend.

We have been successfully operating Foodservice outlets for over a decade and we are a partner of choice for many
leading third‑party brands. Across the Group, we will continue to operate 1,201 Foodservice outlets after giving effect
to the Transactions. We believe that there is significant scope to further expand our Foodservice business, especially
since Foodservice offerings on a backcourt platform remain underdeveloped across most countries in which we operate
in terms of the quality and choice provided at most outlets. We are strongly positioned to fill this gap since we are
already a significant operator of scale of Foodservice sites and have established a position as a leading franchisee for
our brand partners. In recent years, our expanded Foodservice operations have transformed our sites into destinations
serving multiple customer needs, which supports an increase in customer traffic and sales volumes, and we intend to
replicate this across selected sites across the Group. This is reflected in the recent growth of our Foodservice gross
profit, which for 2022 was $705 million compared to $614 million in 2021, a year-on-year increase of 15%, and for
the six months ended June 30, 2023 was $389 million, an increase of 10% from the six months ended June 30, 2022.

We have made continued investment in Foodservice outlets globally with a total of 102 new outlets opening in the
year ended December 31, 2022. At the same time, we have continued to invest in and grow our proprietary Foodservice
brand network.

**Pursue a multi-pronged strategy for energy transition**

As the world transitions to a lower carbon future, and the demand for electric vehicles is expected to increase, we
believe the long-term trend towards electrification of vehicles presents a significant opportunity for us, and one which
we are well-positioned to capitalize on given the site network we already own. We have a multi-pronged strategy to
provide EV charging stations (also referred to herein as charge points, charging points or chargers) and alternative
fuels across our platform and a key aspect of this plan is our electric vehicle charging point strategy, in particular
‘evpoint’ – our proprietary branded, ultra-fast electric vehicle charging proposition.

We believe ‘evpoint’ has the potential to become one of Europe’s leading charge point operators. Our flagship location
at Frontier Park in Blackburn, United Kingdom, the home of six ultra-fast chargers, opened in August 2022. We
already installed ‘evpoint’ ultra-fast chargers at over 20 trial sites across the United Kingdom and Continental Europe
in 2022 and a further 33 sites in the first half of 2023. We have also earmarked a broader rollout across hundreds of
our sites through to 2026. The Retained UK&I Business will include all of our EV chargers in the United Kingdom
following the UK Disposal to Asda. With between two and six charging points per site, and innovations in charging
hardware, including load-balancing technology means several customers can use a single location simultaneously.

In the United States, our strategy has been to partner with leading third-party charge point operators on EV charge
points. These partnerships allow us to leverage our network and reach but minimize the need for deploying our own
capital. As such, our EV charge points in the United States will have third party branding, compared to our EV charge
points in Europe that will primarily have our own branding. We currently do not have any near-term plans for an EV
charger roll-out in Australia, but continue to review our strategy in this area.

We have continued our rollout of EV chargers across the United Kingdom and some sites in Continental Europe.
While we will divest most of our roadside locations in the United Kingdom when we complete the UK Disposal to
Asda, we have deliberately retained 31 well-developed sites in the UK to maintain our presence in this mature,
attractive and innovative market and to use our residual footprint there as a platform to test, adapt and fine-tune our
European EV charger offering as well as the introduction of other developing applications.

As of June 30, 2023, we operate 635 electric charging points (compared to just 250 in 2021 and 470 as of
December 31, 2022) across 189 sites in the United Kingdom and Continental Europe and have identified hundreds of
additional sites that, due to their locations and nature, are suitable for additional electric charging points as part of the

11


-----

next wave of site developments through to 2026. We plan to continue our rollout of EV chargers during the remainder
of 2023, with a further 60 electric charging points operating by the end of the year, a majority of which will be ultrafast chargers. We believe one of our key strengths in the EV charging point market lies in our expansive forecourt
footprint. For many of our competitors, their key challenges and costs include finding suitable and cost-efficient
locations on which to install EV chargers. However, our forecourts provide us access to locations, and we plan to
make continued, efficient investments in this space in order to roll out further electric charging points. The
performance of our trial EV chargers has provided us comfort that the profit margins achievable on the sale of energy
through EV chargers provide a strong business case for a broader roll out. To support this vision, we are working with
other market participants for the deployment of infrastructure and services to support energy transition demand across
our network. See “Business—Our Additional Operations—Electric Vehicle Charging Stations and Alternative Fuels.”

We believe our EV charging stations create a ‘halo effect’ by driving increased customer footfall to their locations.
Our chargers are concentrated at locations that have fulsome Grocery & Merchandise and Foodservice offerings, and
we have found that the presence of electric charging stations helps drive increased customer footfall for such other
offerings as well, since customers will typically spend time at the forecourt while their vehicle is being charged. This
increases the implied profit margin of our electric charging stations, and we believe this provides us with an advantage
over standalone electric charge point providers that do not have the advantage of our large and well-developed
forecourt network. Similarly, we also find that our EV chargers that are on well-developed forecourts benefit from
higher utilization, since customers who visit the forecourt using electric vehicles will often use that time to top-up
their charge. We expect to continue to benefit from this virtuous cycle following the UK Disposal to Asda as we have
agreed to enter into a right to occupation arrangement with Asda that would allow us to continue to use the forecourts
being sold for our existing EV chargers and to have the right to deploy additional EV chargers on any Asda sites
(including standalone forecourt sites and Asda supermarkets) in the future, including but not limited to C-Store sites
sold pursuant to the UK Disposal to Asda. In addition to providing this ‘halo effect’ and higher profit margins than
traditional fuel products, EV chargers also assist with our working capital management by reducing our need for liquid
fuel inventory.

We are conscious that alternative forms of power, other than electric, are being explored as a means to fuel cars, light
vehicles and trucks. Beyond EV chargers, we are also actively considering how compressed natural gas (“CNG”),
liquefied petroleum gas (“LPG”) and hydrogen may form part of a broader strategic program of retail fuels at our sites
to sit alongside traditional transport fuels, with a particular focus on the potential for hydrogen to power light and
heavy-duty vehicles. See “Business—Our Additional Operations—Electric Vehicle Charging Stations and Alternative
_Fuels— Alternative Fuels.”_ In addition, we are also exploring ways to reduce our carbon footprint through our energy
usage. We have already switched to renewable electricity at a number of sites across the UK and Continental Europe,
including all our sites in Luxembourg. Additionally, all of our ‘evpoint’ branded chargers sell electricity only
generated from renewable energy sources. We install solar panels wherever feasible at NTI and KDR sites, including
petrol filling stations and all suitable Foodservice sites, as well as our UK head office. Thus far in 2023, we have
generated more than 1,808,992 kWhs of electricity using solar panels. We also continue to explore battery storage
with the aim of securing self-generated electricity, and in early 2023 we installed our first battery storage unit at our
head office in the United Kingdom. Our EV chargers also generate carbon credits for us which we are currently in the
process of obtaining certification for, following which we may be able to monetize our carbon credits as we grow our
EV charging station network.

**Rationalization of portfolio and focus on strong capital structure**

During 2023, we have undertaken a number of major steps towards deleveraging and addressing our debt maturities.
In May 2023, we completed the sale and leaseback of a portfolio of our US assets, comprising 414 sites across our
Cumberland Farms, Fastrac, Tom Thumb and Sprint brands, with gross proceeds of $1.5 billion (the “U.S. Sale and
Leaseback”) and we announced the UK Disposal to Asda for consideration of £2 billion, which was completed on
October 31, 2023. In addition, we also completed or announced a number of smaller transactions, comprising (i) the
disposal of 26 company operated Minit Mart locations in the Missouri and Kansas resulting in net proceeds of $43
million in April 2023 and (ii) the sale of 55 company operated Minit Mart locations in Kentucky and Northern
Tennessee with net proceeds of $84.4 million. The net proceeds from the UK Disposal to Asda, the Amend and Extend,
the U.S. Sale and Leaseback and the Non-Core Minit Mart Disposal (Missouri and Kansas) are being used to repay
our existing senior secured debt, contributing to a total gross debt reduction of $3,816 million since June 30, 2023.

-----

In June 2023, we successfully undertook an amendment and extension process to extend the maturities of $3,169
million of euro, dollar and sterling denominated term loan facilities to 2028 under our Senior Credit Facilities
Agreement (the “Amend and Extend”), which will take effect on the Conditions Satisfaction Date (as defined herein).
See “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Senior Credit Facilities Agreement.” As a result of this activity
and our other efforts, we expect to reduce total net leverage from 6.3x for the year ended December 31, 2022 to 5.1x
after the completion of this Offering and giving effect to the use of proceeds contemplated herein. See “Capitalization”
and “Summary Consolidated Historical and As Adjusted Financial Information and Other Data—Other Financial and
_Operating Data.” We remain committed to achieving and maintaining a net leverage multiple in the mid 4x range in_
the near- to medium-term, which we aim to achieve through organic growth in earnings and free cash flow generation
and through working capital initiatives and reduced discretionary growth capital expenditures.

After giving effect to the Transactions, we will have third party debt of $229 million maturing in February 2025, $71
million maturing in March 2026, $671 million maturing in April 2027, $3,662 million maturing in February 2028 and
a further $1,589 million maturing in November 2028.

We believe that our diversified business and robust asset base put us in a strong position to access multiple pools of
liquidity to help reduce the overall quantum of our debt. For example, in order to manage our debt quantum and capital
structure we may consider releasing value from our owned real estate, potential asset sales, and/or third-party minority
equity funding for emerging businesses or concepts such as ‘evpoint’, in addition to relying on a disciplined approach
to capital expenditure, organic growth and free cashflow generation. We believe that we continue to have multiple
potential levers to support our deleveraging objective and we will continue to consider these on a selective basis where
we believe they make financial sense and align with our strategic vision.

**Continued investment in, and review of, our site network**

As an entrepreneurial business, we are always looking to drive growth by investing in our site network and developing
our retail offerings. We aim to continue to capitalize on opportunities to grow, although, especially in the current
environment, we plan to do so through a disciplined approach that is in line with our financial policy.

A key pillar of our organic growth plans is growing our footprint through the building and operation of NTI sites,
which provide us with greater ability to apply our preferred multi-format operating platform offering Grocery &
Merchandise, Foodservice and Fuel (including lower-carbon fuels) products. These NTI sites are typically larger than
our existing sites and often quickly develop into some of our best-performing sites. In line with this strategy, we
opened 31 NTI sites in 2022 (compared to 30 in 2021), out of which 13 were opened in the United States, eight in the
United Kingdom and Ireland (of which seven will be sold pursuant to the UK Disposal to Asda), seven in Australia
and three in continental Europe. In the six months ended June 30, 2023, we have completed the opening of another
seven NTI sites, out of which two opened in the US, one in the Disposed UK Business and four in Continental Europe.
Since June 30, 2023, we have opened another six NTI sites and are currently working on bringing another forty-two
to market. We have continued to grow our land bank to support future new site openings, which we expect will support
our roll-out of additional NTI sites across all of our regions.

In addition, we aim to continue to examine our site network, looking for opportunities to re-invigorate sites through
KDRs and through expansion of our offerings through either extension to existing buildings or through the purchase
of adjacent land and construction of new facilities. Our decision to undertake a KDR depends upon a variety of factors,
including potential traffic flow and customer footfall, the ability to set up or increase our Grocery & Merchandise and
Foodservice offerings, the existence of local competitors and local amenities and the site’s potential profitability.
Although our plan is to focus more on organic growth and become increasingly selective when we consider inorganic
growth opportunities, we aim to continue assessing strategic acquisition opportunities when the appropriate business
proposition presents itself. When we review acquisition targets, we look for a strategically well-located portfolio of
sites and real estate of good quality, generally underpinned by freehold value irrespective of geography.

During 2022, we completed the acquisition of OMV’s high‑quality German forecourt business, consisting of 285 sites
in Southern Germany, for a consideration of €495 million ($541 million). On a smaller scale, we also completed a
KFC acquisition in Germany, which enhanced our growing Foodservice business by providing seven additional sites,
for €27 million ($33 million). For a full list of our acquisitions since 2021, see “Management’s Discussion and
_Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Factors Affecting Comparability of Our Financial_
_Statements—Acquisitions and Disposals.” We believe we can add additional value to such sites by leveraging our_

our proprietary brands where appropriate, and generating economies by leveraging EG Group’s advantageous

**About the Issa Brothers**

Zuber Vali Issa and Mohsin Issa have been active in the forecourt sector since the acquisition of a single petrol station
in Bury, United Kingdom in 2001, which the brothers, together with their family, turned into EG Group, the largest
owner-managed forecourt retailer in the United Kingdom. The brothers have received considerable recognition for
their achievements, notably as joint 2018 EY Entrepreneur of the Year in the UK and honored in the Queen’s Birthday
Honours List 2020 for contribution to business and charity. In July 2023, Zuber Issa received an Honorary Fellowship
from the University of Central Lancashire.

As disclosed in “Recent Developments,” upon completion of the potential sale to Zuber Issa of the majority of the
Retained UK&I Business, he intends to step down as Co-CEO, remaining on our Board as non-executive director.
Mohsin Issa would then become our sole CEO.

**About TDR Capital**

TDR Capital LLP is a leading European private equity firm based in the United Kingdom, managing over €15.0 billion
of committed capital across four European buyout funds. Founded in 2002, TDR Capital LLP has been creating value
by applying a high-impact approach to investing in a focused portfolio of companies. TDR Capital LLP has a proven
value-based and operationally focused investment strategy, which is delivered by a dedicated team of investment and
operating professionals from its single office in London. TDR’s strong returns have been driven by combining
ambitious operational plans for portfolio companies with a rigorous focus on capital preservation. TDR Capital LLP
takes an active role in overseeing the transformation and growth of its investments, working in partnership with
management through board representation and professional support. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum,
TDR has invested in 24 portfolio companies across the leisure, consumer, business and financial services sectors.

TDR continue to focus on operational performance in order to provide their shareholders with the maximum range of
strategic options in future.

**_The UK Disposal to Asda_**

On May 30, 2023, we announced our binding agreement to sell a substantial majority of our Fuel, Foodservice and
Grocery and Merchandise business in the United Kingdom to Asda (the “UK Disposal to Asda”). The headline
consideration was £2 billion. For a description of the key terms of the UK Disposal to Asda, see “The Transactions—
_The UK Disposal to Asda—Sale and Purchase Agreement”._

The UK Disposal to Asda (as defined herein) was a transformational step for us. The proceeds from the UK Disposal
to Asda, along with the proceeds from the U.S. Sale and Leaseback and the Non-Core Minit Mart Disposal (Missouri
and Kansas), will be used to repay certain of our term loan facilities and Existing Notes, as described in “—Recent
_Developments—Senior Credit Facilities Amend and Extend” and to redeem a portion of our Existing Notes. See_
“Capitalization”.

The UK Disposal to Asda, along with the U.S. Sale and Leaseback, is the cornerstone of our strategy to reduce total
net leverage, extend our financing maturities and reposition our capital structure for future business growth and
financial resilience. Following the UK Disposal to Asda, we will continue to operate and maximize long-term growth
opportunities in the United States, Australia, Germany, France, Italy, the Netherlands, Luxembourg and Belgium, and
will continue to consider our strategic options in the Retained UK&I Business.

The perimeter and financial metrics of the Disposed UK Business are not identical to our business division in the
United Kingdom and Ireland. As presented in our historical financial accounts and in this Offering Memorandum, our
United Kingdom and Ireland business division’s results of operations and KPIs include the Retained UK&I Business
and do not reflect any deduction for shared service center costs attributable to such operations. However, when
adjusting our consolidated financial KPIs for the Pre-Offering Transactions or the Transactions in this Offering
Memorandum, including for the purposes of calculating Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA, we have specifically removed
amounts attributable to the Disposed UK Business, as well as for the Non-Core Asset Disposals, and have given pro
forma effect to the U.S. Sale and Leaseback.

Based on unaudited accounting records and management accounts of EG Group, we estimate that for the quarter ended
September 30, 2023 at actual currency rates, our revenue, decreased by 6%, from $8,060 million for the quarter ended
September 30, 2022, to $7,608 million for the quarter ended September 30, 2023, our gross profit decreased by 1%,
from $1,195 million for the quarter ended September 30, 2022, to $1,186 million for the quarter ended September 30,
2023 and our Adjusted EBITDA decreased by 21%, from $437 million for the quarter ended September 30, 2022, to
$345 million for the quarter ended September 30, 2023. Excluding the impact of inventory revaluations and the U.S.
Sale and Leaseback rental costs, Adjusted EBITDA decreased by 19%, from $451 million for the quarter ended
September 30, 2022, to $367 million for the quarter ended September 30, 2023.

Market volatility caused by geopolitical events following the conflict in Ukraine impacted wholesale oil prices and
demand in 2022, causing fuel prices to peak in the summer months. Consequently, during the third quarter of 2022,
the reduction in oil cost prices from the highs seen in the first half of 2022 resulted in strong fuel margins, with the
Group reporting margins of 13.0 cents per liter (excluding the impact of the EG Fuel inventory revaluation). Global
and regional energy markets have since stabilized, with oil prices settling at levels lower than the 2022 average, and
fuel retail prices returning to the levels seen prior to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine with margins in the first half of 2023
averaging 11.4 cents per liter (excluding the impact of the EG Fuel inventory revaluation).

Poor summer weather conditions in the United States and Europe, and an intensifying competitive environment in the
United States and Australia have, however, depressed fuel volumes for the third quarter of 2023, which decreased by
9%, from 4.7 billion liters for the quarter ended September 30, 2022, to 4.3 billion liters for the quarter ended
September 30, 2023. For the third quarter of 2023, global oil prices have started to increase again and the fuel margin
we expect to report in that quarter will be slightly above the average fuel margin reported in the first half of 2023.
Depressed fuel volumes, coupled with the decrease in margins versus the comparative period in the prior year, is
expected to result in a reduction in fuel gross profit and EBITDA in the third quarter of 2023, as compared to the third
quarter of 2022, as summarized in the chart below:

Our Grocery & Merchandise gross profit increased by 3%, from $365 million for the quarter ended September 30,
2022, to $376 million for the quarter ended September 30, 2023.

Our Foodservice gross profit increased by 24%, from $179 million for the quarter ended September 30, 2022, to $221
million for the quarter ended September 30, 2023.

Our Fuel gross profit decreased by 12%, from $594 million for the quarter ended September 30, 2022, to $525 million
for the quarter ended September 30, 2023.

19


-----

Our other gross margin, including car wash, rental and franchise income increased by 14%, from $56 million for the
quarter ended September 30, 2022, to $64 million for the quarter ended September 30, 2023. These increases are
largely due to the growth in the business from organic investments.

Based on the trading in October 2023, excluding the impact of the UK Disposal to Asda, the Non-Core Asset Disposals
and the U.S. Sale and Leaseback, we expect our EBITDA for October 2023 to be consistent with that reported for
October 2022.

In addition, during the third quarter of 2023, we have identified a number of initiatives that, if and when successfully
implemented, we believe may improve our overall EBITDA in the near term, which are estimated to generate EBITDA
of $25 million to $45 million. These include (i) a number of initiatives in the United States related to the impact of
further coffee and fountain beverage pricing increases, an employee benefit re-structuring cost initiative, further
growth of Smartpay, which includes a card processing fee cost saving initiative, and additional Tom Thumb to
Cumberland Farms and (ii) potential upside in Australia, where we are also developing synergies from the ongoing
rebranding from initiatives related to third party carwash, the sub-leasing of surplus retail space and we are undertaking
a re-tender of our card processing services which we believe will reduce transactional costs. Although we believe that
we are likely to implement these initiatives successfully, there is no assurance that we will be able to do so, and we
have not included these figures in the calculation of our Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA before IFRS 16 because such
initiatives remain subject to further review and finalization. See “Risk Factors––We may not be able to successfully
_implement our growth and consolidation strategies.”_

In the third quarter of 2023, rental expenses have increased by $30 million as compared to the third quarter of 2022.
This increase was primarily as a result of the U.S. Sale and Leaseback, which involved the sale and leaseback of a
portfolio of our U.S. assets, comprising of 414 sites across our Cumberland Farms, Fastrac, Tom Thumb and Sprint
brands, which we completed in May 2023.

**_By Geography_**

_Europe_

On a regional basis, Adjusted EBITDA from our European operations increased by 8%, from $215 million for the
quarter ended September 30, 2022 (Continental Europe: $142 million; United Kingdom and Ireland: $73 million) to
$233 million for the quarter ended September 30, 2023 (Continental Europe: $160 million; United Kingdom and
Ireland: $74 million). This increase was primarily due to positive inventory revaluations in our wholesale fuel supply
division, EG Fuel, with the group seeing a negative impact of $14 million in the quarter ended September 30, 2022
and a positive impact of $8 million in the quarter ended September 30, 2023. Excluding the impact of inventory
revaluations, Adjusted EBITDA from our European operations decreased by 2%, from $230 million for the quarter
ended September 30, 2022, to $225 million for the quarter ended September 30, 2023.

_United States_

Against the backdrop of higher than usual margins in the quarter ended September 30, 2022 due to the Ukraine
conflict’s impact on wholesale oil prices and demand, the U.S. business performance was impacted by a challenging
and increasingly competitive environment in addition to poor weather conditions in the quarter ended September 30,
2023. Adjusted EBITDA from our United States operations decreased by 44%, from $217 million for the quarter
ended September 30, 2022, to $122 million for the quarter ended September 30, 2023. This decrease was due to the
US sale and leaseback, which led to an increase of approximately $30 million in our rental costs, and fuel performance,
which was negatively impacted by market conditions. Excluding the impact of the sale and leaseback, Adjusted
EBITDA from our United States operations decreased by 30%, from $217 million for the quarter ended September
30, 2022, to $153 million for the quarter ended September 30, 2023.

20


-----

The main driver of our underperformance in the United States region was lower fuel margins, which declined by 3.1
cents per liter in the third quarter of 2023 compared to the third quarter of 2022. However, this decline in margin was
exacerbated by the fuel margins in the third quarter of 2022, when fuel margins were among the highest in reported
recent history due to the steep reduction in oil cost prices. While there was a decline when comparing fuel margin of
the third quarter 2023 to the third quarter of 2022, the third quarter of 2023 is in line with fuel margins for the six
months ended June 30, 2023. We continue to see outperformance in fuel margins, relative to pre-COVID levels, driven
by the structural changes in the U.S. market and we have largely seen recovery through October of 2023.

Fuel volumes also decreased in comparison to the third quarter of 2022, falling 9% due to the intensifying competitive
environment and poor weather conditions. However, despite this intensifying competitive environment, we continue
to focus on our premium fuel offering rather than chasing fuel volumes at the expense of margins.

Grocery and Merchandise sales decreased slightly for the quarter, declining by 1%. However, gross profit increased,
driven in part by improved margin from our coffee and dispensed beverage initiatives. Similarly, Foodservice sales
decreased by 1% in the third quarter of 2023, but gross margin increased from 32% to 43%, driven by store
rationalization and the closure of unprofitable concessions. Our overheads decreased in the third quarter of 2023 by
approximately $4 million as we remain focused on managing our labor spending through operational initiatives.

Adjusted EBITDA from our Australia operations decreased by 35%, from $38 million for the quarter ended September

volumes and the impact of temporary excise relief, which strengthened fuel margins during the quarter ended
September 30, 2022.

Issuer will be required to offer to repurchase all outstanding Notes at a
purchase price equal to 101% of the principal amount thereof, plus accrued
and unpaid interest to, but not including, the date of the purchase (subject to
the right of holders of record on the relevant record date to receive interest
due on the relevant interest payment date). See “Description of the Notes—
_Change of Control.”_

**Tender Offers .............................................** In connection with certain tender offers for the Notes, if holders of not less
than 90% in aggregate principal amount of the applicable outstanding Notes
validly tender and do not withdraw such Notes in such tender offer and the
Issuer, or any third party making such a tender offer in lieu of the Issuer,
purchases, all of the Notes validly tendered and not withdrawn by such
noteholders, the Issuer or such third party will have the right to redeem the
Notes that remain outstanding in whole, but not in part, following such
purchase at a price equal to the price offered to each other holder of Notes.
See “Description of the Notes—Optional Redemption.”

**Certain Covenants ......................................** The Indenture will limit, among other things, the ability of the Issuer to:

                       - incur or guarantee additional indebtedness and issue certain
preferred stock;

                       - pay dividends on, redeem or repurchase our capital stock;

                       - make certain restricted payments;

                       - make certain investments;

                       - create or permit to exist certain liens;

                       - impose restrictions on the ability of our subsidiaries to pay
dividends or make other payments to us;

                       - merge or consolidate with other entities, or make certain asset sales;

                       - enter into certain transactions with affiliates; and

                       - impair the security interests for the benefit of the holders of the
Notes.

Each of the covenants in the Indenture will be subject to significant
exceptions and qualifications. See “Description of the Notes—Certain
_Covenants.”_

30


-----

**Transfer Restrictions .................................** The Notes and the Guarantees have not been registered under the Securities
Act or the securities laws of any other jurisdiction and will not be so
registered. The Notes are subject to restrictions on transferability and resale.
See “Notice to Investors.” Holders of the Notes will not have the benefit of
any exchange or registration rights.

**Listing/No Prior Market ............................** Application will be made to The International Stock Exchange Authority
Limited (the “Authority”) for the listing of and permission to deal in the
Notes on the Official List of The International Stock Exchange (the
“Exchange”). There can be no assurance that the Notes will be listed on the
Official List of the Exchange, that such permission to deal in the Notes will
be granted or that such listing will be maintained. The Notes will be new
securities for which there is no market. Although certain of the Initial
Purchasers have informed us that they intend to make a market in the Notes,
they are not obligated to do so and they may discontinue market making at
any time without notice. Accordingly, we cannot assure you that an active
trading market for the Notes will develop or be maintained.

**Risk Factors ................................................** Investing in the Notes involves substantial risks. You should consider
carefully all the information in this Offering Memorandum and, in particular,
you should evaluate the specific risk factors set forth in the “Risk Factors”
section before making a decision whether to invest in the Notes.

**Governing Law ...........................................** The Notes and the Indenture will be governed by New York law.

The Intercreditor Agreement is governed by English law. The Security
Documents (as defined in “Description of the Notes”) will be governed by
the laws of Belgium, England and Wales, Germany, Italy, the Netherlands,
New South Wales and New York.

**RISK FACTORS**

_An investment in the Notes involves risks. Before investing in the Notes, you should consider carefully the following risk factors_
_and all information contained in this Offering Memorandum. Additional risks and uncertainties of which we are not aware or_
_that we believe are immaterial may also adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations. If any of_
_these events occur, our business, financial condition and results of operations could be materially and adversely affected, the_
_Issuer may not be able to pay interest or principal on the Notes when due and you could lose all or part of your investment._

_This Offering Memorandum also contains forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties. Our actual results_
_may differ materially from those anticipated in these forward-looking statements as a result of various factors, including the_
_risks described below and elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum._

_The sequence in which the risks are presented below is not necessarily indicative of their importance, their likelihood of_
_occurrence or the scope of their financial consequences._

**Risks Related to Our Market and Our Business**

**_An economic downturn or a significant deterioration in macroeconomic conditions could have a material adverse effect on_**
**_our operations._**

Our financial performance is dependent on national and regional economic conditions and consumer confidence in Australia,
Belgium, France, Germany, Italy, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, the United Kingdom and the United States. Since early 2022,
many of these countries have reported persistent high inflation. Concurrently, central banks in these countries have raised
interest rates in order to fight inflationary pressures and have discussed the possibility of further such rate increases. Such
increases in interest rates may reduce growth and may result in a global or regional recession. The combination of high inflation
and increases in interest rates may also result in a decrease in the disposable income of consumers. Further market volatility
may occur as inflation continues to rise and markets respond to the interest rate increases and the cessation of quantitative
easing programs by major central banks. Our business may be adversely impacted by macroeconomic factors such as a potential
long-term and widespread recession (which may affect disposable incomes, unemployment rates and consumer credit levels),
higher energy costs and fluctuations in commodity prices (including changes in fuel prices), inflationary pressures, and the
availability and cost of credit, which could each affect consumer confidence and, in turn, impact the level of consumer spending
on our products and services. As a result, an adverse change in economic conditions may have a material adverse effect on our
business, financial condition, liquidity and results of operations.

If our customers are negatively affected by an economic downturn or a significant deterioration in macroeconomic conditions,
they may spend less on our products and services, and we may generate less revenue. When the economy slows, demand for
freight and trucking is reduced, which may reduce vehicle travel distance and reduce demand for our products and services
from commercial drivers. Likewise, leisure travelers affected by a deterioration in macroeconomic conditions may decide that
they can no longer afford to travel, reducing vehicle travel distance, or that when they do travel, they may spend less at our
sites. Increased unemployment rates during an economic downturn may reduce footfall from commuters and business
customers. For example, during the first half of 2023, we have seen continued reduced footfall caused by a shift to hybrid
working, reducing travel requirement for employees. These impacts on footfall and customer spending have had a
corresponding negative effect on our ability to generate revenue at levels consistent with or higher than at present. Such a
decrease in footfall at our PFS sites in particular adversely impacted our margins and revenue, as Grocery & Merchandise and
Foodservice products offered at our PFS sites are often priced higher than similar products at non-fuel station retail outlets.

Additionally, as commodities and energy are subject to significant price fluctuations and volatility, current high inflation rates
continue to increase pressure on our earnings, as we may not be able to preserve our profit margin during periods of increased
inflation without suffering reduced revenue. Relatedly, increased inflation may lead to increased personnel costs and wage
pressures. We may not always be able to pass such increased costs, in part or in whole, onto our customers, which may reduce
our profit margins. These factors could, in turn, have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results
of operations.

In addition, an economic downturn may cause financial stress, performance issues and outright failure by one or more third
parties with whom we enter into agreements, including fuel supply agreements and brand partnership agreements, potentially
resulting in substantial costs to us. For example, fuel suppliers would normally seek to pass increased raw materials costs
through to us, especially if they are experiencing financial stress, and may be able to do so depending on our contractual
relationship with them and our ability to obtain an alternative supply of fuel.


-----

A deterioration in economic conditions could also heighten pressure on the governments in the markets in which we operate.
Governments could take measures to raise additional revenue during an economic downturn, including the imposition of higher
fuel taxes.

Challenging economic conditions could also increase the cost of capital and negatively impact our ability to access the capital
markets and secured lending markets on financial terms acceptable to us. There can be no assurance that our liquidity will not
be inhibited by events affecting the capital markets or that our capital resources will at all times be sufficient to satisfy our
liquidity requirements. Any increase in interest rates will increase the interest we pay on our debt, which will negatively affect
our ability to generate free cash flow. This, in turn, may hinder our ability to repay the Notes.

**_Fluctuations in the price of fuel and non-fuel products may negatively affect our business._**

Any increase in the prices at which we purchase our inventory or our costs in partnering with third parties could adversely
affect the margins on the fuel and non-fuel products and services we sell, and we may not be able to raise our prices due to
economic conditions, competition, regulation, contractual terms or other factors. For example, while we are generally free to
set prices and select stock and promotional offers for our non-fuel products and services at our sites, the terms of our commercial
relationships with our franchise and other partners could require us to set prices no higher than their recommended retail price.
Attempts to pass price increases on to our customers could also negatively affect both short-term and long- term demand for
our products.

Fuel prices have been high in recent years and have fluctuated as a result of various factors, many of which are beyond our
control, such as global and regional supply and demand, geopolitical and economic uncertainty, such as the Russia-Ukraine
conflict, which has threatened supply lines and resulted in embargoes of certain supply sources, and the most recent escalation
of military and diplomatic tensions in the Middle East, as well as pricing and availability of competing alternative fuel
technologies. Changing fuel prices and the inability to project future prices can from time to time impact our business. For
example, changing fuel prices affect the market value of our fuel inventories and expose us to significant fluctuations in the
recorded value of our inventory and the related costs of goods sold, thus reducing our profit margins. In particular, when fuel
cost prices increase, whether as a result of governmental intervention or global oil market conditions, we may not always be
able to pass such increase onto our customers, which may reduce our fuel margins. Fluctuations in cost prices may be
exacerbated in the future, for example, as a result of environmental legislation or regulation. We may face pressure from
consumers and governments to not increase our fuel retail prices and governments in countries where we operate may also
institute fuel price regulation. For example, the program agreement between the Ministers of Economy and Energy and Energia
(formerly the Belgium Petroleum Federation) in Belgium determines the maximum cost for the most common petroleum
products and the way in which these prices can change. As such, there can be no assurance that the price of fuel will remain
stable or that we will be able to pass any price increases onto our consumers, in a timely manner or at all, resulting in higher
expenses, lower margins and other material adverse effects on our business, financial condition, and results of operations.

Because fuel costs are a significant expense for many of our customers, higher fuel prices may also have an adverse impact on
discretionary spending and travel. For example, for the six months ended June 30, 2023, we saw price sensitive consumers
switching to lower price competitors in the United States. Higher fuel prices have previously caused shipping companies to
consider alternative means for transporting freight, which reduces commercial traffic on motorways and highways and, in turn,
negatively impacts our business. A reduction in road traffic and customer footfall may also negatively impact sales volumes
for our non-fuel products and services.

Higher fuel and non-fuel prices could cause some of our customers to institute cost-saving measures such as seeking out lowerpriced competitors. The publishing of weekly average fuel prices, whether by the government in countries like the United
Kingdom or by private websites in countries like Germany, increase the risk posed by such lower-priced competitors by
increasing the chances of our customers choosing to purchase fuel from them. Lowering our prices to mitigate these risks can
also have a negative impact on our working capital and cash position, as lower prices may not be offset by increased volumes.
Additionally, lower prices could affect our profitability. If prices or fluctuations thereof increase, there could be material
adverse effects on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Higher fuel prices will also increase the operating costs of our sites. For example, higher fuel prices would increase the costs
of appropriate cold chain requirements for the grocery and foodservice sites. Any increase in fuel prices could lead to a decrease
in margin on grocery and foodservice, negatively impacting our business, financial condition and results of operations.

**_We are dependent upon our suppliers and partners, their brands and their reputations._**

We offer Fuel, Grocery & Merchandise and Foodservice products and services to our customers largely pursuant to agreements
with a number of franchise and other partners, including prominent fuel brands such as Esso, BP, Shell and Texaco, well known


-----

Grocery & Merchandise brands such as Asda ‘on the Move’, Woolworths, Carrefour, Louis Delhaize and SPAR, and globally
recognized Foodservice brands such as Starbucks, Burger King, Subway and KFC, as well as strong local brands such as
Pomme de Pain, and Greggs. These partnerships and their accompanying brands are a key component of our business, and most
of our revenue is generated from products offered through such partners under their brand names. However, we do not have
direct operational or financial control over our partners and have limited influence with respect to the manner in which they
conduct their businesses. Therefore, we may not be able to influence the development of these brands. In addition, given the
long-term nature of our partnership and franchise agreements, there is a risk that a particular brand may lose popularity during
the term of the relevant agreement and the relevant agreement may contain limited opportunities for early termination and/or
contain stringent non-compete provisions which may limit our ability to implement the best commercial offering at a particular
site.

Our operations depend on the reputations of our partners and their brands and corresponding consumer perceptions. The brands
we offer at our sites could be damaged by claims or perceptions about the quality or safety of our partners’ products or the
quality of our or their suppliers and distributors, regardless of whether such claims or perceptions are true. Similarly, our
partners, and entities in their supply chain, may engage in conduct that damages the reputations of the brands we offer.
Reputational damage to our partners may also occur due to factors beyond their control such as fall out from natural disasters
affecting, or accidents occurring, at their oilfields or oil refineries, contaminated food products, severe allergic reactions to food
products or outbreaks of crop or livestock disease. In addition, our partners may also incur reputational damage by failing to
maintain environmental and social governance standards. Any reputational harm, negative publicity or negative public
perception of our partners or their brands could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, and results
of operations.

Certain of our partnerships have regular renewal dates, and we may not be able to renew our partnerships on favorable terms,
in a timely manner or at all. See “Business— Descriptions of Our Operations by Region” for more information on partnership
renewal dates. For example, our contract with SPAR in the Netherlands expired in August 2023 but is continuing on the same
terms while a new deal is being negotiated. In particular, the renewal of our contracts can be challenging if our partners insist
on price control mechanisms that could restrict our ability to increase selling prices. We may incur high costs in trying to find
alternative suppliers or partners. The loss of one or more of our franchise and other partnership agreements could have a
significant impact on our ability to attract customers and our operations, and we may be unable to find a suitable replacement,
particularly for fuel supplies.

Our brand agreements generally grant us the right to use the brand principals’ intellectual property in connection with the
development, operation, promotion, marketing and management of their brands. While the brand principals remain primarily
responsible for the protection of the intellectual property associated with their brands, if we or the brand principals fail to
identify unauthorized filings of the brand principals’ trademarks, or either of us fail to adequately protect the brand principals’
trademarks and copyrights, the infringement of the intellectual property rights associated with these brands may cause harm to,
or a diminution in value of, the relevant brand, and possibly a decrease in sales, in turn causing an adverse effect on our
profitability and results of operation.
