financial condition and results of operations. There can be no assurance that any assets which we could be required to dispose
of could be sold or that, if sold, the timing of such sale and the amount of proceeds realized from such sale would be acceptable.

Furthermore, our inability to meet payment obligations under our existing debt could trigger various default provisions,
accelerate a substantial portion (if not all) of our debt, and would materially affect our business, financial condition and results
of operations.

**_We are subject to significant restrictive debt covenants, which limit our operating and financial flexibility._**

The Indenture and the Existing Indentures contain covenants which impose significant operating and financial restrictions on
us. These agreements limit our ability to, among other things:

  - incur or guarantee additional indebtedness or issue certain preferred stock;

  - make certain restricted payments and investments;

  - transfer or sell assets or enter into sale and leaseback transactions;

  - enter into transactions with affiliates;

  - create or incur certain liens;

  - make certain loans, investments or acquisitions;

  - create or incur restrictions on the ability of our subsidiaries to pay dividends or to make other payments to us;


-----

  - take certain actions that would impair the security interests in the Collateral granted for the benefit of the holders of
the Notes; and

  - merge, consolidate or transfer all or substantially all of our assets.

These covenants could limit our ability to finance our future operations and capital needs and our ability to pursue acquisitions
and other business activities that may be in our interest.

**_Our failure to comply with the covenants under the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement, the Second Lien Credit Facilities_**
**_Agreement, the Existing Indentures or the Indenture, including as a result of events beyond our control, could result in an_**
**_event of default which could materially and adversely affect our financial condition and results of operations._**

The Senior Credit Facilities Agreement and the Second Lien Credit Facilities Agreement require us to, among other things,
comply with certain financial ratios. Our ability to meet these financial requirements could be affected by deterioration in our
operating results, as well as by events beyond our control, including unfavorable economic conditions, and we cannot assure
you that we will be able to meet these tests in the future.

Moreover, a breach of any covenant in the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement, the Second Lien Credit Facilities Agreement,
the Existing Indentures, the Indenture or the agreements governing any other debt that we may have outstanding from time to
time could result in a default under that respective agreement after any applicable grace period. If a default occurs, the holders
of the Existing Notes and the Notes and the lenders under the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement and the Second Lien Credit
Facilities Agreement may elect to declare all such notes or borrowings, as applicable, together with accrued interest and other
fees, to be immediately due and payable. The lenders under the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement and the Second Lien Credit
Facilities Agreement also have the right in these circumstances to terminate any commitments they have to provide further
borrowings. If we are unable to repay our indebtedness when due or declared due, the lenders under the Senior Credit Facilities
Agreement and the Second Lien Credit Facilities Agreement and the holders of the Existing Notes and the Notes or of any
other secured indebtedness will also have the right to proceed against the collateral, including cash, granted to them to secure
such indebtedness. If the indebtedness under the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement, the Second Lien Credit Facilities
Agreement, the Existing Indentures and the Indenture were to be accelerated, we cannot assure you that our assets would be
sufficient to repay such indebtedness, including the Notes, in full, and we could be forced into bankruptcy or liquidation.

**_Hedging agreements may expose us to credit default risks and potential losses if our hedging counterparties fall into_**
**_bankruptcy._**

From time to time, we may enter into interest hedging or currency agreements to hedge our exposure to fluctuations in interest
rates, primarily under the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement, or foreign exchange rates. Under any such agreements, we would
be exposed to credit risks of our counterparties. If one or more of our counterparties falls into bankruptcy, claims we have
under the swap agreements or other hedging arrangements may become worthless. In addition, in the event that we refinance
our debt or otherwise terminate such hedging agreements, we may be required to make termination payments, which would
result in a loss. See “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Liquidity and
_Capital Resources—Hedging.”_

**_Our ability to repay our debt depends on many factors beyond our control. If we are unable to raise capital in the future, we_**
**_may seek other avenues to fund the business, including sale/leaseback arrangements or seeking to sell assets of all, or a_**
**_portion of, our operations._**

Payments on our debt will depend on our ability to generate cash or secure additional financing in the future. This ability, to
an extent, is subject to general economic, financial, competitive, legislative, regulatory, and other factors beyond our control.
If our business does not generate sufficient cash flow from operations and sufficient future financing is not available to us, we
may not be able to repay our debt, operate our business or fund our other liquidity needs. If we cannot meet or refinance our
obligations when they become due, we may be required to attempt to raise capital, reduce expenditures, or take other actions
which we may be unable to successfully complete or, even if successful, could have a material adverse effect on us. If such
sources of capital are not available or not available on sufficiently favorable terms, we may seek other avenues to fund the
business, including sale/leaseback arrangements or seeking to sell assets of all or a portion of our operations. If we are unable
to raise capital, our ability to effectively operate our business could be impaired.

**Risks Related to the Notes**

**_No appraisals of any of the Collateral have been prepared by us or on our behalf in connection with the issuance of the_**
**_Notes. The Notes will be secured only to the extent of the value of the Collateral that has been granted as security for the_**


-----

**_Notes and the Guarantees and such security may not be sufficient to satisfy the obligations under the Notes and the_**
**_Guarantees._**

No appraisals of any of the Collateral have been prepared by us or on our behalf in connection with the issuance of the Notes.
There is no guarantee that the value of the Collateral will be sufficient to enable the Issuer to perform its obligations under the
Notes. There is no requirement to provide funds to enhance the value of the Collateral if it is insufficient. The proceeds of any
sale of the Collateral following an event of default with respect to the Notes may not be sufficient to satisfy, and may be
substantially less than, amounts due on the Notes. In addition, the Collateral will secure on a first-ranking basis our obligations
under the Senior Credit Facilities, the Existing Notes and certain hedging obligations, if any. Additionally, the Collateral may
also secure additional debt to the extent permitted by the terms of the Indenture, the Existing Indentures, the Senior Credit
Facilities Agreement and the Intercreditor Agreement. The rights of holders of the Notes to the Collateral may be diluted by
any increase in the first-priority debt secured by the Collateral.

The amount of proceeds realized upon the enforcement of the security interests over the Collateral or in the event of liquidation
will depend upon many factors, including, among others, general market and economic conditions, the condition of the market
for the Collateral, the ability to sell the Collateral in an orderly sale, the fair value of the Collateral, the availability of buyers,
the timing and manner of the sale, whether or not our business is sold as a going concern, the ability to readily liquidate the
Collateral, the availability of buyers and the condition of the Collateral, as applicable. Further, there may not be any buyer
willing and able to purchase our business as a going concern, or willing to buy a significant portion of its assets in the event of
an enforcement action.

The value of the Collateral may be subject to significant changes in value due to economic or regulatory trends. The book value
of the Collateral should not be relied on as a measure of realizable value for such assets. Portions of the Collateral may be
illiquid and may have no readily ascertainable market value. In the event of a foreclosure, liquidation, bankruptcy or similar
proceeding, we cannot assure you that the proceeds from any sale or liquidation of this Collateral will be sufficient to pay our
obligations under the Notes. In addition, share pledges of an entity may be of no value if that entity is subject to an insolvency
or bankruptcy proceeding.

**_The Notes will be secured over substantially the same assets that secure the Senior Credit Facilities, the Existing Notes and_**
**_the Second Lien Credit Facilities, and will share in any enforcement proceeds on a pari passu basis with the Senior Credit_**
**_Facilities and the Existing Notes._**

The rights of the holders of the Notes with respect to the Collateral will be subject to the Intercreditor Agreement. Under the
Intercreditor Agreement, any enforcement action that may be taken with respect to the security will be undertaken by the
Security Agent. The Security Agent is required to take enforcement action upon receiving instructions from an instructing
group of holders of a majority of the aggregate outstanding principal amount of all our liabilities that qualify as senior liabilities
secured on a first-priority basis under the Intercreditor Agreement, which will include the Notes, the Existing Notes and
borrowings under the Senior Credit Facilities. The Collateral will also secure the Second Lien Credit Facilities on a junior basis
under the Intercreditor Agreement.

The Notes will be secured over substantially the same assets that secure the Senior Credit Facilities and the Existing Notes,
provided that, in accordance with the Agreed Security Principles, the Senior Credit Facilities and the Existing Murray Notes
are also secured by security interests over certain assets of EG Holdings (France) SAS and EG Retail (France) SAS, which do
not secure the Second Lien Credit Facilities, the Existing Cirrus Notes or the Notes. While the Intercreditor Agreement includes
an equalization provision relating to the Notes, the Senior Credit Facilities and Existing Notes, the enforceability of this
equalization provision is uncertain. See “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Non-Distressed Disposals—
_Equalization.”_

The Senior Credit Facilities Agreement, the Second Lien Credit Facilities Agreement, the Existing Indentures and the Indenture
permit us to issue additional notes or other indebtedness that will share in the Collateral. If we issue additional notes or procure
additional senior indebtedness secured on a first-priority basis in the future which, taken together with the Existing Notes and
outstanding borrowings under the Senior Credit Facilities, represents a majority of the aggregate outstanding principal amount
of all our liabilities that qualify as senior liabilities under the Intercreditor Agreement, the holders of such other senior
indebtedness may acquire the right to direct the Security Agent to take enforcement action ahead of the holders of the Notes.

As a result of the voting provisions set forth in the Intercreditor Agreement, certain amendments, waivers and other actions
under the Intercreditor Agreement and in relation to the Collateral will require consent from the required majority of holders
of the Notes, the required majority of holders of any _pari passu senior secured indebtedness (including the creditors of the_
Senior Credit Facilities and the Existing Notes), the required majority of “super senior creditors” in respect of any indebtedness
which is permitted to be secured on a super senior basis under the Intercreditor Agreement and, in certain circumstances, the


-----

required majority of holders of any junior indebtedness. The Intercreditor Agreement provides that the Security Agent will
serve in respect of the Collateral for the secured parties under the Intercreditor Agreement and will act with respect to the
Collateral only at the direction of the relevant “instructing group” and in accordance with the enforcement principles set out
therein.

As of the Issue Date, the aggregate principal amount outstanding under the Senior Credit Facilities and the Existing Notes is
significantly greater than the aggregate principal amount of the Notes, corresponding to higher voting power within the relevant
instructing group of creditors of the Senior Credit Facilities and the Existing Notes compared to holders of the Notes.
Furthermore, to the extent we incur additional indebtedness that is secured on a _pari passu_ basis with the Notes (such as
additional indebtedness under the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement or the Existing Indentures), the voting interest of holders
of the Notes in the relevant instructing group will be diluted commensurate with the amount of such indebtedness we incur.

**_The security provided does not attach to substantially all assets of the Australian Guarantors, which may restrict the ability_**
**_to enforce that security during the decision period under section 441A of the Australian Corporations Act._**

If the security provided does not attach to all or substantially all of the assets of the Australian company, there is a risk at
Australian law that the secured creditor may be restricted in its ability to enforce that security by appointing a receiver during
the decision period under section 441A of the Australian Corporations Act. Each general security deed granted by the Australian
Guarantors provides for customary exclusions of certain assets from the scope of that security, and if sufficient assets of the
Australian Guarantors are subject to these exclusions, there may be a risk that the security provided does not attach to
substantially all assets of the Australian Guarantors, which may restrict the ability to enforce that security during the decision
period under section 441A of the Australian Corporations Act.

**_It may be difficult to realize the value of the Collateral securing the Notes._**

The Collateral securing the Notes will be subject to any and all exceptions, defects, encumbrances, liens, security interests and
other imperfections permitted under the Indenture or the Intercreditor Agreement and accepted by other creditors that have the
benefit of first-priority security interests in the Collateral securing the Notes, from time to time, whether on or after the date
the Notes are first issued, including lenders under the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement and holders of the Existing Notes.
The existence of any such exceptions, defects, encumbrances, liens, security interests and other imperfections could adversely
affect the value of the Collateral securing the Notes, as well as the ability of the Security Agent to realize or foreclose on such
Collateral. Furthermore, the priority ranking of security interests can be affected by a variety of factors, including, among
others, the timely satisfaction of perfection requirements, or statutory liens.

**_Rights of holders of Notes in the Collateral may be materially adversely affected by the failure to create or perfect security_**
**_interests in the Collateral on a timely basis or being junior security interests._**

Under applicable law, a security interest in certain tangible and intangible assets may only be properly perfected, and even if
properly perfected may only attain its intended priority, through certain actions undertaken by the secured party and/or the
grantor of the security, such as registration with a relevant court or other authority or notification of a third party, or taking
possession or control of the relevant Collateral or the entry into a subordination agreement with any third party that has a prior
ranking security interest in the relevant Collateral. The security interests on the assets securing the Notes may not be perfected
with respect to the claims of the Notes, or even if properly perfected may not attain a first ranking priority, if we or the Security
Agent, fail or are unable to take the actions required to perfect any of these security interests or to attain that first ranking
priority. Any hardening period under insolvency law with respect to the Collateral will not commence until such security has
been perfected. The Security Agent will have no obligation to perfect or take actions required to perfect any of the security
interests, or to attain a first ranking priority.

There can be no assurance that the Security Agent will monitor, or the Trustee, or that we or any security provider will inform
the Security Agent or the Trustee, and that the necessary actions will be taken to properly create, perfect and re-perfect the
security interest in any future assets and or rights or to preserve the security interest over time. Such failure may adversely
affect the enforceability of such security interest and/or the priority of such security interest in favor of third parties, including
a receiver in insolvency proceedings and other creditors who have a claim in the same security interest.

In addition, depending on the jurisdiction of the relevant security documents and the location of the Collateral, the security
interests of the Noteholders in respect of the Collateral owned by certain members of the Group may be considered to be junior
to the security interests granted under the Senior Credit Facilities, the Existing Notes and the Second Lien Credit Facilities.
The Intercreditor Agreement provides that such junior security interests will be deemed and treated as security interests ranking
_pari passu_ with the security interests securing the Senior Credit Facilities. If the Intercreditor Agreement or the relevant
provisions thereof were voided or held to be unenforceable for any reason, holders may not benefit from such first-priority


-----

treatment and may be subordinated, with respect to such security interests, to senior security interests over the same Collateral
securing other indebtedness of the Parent, the Issuer and the restricted subsidiaries, which may result in greater risk and loss of
principal.

**_The granting of the security interests in connection with the issuance of the Notes, or the incurrence of permitted debt in_**
**_the future, may create or restart hardening periods._**

The granting of the security interests in connection with the issuance of the Notes, or the incurrence of permitted debt in the
future, may create or restart hardening periods, which are the periods of time following the granting of security interests during
which such security interests may be challenged in accordance with relevant laws.

The granting of security interests to secure the Notes and the Guarantees may create hardening periods for such security interests
in certain jurisdictions. The granting of shared security interests (including the security interests in the Collateral), including in
connection with any release and retake of such security interests, to secure existing, new or future indebtedness permitted to be
secured on the Collateral may restart or reopen such hardening periods in particular, because the Indenture permits the release
and retaking of security granted in favor of the relevant Notes in certain circumstances, including in connection with the
incurrence of future indebtedness. The applicable hardening period for these new security interests can run from the moment
each new security interest has been granted, perfected, amended, shared or recreated (as applicable). At each time, if the security
interest granted or recreated were to be enforced before the end of the respective hardening period applicable in such
jurisdiction, it may be declared void or ineffective and/or it may not be possible to enforce it.

**_Noteholders’ ability to enforce certain rights in connection with any Guarantee, or security interest in the Collateral, granted_**
**_by a Guarantor that is incorporated under the laws of Australia may be limited or affected by Australian insolvency_**
**_legislation relating to “ipso facto” rights._**

Under the Australian Corporations Act, rights under a contract, agreement or arrangement (such as a right entitling a creditor
to terminate a contract or to accelerate a payment under a contract) arising merely because a company, among other specified
circumstances, is under administration, has appointed a managing controller or is the subject of an application under section 411
of the Australian Corporations Act or because of its financial position during such proceedings (i.e., “ipso facto rights”), will
generally not be enforceable during a prescribed moratorium period. The specified circumstances do not include a winding up
or liquidation.

These laws apply to ipso facto rights arising in respect of companies incorporated under the laws of Australia (which relevantly
would include a Relevant Australian Company) under contracts, agreements or arrangements entered into at or after July 1,
2018, subject to certain exclusions specified in the Australian Corporations Regulations.

The Australian Corporations Regulations provide that a contract, agreement or arrangement that is, or governs, securities,
financial products, bonds or promissory notes will be exempt from the moratorium. Furthermore, a contract, agreement or
arrangement that is, or is directly connected with, a securities financing transaction is also excluded from the moratorium.
Accordingly, the Australian Corporations Regulations should exclude from the stay those Guarantees and security interests in
the Collateral that are granted by Relevant Australian Companies. However, as the relevant provisions of the Australian
Corporations Act and the Australian Corporations Regulations are relatively new to the insolvency regime in Australia, they
have not been the subject of extensive judicial interpretation and there remains some uncertainty as to the scope of the
application of the exclusion to guarantees or securities granted by a Relevant Australian Company, given that the relevant
contract, agreement or arrangement must be “directly connected” with a securities financing transaction. If the Australian
Corporations Regulations are determined not to exclude those Guarantees and security interests in the Collateral that are granted
by Relevant Australian Companies, this may render unenforceable in Australia any provisions of those Guarantees and security
interests that are granted to Relevant Australian Companies, conditioned solely on the occurrence of events giving rise to ipso
facto rights. Investors should seek independent advice on the implications (if any) of these laws and regulations on their
investment in the Notes.

**_The Collateral is subject to casualty risks and potential environmental liabilities._**

We intend to maintain insurance or otherwise insure against hazards in a manner appropriate and customary for our business.
There are, however, certain losses that may be either uninsurable or not economically insurable, in whole or in part. Insurance
proceeds may not compensate us fully for our losses. If there is a complete or partial loss of any of the pledged Collateral, the
insurance proceeds may not be sufficient to satisfy all of the secured obligations, including the Notes and the Guarantees.

In addition, even if there is sufficient insurance coverage, there may be significant delays in obtaining the insurance proceeds
or replacement Collateral. As a result, if we incur an event that damages or destroys certain Collateral, it could reduce the


-----

aggregate value of the Collateral, which could reduce the amounts payable to you from the proceeds of any sale of the Collateral
in the case of an enforcement of the liens securing the Notes.

Moreover, the Security Agent may need to evaluate the impact of potential liabilities before determining to foreclose on
Collateral consisting of real property because owners and operators of real property may be held liable under environmental
laws for the costs of remediating or preventing the release or threatened release of hazardous substances at such real property,
and the property itself could become subject to a lien, under environmental laws for the costs of remediating or preventing the
release or threatened release of hazardous substances at such real property. Consequently, the Security Agent may decline to
foreclose on such Collateral or exercise remedies available in respect thereof if it does not receive indemnification to its
satisfaction from the holders of the Notes.

**_Enforcing your rights as a holder of the Notes or under the Guarantees or in the Collateral across multiple jurisdictions_**
**_may be difficult._**

The Notes will be issued by the Issuer, which is incorporated under the laws of England and Wales and will be guaranteed by
certain subsidiaries that are incorporated under the laws of Australia, Belgium, England and Wales, Germany, Italy, the
Netherlands and the U.S. states of California, Delaware, Pennsylvania, Wyoming, Vermont, Massachusetts and Virginia.
Security interests to secure the Notes and guarantees will be granted in collateral located in certain of these jurisdictions. In the
event of bankruptcy, insolvency or a similar event, proceedings could be initiated in any of these jurisdictions or in the
jurisdiction of organization of a future Guarantor. Your rights under the Notes, the Collateral and the Guarantees will therefore
be subject to the laws of multiple jurisdictions, and you may not be able to enforce effectively your rights in multiple
bankruptcy, insolvency and other similar proceedings. Moreover, such multi-jurisdictional proceedings are typically complex
and costly for creditors and often result in substantial uncertainty and delay in the enforcement of creditors’ rights.

In addition, the bankruptcy, insolvency, foreign exchange, administration and other laws of the various jurisdictions may be
materially different from or in conflict with one another and those of the United States, including in respect of creditors’ rights,
priority of creditors, the ability to obtain post-petition interest and the duration of the insolvency proceeding. The consequences
of the multiple jurisdictions involved could trigger disputes over which jurisdiction’s law should apply which could adversely
affect your ability to enforce your rights and to collect payment in full under the Notes and the Guarantees. In addition, certain
jurisdictions may impose limitations on the ability of foreign creditors to enforce security interests, including, for example,
requiring registration or approval under foreign ownership regulations. The laws of certain of the jurisdictions in which the
Guarantors are incorporated or organized further limit the ability of these subsidiaries to guarantee debt of, or provide security
for, other companies.

**_The security over the Collateral will not be granted directly to the holders of the Notes and the concept of “trust” is not a_**
**_recognized concept in certain jurisdictions._**

The security interests in the Collateral that will secure the obligations of the Issuer and the Guarantors under the Notes and the
Guarantees, respectively, will not be granted directly to the holders of the Notes but will be granted only in favor of the Security
Agent for the Notes and to the Security Agent for the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement, the Existing Notes and the Second
Lien Credit Facilities Agreement. The Intercreditor Agreement will provide for the creation of “parallel debt” obligations in
favor of the Security Agent mirroring the obligations of the Issuer and the Guarantors (as principal obligors) towards the holders
of the Notes under or in connection with the Indenture. The Intercreditor Agreement will provide that only the Security Agent
has the right to enforce the Security Documents. As a consequence, the holders of the Notes will not be entitled to take
enforcement action in respect of the Collateral securing the Notes, except through the Trustee for the Notes, who will provide
instructions to the Security Agent in accordance with the Intercreditor Agreement. Holders of the Notes will also bear some
risks associated with a possible insolvency or bankruptcy of the Security Agent as the beneficiary of the parallel debt.

There can be no assurances that such a “parallel debt” structure will be recognized and effective in all cases. There is some
uncertainty under the laws of certain jurisdictions, such as Italy, as to whether obligations to beneficial owners of the Notes
that are not identified as registered holders in, nor are directly parties to, a security document will be validly secured and/or can
be enforced; this area of law is untested in the courts of certain jurisdictions. There can be no assurances that such a parallel
debt structure will be recognized and effective in all cases in all relevant jurisdictions and several of the relevant jurisdictions
do not provide for the parallel debt construct and such structures have not been tested in the relevant courts and it cannot be
excluded that a court might not hold up the parallel debt construct and that parallel debt provisions would not be applicable.
See “Certain Insolvency Law Considerations and _Limitations on the Validity and Enforceability of the Guarantees and the_
_Security Interests.” To the extent that the security interests in the Collateral created for the benefit of the Security Agent as_
parallel debt creditor under the parallel debt construction are successfully challenged by other parties, holders of the Notes will
not be entitled to receive on this basis any proceeds from an enforcement of the security interests in the Collateral.


-----

To the extent that the security interests in the Collateral created for the benefit of the Security Agent are successfully challenged
by other parties, holders of the Notes could not be entitled to receive on this basis any proceeds from an enforcement of the
security interests in the Collateral. In addition, the holders of the Notes may bear risks associated with the possible insolvency
or bankruptcy of the Security Agent.

**_Holders of the Notes will not control certain decisions regarding the Collateral and the sale of particular assets could reduce_**
**_the pool of assets securing the Notes._**

The Security Documents will, subject to the terms of the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement, the Second Lien Credit Facilities
Agreement, the Existing Indentures and the Indenture, allow the Issuer and the Guarantors to remain in possession of, retain
control over, freely operate, and collect, invest and dispose of any income from the Collateral. So long as no acceleration event
under the Indenture is occurring or would result therefrom, the Issuer and the Guarantors, may, among other things, without
any consent by the Security Agent, conduct ordinary course activities with respect to the Collateral, such as selling, factoring
or otherwise disposing of Collateral and making ordinary course cash payments, including repayments of indebtedness. Any
of these activities could reduce the value of the Collateral and consequently the amounts payable to holders of the Notes from
the proceeds of any sale of the Collateral in the case of an enforcement.

**_If the Revolving Credit Facilities are designated as super senior liabilities in accordance with the terms of the Intercreditor_**
**_Agreement, creditors under the Revolving Credit Facilities and counterparties to certain hedging obligations and other_**
**_indebtedness permitted to be incurred under the terms of the Indenture and the Intercreditor Agreement ranking pari passu_**
**_with the Revolving Credit Facilities are entitled to be repaid with proceeds from the enforcement of the Collateral in priority_**
**_over the Notes._**

The Intercreditor Agreement includes provisions governing the sharing of proceeds from enforcement of the Collateral. Such
enforcement proceeds are required to be turned over to the Security Agent after certain events, including the acceleration of
the Notes. The Security Agent is required to apply turned-over amounts and other recoveries by the Security Agent from
enforcement actions toward discharging the super senior obligations (including, among others, (following the designation of
the Revolving Credit Facilities as super senior liabilities in accordance with the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement) those
under the Revolving Credit Facilities, certain hedging obligations and other indebtedness that may be secured on a super senior
basis (the “Super Senior Liabilities”)) in priority to applying any such amounts toward discharging the Notes. As such, in the
event of a foreclosure of the Collateral, you may not benefit from such recoveries if the then outstanding claims under such
Super Senior Liabilities are greater than the proceeds recovered. Any proceeds remaining from an enforcement sale of
Collateral will, after all obligations under such Super Senior Liabilities have been discharged, be applied pro rata in repayment
of the Senior Credit Facilities (other than the Senior Credit Facilities constituting Super Senior Liabilities), the Existing Notes,
the Notes, and any other indebtedness that ranks pari passu with the Notes. Furthermore, claims of our secured creditors that
are secured by assets that do not also secure the Notes will have priority with respect to such assets over the claims of holders
of the Notes. As such, the claims of the holders of the Senior Secured Notes will be effectively subordinated to the rights of
such secured creditors to the extent of the value of the assets securing such indebtedness.

**_We may not be able to repurchase the Notes upon a change of control._**

The Indenture will contain provisions relating to certain events constituting a “Change of Control” as defined in the Indenture.
Upon the occurrence of such events (subject to certain exceptions), we will be required to offer to repurchase all outstanding
Notes at a price equal to 101% of their principal amount, plus accrued and unpaid interest and Additional Amounts, if any, to
the date of repurchase. If a change of control event were to occur, we cannot assure you that we would have sufficient funds
available at such time, or that we would have sufficient funds to provide to the Issuer to pay the purchase price of the outstanding
Notes or that the restrictions in the Intercreditor Agreement or our other than existing contractual obligations would allow us
to make such required repurchases. A change of control may result in an event of default under, or acceleration of, our other
indebtedness. The repurchase of the Notes pursuant to such an offer could cause a default under such indebtedness, even if the
change of control itself does not. If an event constituting a change of control event occurs at a time when the Group is prohibited
from providing funds to the Issuer for the purpose of repurchasing the Notes, we may seek the consent of the lenders under
such indebtedness or may attempt to refinance the borrowings that contain such prohibition. If such a consent to repay such
borrowings is not obtained, the Issuer will remain prohibited from repurchasing any Notes. In addition, we expect that we
would require third-party financing to make an offer to repurchase the Notes upon a change of control. We cannot assure you
that the Group would be able to obtain such financing.

**_Holders of the Notes may have adverse tax consequences in the event of an IPO Pushdown or in certain other circumstances._**

Under certain circumstances, we may undertake an IPO Pushdown (as described in “Description of the Notes—IPO
_Pushdown”), pursuant to which the Parent is entitled to give notice that the terms of the Indenture and the Intercreditor_


-----

Agreement (or any Additional Intercreditor Agreement (as defined in “Description of the Notes—Certain Covenants—
_Additional Intercreditor Agreements”)) will automatically operate so that, among other things, the references to the Parent and_
Restricted Subsidiaries (as defined in “Description of the Notes—Certain Definitions”) (and all related provisions) shall apply
only to the IPO Pushdown Entity (as defined in “Description of the Notes—IPO Pushdown”) and its Restricted Subsidiaries.
In such event, each holding company of the IPO Pushdown Entity would be released from its obligations under the Indenture
governing the Notes. In addition, in certain circumstances some or all of the Guarantees by the Guarantors could be released
and terminated, as described further under “Description of the Notes—Notes Guarantees Release.”

In either case, such a modification to the terms of the Notes could be treated for U.S. federal income tax purposes as a deemed
exchange of (i) the Notes as in place prior to such modifications for (ii) new Notes as in place after such modifications (“New
Notes”). If such modifications resulted in a deemed exchange, such a deemed exchange could be treated as a taxable transaction
for U.S. federal income tax purposes in which beneficial owners of the Notes could be required to recognize gain or loss.
Furthermore, for U.S. federal income tax purposes, the New Notes deemed issued in such a deemed exchange could be treated
as issued with original issue discount. In such event, U.S. Holders (as defined under “Certain Taxation Considerations—
_Certain U.S. Federal Income Tax Considerations”) would be required to include the original issue discount in their income as_
it accrues, in advance of the receipt of cash corresponding to such income. In addition, the determination of whether the New
Notes are treated as “contingent payment debt instruments” as a result of the possibility of additional payments, as further
described under “Certain Taxation Considerations—Certain U.S. Federal Income Tax Considerations—Characterization of
_the Notes,” would be made at the time of the modification. U.S. Holders should consult their own tax advisors as to the U.S._
federal income tax considerations relating to modification of the Notes in connection with the IPO Pushdown or other
circumstances in which Guarantees could be released and terminated.

**_Our current and future variable interest rate debt may be impacted by applicable regulation and may bear interest that could_**
**_rise significantly, thereby increasing our costs and reducing our cash flow._**

Substantially all of our debt (other than the Notes and the Existing Notes) bears interest at a variable rate, and we have been
and will continue to be exposed to the risk of fluctuations in interest rates. These interest rates have risen significantly more
recently and could continue to rise significantly in the future, increasing our interest expense associated with these obligations,
reducing cash flow available for capital expenditures and hindering our ability to make payments on the Notes. Although we
have entered into and maintained certain hedging arrangements designed to fix a portion of these rates, there can be no assurance
that hedging will continue to be available on commercially reasonable terms. Hedging itself carries certain risks, including that
we may need to pay a significant amount (including costs) to terminate any hedging arrangements. To the extent interest rates
continue to rise significantly, our interest expense would correspondingly continue to increase, thus reducing cash flow.

In addition, any elimination of any applicable benchmark, or changes in the manner of administration of such benchmark, could
require an adjustment to the terms and conditions of our floating rate debt. Any such consequence could have a material adverse
effect on the value of and return on any such floating rate debt. If any applicable benchmark was discontinued or otherwise
unavailable, the rate of interest on our floating rate debt will be determined for the relevant period by the fallback provisions
applicable to such debt.

**_There are circumstances other than repayment or discharge of the Notes under which the Collateral securing the Notes and_**
**_the Guarantees will be released automatically and under which the Guarantees will be released automatically, without your_**
**_consent or any action on the part of the Trustee._**

Under various circumstances, the Collateral securing the Notes and the Guarantees will be released automatically, including,
among others, the following:

  - in connection with any sale or other disposition of Collateral not prohibited under the Indenture;

  - with respect to Collateral owned by a Guarantor, upon the release of such Guarantor from its Guarantee as described
under “Description of the Notes—Notes Guarantees—Notes Guarantees Release”;

  - with respect to any Collateral, upon the release or discharge of the Security Interests granted over such Collateral in
favor of the Lenders under the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement, the Second Lien Credit Facilities Agreement, any
Credit Facilities that refinance or replace any amounts outstanding under such facilities or any successor facilities
thereof except a release as a result of repayment of any such facilities (other than pursuant to a refinancing in which
the refinancing indebtedness does not benefit from any security in such Collateral); provided that the security interests
over such Collateral granted in favor of the holders of any outstanding Existing Notes are also released or discharged


-----

at such time (or will be released or discharged substantially concurrently with the release or discharge of the security
interest over such Collateral granted in favor of the Holders of the Notes); or

  - if such property or other asset is or becomes an asset excluded from the grant of Security Interests pursuant to any
Security Document.

The Indenture will also permit us to designate certain of our Subsidiaries as Unrestricted Subsidiaries. See “Description of the
_Notes—Certain Covenants—Designation of Restricted and Unrestricted Subsidiaries.” If we designate a Guarantor as an_
Unrestricted Subsidiary for purposes of the Indenture, the Security Interests in respect of the Collateral owned by such
Subsidiary or any of its Subsidiaries and any Guarantees provided by such Subsidiary or any of its Subsidiaries will terminate
and be released under the Indenture, but not necessarily under our Credit Facilities. Designation of an Unrestricted Subsidiary
will reduce the aggregate value of the Collateral securing the Notes to the extent that liens on the assets of the Unrestricted
Subsidiary and its Subsidiaries are released. Any of these events will reduce the aggregate value of the Collateral securing the
Notes.

In addition, under various circumstances, the Guarantees will be released automatically, including while any obligations under
the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement, the Second Lien Credit Facilities Agreement, or any Credit Facilities that refinance or
replace any amounts outstanding under such facilities or any successor facilities thereof remain outstanding, the Guarantee of
a Guarantor may terminate and be released without action by, or consent of, the holders of the Notes, the Trustee or the Security
Agent under the Indenture if such Guarantor is no longer a guarantor of the obligations under the Credit Facilities and the
Existing Notes, subject to certain exceptions. See “Description of the Notes—Notes Guarantees—Notes Guarantees Release.”
Upon the closing of a direct or indirect disposal of a Guarantor to a Person which is not a member of the Group, or other
transaction pursuant to which that Guarantor will cease to be a member of the Group and which, in each case, is not prohibited
by the terms of the applicable Credit Facility, the obligations of such Guarantor under the applicable Credit Facility will, subject
to the satisfaction of certain conditions, be discharged and released. In addition, if any shares of a Guarantor are subject to
certain permitted interest transfers under the Credit Facilities, including transfers of such shares in connection with permitted
joint ventures or similar arrangements, or a Guarantor otherwise ceases to be a wholly owned subsidiary of another member of
the Group, the guarantee of such Guarantor under the applicable Credit Facility may automatically terminate and be released.
The lenders under our Credit Facilities will have the discretion to release the guarantees under our Credit Facilities in a variety
of other circumstances. The Indenture will also permit the Guarantee of a Guarantor to terminate and be released without action
by, or consent of, any holder of the notes in certain other circumstances as described under “Description of the Notes—Notes
_Guarantees—Notes Guarantees Release.” You will not have a claim as a creditor against any Subsidiary that is no longer a_
Guarantor, and the Indebtedness and other liabilities, including trade payables, whether secured or unsecured, of those
Subsidiaries will effectively be senior to claims of noteholders.

See “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Intercreditor Agreement” and “Description of the Notes.”

**_The Notes and the Guarantees will be subject to certain limitations on enforcement and may be limited by applicable laws_**
**_or subject to certain defenses that may limit their validity and enforceability._**

Generally, a court could subordinate or void the Notes or the Guarantees under various corporate purpose or benefit, fraudulent
conveyance or transfer, voidable preference, insolvency or bankruptcy challenges, financial assistance, preservation of share
capital, thin capitalization, capital maintenance or similar laws or regulations affecting the rights of creditors generally if, at
the time the Notes were issued or one of the Guarantors entered into a Guarantee:

  - the amount paid or payable under the relevant Guarantee was in excess of the maximum amount permitted under
applicable law;

  - the relevant Guarantee or security interest was incurred with actual intent to hinder, delay or defraud creditors or
shareholders of the Guarantor or, in certain jurisdictions, even when the recipient was simply aware that the Guarantor
was insolvent when it granted the relevant Guarantee or security interest;

  - the Guarantor did not receive fair consideration or reasonably equivalent value for granting the relevant
Guarantee/security interests and the Guarantor was: (i) insolvent or rendered insolvent because of the relevant
Guarantee/security interest; (ii) undercapitalized or became undercapitalized because of the relevant Guarantee; or

The Notes are a new issue of securities and there is no established trading market for them, and we cannot assure you that an

institutional buyers” as defined under Rule 144A, and to persons that are “not U.S. persons” outside of the United States as
defined under Regulation S.

Future trading prices for the Notes will depend on many factors, including, among other things, prevailing interest rates, our

subject to disruptions that have caused substantial volatility in the prices of securities similar to the Notes. The liquidity of a
trading market for the Notes may be adversely affected by a general decline in the market for similar securities and is subject
to disruptions that may cause volatility in prices. The trading market for the Notes may attract different investors and this may

**_Investors may face foreign exchange risks by investing in the Notes._**

The Dollar Notes will be denominated and payable in U.S. dollars and the Euro Notes will be denominated and payable in euro.
If investors measure their investment returns by reference to a currency other than U.S. dollars or euro, an investment in the
Notes will entail foreign exchange-related risks due to, among other factors, possible significant changes in the value of the
U.S. dollar or euro relative to the currency by reference to which such investors measure the return on their investments,
including as a result of exchange controls imposed in relation to such currencies by the authorities with jurisdiction over those
currencies. These changes may be due to economic, political and other factors over which we have no control. Depreciation of
the U.S. dollar or euro against the currency by reference to which such investors measure the return on their investments could
cause a decrease in the effective yield of the Notes below their stated coupon rates and could result in a loss to investors when
the return on the Notes is translated into the currency by reference to which such investors measure the return on their
investments. Investments in the Euro Notes by U.S. investors may also have important tax consequences as a result of foreign
exchange gains or losses, if any. Foreign exchange and losses relating to the Notes may also have tax consequences for investors
in other jurisdictions. See in particular “Certain Tax Considerations—Certain U.S. Federal Income Tax Considerations” and
“Certain Tax Considerations—Certain United Kingdom Taxation Considerations.”

**_The Notes will initially be held in book-entry form and therefore investors must rely on the procedures of the relevant_**
**_clearing systems to exercise any rights and remedies._**

The Notes will initially only be issued in global registered form and held through DTC (with respect to the Dollar Notes) and
Euroclear and Clearstream (with respect to the Euro Notes). Interests in the global notes will trade in book-entry form only,
and Notes in definitive registered form will be issued in exchange for book-entry interests only in very limited circumstances.
Owners of book-entry interests will not be considered owners or holders of Notes. The nominee for DTC will be the sole
registered holder of the global notes representing the Dollar Notes and the common depositary, or its nominee, for Euroclear
and Clearstream will be the sole registered holder of the global notes representing the Euro Notes. Payments of principal,
interest and other amounts owing on or in respect of the global notes representing the Notes will be made to the relevant paying
agent, which will make payments to DTC or Euroclear and Clearstream, as applicable. Thereafter, these payments will be
credited to participants’ accounts that hold book-entry interests in the global notes representing the Notes and credited by such
participants to indirect participants. After payment to the nominee for DTC and the common depositary for Euroclear and
Clearstream, as applicable, none of the Issuer, the Trustee, the Paying Agent, the Transfer Agent or the Registrar will have any
responsibility or liability for the payment of interest, principal or other amounts to the owners of book-entry interests.
Accordingly, if investors own a book-entry interest, they must rely on the procedures of DTC or Euroclear and Clearstream, as
applicable, and if investors are not participants in DTC or Euroclear and Clearstream, as applicable, they must rely on the
procedures of the participant through which they own their interest, to exercise any rights and obligations of a holder of Notes
under the Indenture.

Unlike the holders of the Notes themselves, owners of book-entry interests will not have the direct right to act upon the Issuer’s
solicitations for consents, requests for waivers or other actions from holders of the Notes. Instead, if an investor owns a bookentry interest, it will be permitted to act only to the extent it has received appropriate proxies to do so from DTC or Euroclear
and Clearstream, as applicable. The procedures implemented for the granting of such proxies may not be sufficient to enable
such investor to vote on a timely basis.

Similarly, upon the occurrence of an event of default under the Indenture, unless and until Definitive Registered Notes (as
defined herein) are issued in respect of all book-entry interests, if investors own book-entry interests, they will be restricted to
acting through DTC or Euroclear and Clearstream, as applicable. The procedures to be implemented through DTC or Euroclear
and Clearstream, as applicable, may not be adequate to ensure the timely exercise of rights under the Notes.

**_Credit ratings may not reflect all risks, are not recommendations to buy or hold securities and may be subject to revision,_**

The credit ratings address our ability to perform our obligations under the terms of the Notes and credit risks in determining
the likelihood that payments will be made when due under the Notes. The ratings may not reflect the potential impact of all

withdrawal by the rating agency at any time. No assurance can be given that a credit rating will remain constant for any given
period of time or that a credit rating will not be lowered or withdrawn entirely by the credit rating agency if, in its judgment,
circumstances in the future so warrant. A suspension, reduction or withdrawal at any time of the credit rating assigned to the
Notes by one or more of the credit rating agencies may adversely affect the cost and terms and conditions of our financings and
could adversely affect the value and trading of the Notes. In addition, if any of our other outstanding debt is rated and

could materially adversely affect our ability to finance our ongoing operations and to refinance our indebtedness. The effects

business, financial condition and results of operations.

**_The Intercreditor Agreement requires that noteholders respond to requests for consent or details of its participation within_**
**_a certain period of time in order to be deemed to have participated in respect of the relevant matter._**

The Intercreditor Agreement includes provisions governing voting procedures for classes of creditors, including the
noteholders. If in relation to a request for a consent, to participate in a vote of a class of creditors, to approve any action or to
provide any confirmation or notification, in each case, under the Intercreditor Agreement or the Indenture, any creditor fails to
respond to the request within a specified number of business days or fails to provide details of its credit participation to the
Security Agent within a specified time, such creditor will be disregarded or be deemed to have zero participation in respect of
the matter or be deemed to have provided the relevant confirmation or notification, as applicable, provided that this provision
shall not apply to any noteholder in respect of a request where such noteholder is not given the option to respond to such request
in the negative. As such, any noteholder who does not wish to vote in favor of a request for a consent, but does not submit a
negative vote through the relevant voting system, will not have such noteholder’s preference counted.

**_A series of Notes may be issued with original issue discount (“OID”) for U.S. federal income tax purposes._**

A series of Notes may be issued with OID for U.S. federal income tax purposes. In that event, U.S. investors generally will be
required to include OID in gross income (as ordinary income) on an annual basis under a constant yield accrual method,
regardless of their regular method of accounting for U.S. federal income tax purposes. As a result, U.S. investors will generally
include any OID in income in advance of the receipt of cash attributable to such income. For more information, see “Certain
_Taxation Considerations—Certain U.S. Federal Income Tax Considerations.”_

**_The Italian Golden Power legislation may restrict our ability to pursue certain transactions or restrict the ability of investors_**
**_to acquire a significant stake in our share capital._**

EG Italia may be subject to the Italian Golden Power Legislation, pursuant to which the Italian Golden Power Authority can,
among others, prohibit or impose restrictions, conditions and undertakings on: (i) the acquisition of shareholdings in companies
holding assets and contractual relationships in sectors qualified as strategic (notably, defense and national security, energy,
transport, communications, healthcare, agri-food and financial, amongst others), and (ii) resolutions, acts or transactions
approved by companies holding assets and contractual relationships in strategic sectors and resulting in a change in ownership,
control, possession of such strategic assets or relationships or in the use or purpose thereof, including the enforcement and,
according to a prudential interpretation, the granting or extension of securities over the shares and strategic assets of the said
companies.

In particular, acquisitions of controlling interests by individuals or entities belonging to the European Union (including Italy)
and acquisitions of interests by persons or entities not belonging to the European Union that entail the direct or indirect
acquisition of at least 10% of the voting rights or share capital (provided that the value of investments is at least €1 million)
must be reported to the Italian Golden Power Authority for the possible exercise of the veto right or the application of
restrictions, conditions and undertakings; acquisitions that exceed the 15%, 20%, 25% and 50% of the voting rights or share
capital thresholds are also subject to the reporting obligation.

Acquisitions of controlling interests by individuals or entities belonging to the European Union are subject to the Italian Golden
Power Legislation only if related to companies holding assets and relationships in the communications energy, transport,
healthcare, agri-food and financial sectors. In the defense and national security sector, the relevant threshold is more than 3%
of the voting rights or share capital for both European Union and non-European Union investors (it does not apply only to
acquisitions by Italian public authorities or entities controlled by such authorities). Resolutions, acts or transactions approved
by a company holding assets and relationships in strategic sectors that give rise to changes in the ownership, control or
possession of such assets, or in the use or purpose thereof, including the enforcement and, according to a prudential
interpretation, the granting or extension of securities over the shares or strategic assets must also be reported within ten days,
and in any case prior to their implementation, to the Italian Golden Power Authority.

As a result, our ability to pursue commercial or industrial strategic resolutions, acts or transactions that involve, inter alia, the
direct or indirect acquisition of, or the subscription for, the shares of EG Italia may be impacted by the exercise by the Italian
Golden Power Authority of its powers under the Italian Golden Power Legislation. On a more general note, if EG Italia is
involved, directly or indirectly, in any transaction, act or resolution falling in the scope of the Italian Golden Power Legislation,
the Italian Golden Power Authority may veto or impose conditions to consent to the implementation of such transaction, act or
resolution, which may be material. Accordingly, we may not be permitted to undertake such transaction, act or resolution in a
timely fashion, without remedies or undertakings, or at all.

Therefore, the Italian Golden Power Legislation could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations,
financial condition or prospects. Furthermore, our shareholders’ ability to enter into change of control or takeover transactions


-----

relating to shareholdings in our share capital may be impacted by the exercise by the Italian Golden Power Authority of its
powers under the Italian Golden Power Legislation. Our shareholders may not be able to transfer their interests or such a
transfer may be subject to conditions, which diminish the value of the transaction. Failure to comply with the reporting
obligation provided under the Italian Golden Power Legislation or with any veto or undertakings imposed by the Italian Golden
Power Authority may result in the relevant transaction, act or resolution being unwound or declared null and void, and in the
perpetrators being subject to material monetary fines.

**_The enforcement and, according to a prudential interpretation, the granting/extension of the pledge over the shares of EG_**
**_Italia will require clearance under the Italian Golden Power Legislation._**

EG Italia may be subject to the Italian Golden Power Legislation, pursuant to which the Italian Golden Power Authority can,

**THE TRANSACTIONS**

**The Transactions**

On or around the Issue Date, we intend to enter into committed financing in respect of additional senior term loan facilities
comprising (i) a term facility in a principal amount of €          (the “Tranche E Facility B (EUR)”) and (ii) a term facility
in a principal amount of $          (the “Tranche E Facility B (USD)”, together with Tranche E Facility B (EUR), the
“Tranche E Term Facilities” and each a “Tranche E Term Facility”) provided for under our existing Senior Credit Facilities
Agreement. See “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Senior Credit Facilities Agreement.”

On or about the Issue Date, we will use the gross proceeds from the Offering and the Tranche E Term Facilities to (i) redeem
the Existing Notes and (iii) pay fees and expenses incurred in connection with the Offering Transactions. The Offering, the
Tranche E Term Facilities and such use of proceeds therefrom, collectively, are referred to as the “Offering Transactions”. The
Offering Transactions, the UK Disposal to Asda, the Amend and Extend, the U.S. Sale and Leaseback (as defined herein), the
Non-Core Asset Disposals and the application of the proceeds therefrom, collectively, are referred to as the “Transactions”.

application of the proceeds therefrom (excluding from the Non-Core Minit Mart Disposal (Kentucky and Tennessee)) to repay

**_Non-Core Minit Mart Disposal (Kentucky and Tennessee)_**

The Non-Core Minit Mart Disposal (Kentucky and Tennessee) refers to the sale of 65 of our convenience retail locations in
Kentucky and Tennessee, which operate under the Minit Mart and Certified Oil banners. As of November 3, 2023, we had
completed the sale of 55 of these sites in a sale to Casey’s General Stores, Inc. for gross consideration of $101.4 million and
net proceeds of $84.4 million. The C-Store site numbers presented in this Offering Memorandum, when adjusted for the
Transactions or the Pre-Offering Transactions, are adjusted for the sale of 63 sites, which include the 55 sites we have sold as
of November 3, 2023 and an additional eight sites which are held for sale and for which we are actively looking for a buyer.
We will continue to evaluate our strategic options in relation to the remaining two sites.

**Non-Core Minit Mart Disposal (Missouri and Kansas)**

In April 2023, we completed the Non-Core Minit Mart Disposal, consisting of 26 non-core company operated Minit Mart
locations in Missouri and Kansas with net proceeds of $43 million.

**Sale and Leaseback Transaction**

**_Overview and Structure_**

EG America, LLC entered into a sale-leaseback arrangement pursuant to that certain Agreement of Purchase and Sale of Real
Estate dated as of February 27, 2023, as amended by that certain First Amendment to Agreement for Purchase and Sale of Real
Estate dated as of March 6, 2023, that certain Second Amendment to Agreement for Purchase and Sale of Real Estate dated as
of March 31, 2023, that certain Third Amendment to Agreement for Purchase and Sale of Real Estate dated as of May 2, 2023,
as amended and restated by that certain Amended and Restated Agreement for Purchase and Sale and Contribution of Real
Estate (the “SLB Purchase Agreement”) dated as of May 15, 2023, pursuant to which EG America, LLC, along with Junior
Food Stores of West Florida, Inc. dba Tom Thumb, Fastrac EG, LLC, Cumberland Farms, Inc. and CFI PropCo 2, LLC, agreed
to sell, or contribute, to MDC Obsidian Holdings, LLC and its subsidiaries named therein (collectively, “Realty Income”) four
hundred-fourteen (414) properties valued at $1,494,284,744.43. In connection with the closing of the SLB Purchase Agreement,
EG America, LLC or its affiliates received aggregate cash of $1,455 million and received a five percent (5%) interest in MDC
Obsidian, LLC (a subsidiary of Realty Income), which previously acquired ninety (90) real property assets from affiliates of
CIM Real Estate Finance Trust, Inc.

In connection with the SLB Purchase Agreement, EG America, LLC or its affiliate, as tenant, along with Realty Income, as
landlord, entered into eight (8) master leases (each a “Master Lease” and collectively, the “Master Leases”) encumbering the
properties located in Massachusetts, Rhode Island, New York, Connecticut, New Hampshire, Maine, Vermont, Florida,
Alabama, Georgia, and South Carolina.


-----

**_Post-Closing Obligations_**

Following the consummation of the sale-leaseback transaction, EG America, LLC remained obligated for a period of twelve
(12) months from the date of the applicable Master Lease to use commercially reasonable efforts, at its sole cost and expense,
to resolve various non-material diligence items at certain of the properties. The resolution of those diligence items included
obtaining easements, combining tax parcels, and obtaining certain Phase II environmental studies (and performing any required
remediation obligations in connection therewith).

**_Material Master Lease Terms_**

_Term_

The initial term of the Master Leases vary between eighteen (18) and twenty-two (22) years, with an average initial term of
twenty (20) years. In addition, each Master Lease contains eight (8) extensions of five (5) years each, which must be exercised
with respect to no less than fifty percent (50%) of the properties described in each such Master Lease. The applicable extension
term automatically renews unless EG America, LLC or its affiliate, as tenant, provides written notice, no later than six (6)
months prior to the expiration of the then current term, setting forth the property or properties for which the Master Lease will
not be extended.

_Rent_

The Master Leases are “triple net”, which require EG America, LLC or its affiliate to make monthly installments of the annual
rent payments in addition to paying all costs, expenses and obligations arising thereunder with respect to the properties and all
improvements and appurtenances related thereto.

_Guarantor_

The obligations of EG America, LLC or its affiliate as tenant under each Master Lease are unconditionally guaranteed by EG
America, LLC and the Parent, as guarantors (collectively, the “Master Lease Guarantors”). Pursuant to each guaranty, in certain
instances whereby an event of default is occurring under a Master Lease, any indebtedness of EG America, LLC or its affiliate
party to the respective Master Lease and held by the Master Lease Guarantors, is subordinated to the right of payment to the
obligations under the Master Lease secured by that certain guaranty.

_Maintenance, Alterations and Expansion_

Pursuant to the Master Leases, EG America, LLC or its affiliate, as tenant, is obligated to repair, rebuild, replace and maintain
each property. EG America, LLC or its affiliate may make structural and non-structural alterations to the properties or construct
one or more new buildings or additional structures or expand the existing improvements; provided, however, consent by Realty
Income is required if it is anticipated that such structural alterations or contemplated expansions would materially decrease the
value, building footprint or functionality of such property.

_Right of First Refusal_

In the event that Realty Income, as landlord, desires to directly or indirectly transfer any property to a third party, it shall first
offer EG America, LLC or its affiliates, party to such Master Lease, the right to purchase such property. The right of first offer
is conditioned upon (i) no event of default then occurring under the subject Master Lease and (ii) is personal to the original
tenant thereunder.

_Assignment and Subletting_

The Master Leases contain broad assignment and subletting rights in favor of EG America, LLC or its affiliate party thereto.
However, EG America, LLC or its affiliate, as tenant, must provide at least thirty (30) days’ prior written notice in connection
with a transfer, change of control of the tenant or guarantor, or a material sublease (a sublease of eighty percent (80%) or more
of the properties). Further, EG America, LLC or its affiliate, as tenant, must obtain the consent of Realty Income, as landlord,
in the event of an assignment of less than all of the properties constituting the premises under each such Master Lease in
connection with any direct assignment of the Master Lease by EG America, LLC or its affiliate party thereto.

_Events of Default_

The Master Leases contain a customary event of default provision, which events of default include: (i) the failure of EG
America, LLC or its affiliate, as tenant, to pay any amounts due and owing under the Master Lease or to perform any non

-----

monetary obligation required to be performed by the tenant within the applicable notice and cure period (if such non-monetary
failure results in a material adverse effect on such property or properties); (ii) a default by the guarantor under the guaranty
beyond the applicable notice and cure period; (iii) a transfer of the Master Lease in violation of the terms set forth therein which
is not cured within the applicable notice and cure period; and (iv) the bankruptcy of tenant or guarantor, including a general
assignment for the benefit of creditors, the appointment of a receiver or trustee, or a liquidation or dissolution thereof.

_Terminations due to Casualty and Condemnation_

Pursuant to the Master Leases, EG America, LLC or its affiliate party thereto, as tenant, may only terminate the Master Lease
with respect to the effected property in the event that: (i) following a casualty during the least year of the term, the buildings
with respect to a property are damaged twenty-five percent (25%) or more of their insurable value, tenant’s access to the
property is impaired and the property is therefore rendered unfit for ordinary use, or tenant’s operations at the property are
significantly impaired for more than ninety (90) days; (ii) all or substantially all of any property is taken by eminent domain;
(iii) during the last year of the term, a temporary taking occurs with respect to any property; or (iv) following a partial
condemnation, the continued operation of tenant’s business is no longer commercially advantageous, the parking is reduced by
fifteen percent (15%) or more, reasonable access to the property is frustrated, or the appropriation has a material adverse effect
on tenant’s use of the property.

**_Investment in MDC Obsidian, LLC_**

Pursuant to the SLB Purchase Agreement, Cumberland Farms, Inc., an affiliate of EG America, LLC acquired an interest in
MDC Obsidian, LLC (“Obsidian”) pursuant to that Amended and Restated Limited Liability Company Agreement of Obsidian,
dated as of May 16, 2023 (the “Obsidian Agreement”).

_Purpose – The purpose and business of Obsidian is (either itself or through subsidiaries) to acquire, own, operate and maintain_
the properties it owns, and in connection therewith to finance, refinance, pledge, encumber, own, operate, lease, manage, repair,
redevelop, renovate, construct, improve, dispose of and otherwise deal with such properties and other Obsidian assets acquired
by Obsidian and to perform all other activities necessary, customary, advisable, desirable, ancillary or incidental to the
furtherance of such purpose.

_Percentage Interests – 95% to MSC Obsidian Holdings, LLC (“Realty Income Member”) and 5% to Cumberland Farms, Inc._
(“Investor Member”).

_Initial Capital Contributions – $743,968,045.49 by MDC Obsidian Holdings, LLC and $1,214,108,901.94 by Cumberland_
Farms Inc., of which $1,174,952,689.02 was distributed to Cumberland Farms, Inc., such that the Capital Account Balance of
Cumberland Farms, Inc. as of the date of the Obsidian Agreement was equal to $39,156,212.92.

_Additional Capital Contributions – If Obsidian requires additional equity capital prior to the expiration of the Tax Protection_
Period, the Investor Member has a pre-emptive right (but no obligation) to fund its pro rata share of any such equity capital
required.

_Distributions – pro rata to the Members in proportion to their respective Percentage Interests (as set forth above)._

_Management – Obsidian is managed by the Realty Income Member as the managing member who is vested with the exclusive_
right to manage Obsidian.

_Transfers of Interests – Transfers of interests by either Member are permitted subject to (A) such transfers not being made to_
prohibited persons or in a manner which would violate applicable laws, and (B) delivery to the other member of the executed
instrument of transfer and an express assumption of the obligations of the transferring member (which for a transfer by Realty
Income Member requires delivery to Investor Member of an express assumption of the obligations under the Tax Protection
Agreement (as defined below)).

_Right of First Offer – Investor Member is entitled to a right of first offer on the sale of Realty Income Member’s interest in_
Obsidian or a sale of Obsidian if the same occurs prior to the earlier of May 16, 2035 or a Buyout Trigger Event (a “Buyout
Trigger Event” means the earliest to occur of the following: (i) any of the events set forth in clauses (i), (ii) or (iv) of the
definition of “Tax Protection Period,” as described below, and (ii) the event set forth in clause (iii) of such definition occurs
with respect to all of the EG Contributed Properties).


-----

_Drag Right – Subject to Investor Member’s right of first offer, in the event the Realty Income Member approves a sale of_
Obsidian, the Realty Income Member has the ability to cause the Investor Member to sell its interest in Obsidian in connection
with such sale of Obsidian.

_Put/Call Rights –_

  - At any time during the period commencing on the date of a sale or other disposition in which all or any portion of
Investor Member’s built-in gain with respect to the properties contributed (or deemed contributed) to Obsidian by
Investor Member (the “EG Contributed Properties”) is recognized for U.S. federal income tax purposes and ending
on the date that is 60 days after the earlier of (i) the date that managing member notifies Investor Member in writing
that such sale or other disposition has occurred or (ii) the date on which Investor Member otherwise becomes aware
of such sale or other disposition, Investor Member shall have the right, but not the obligation, to require Realty Income
Member to purchase (either itself or through one or more designees) from Investor Member all (but not less than all)
of Investor Member’s interest in Obsidian, free and clear of all liens, for a purchase price equal to the fair market value
of such interest.

  - At any time from and after the earlier to occur of (i) May 16, 2043, or (ii) a Buyout Trigger Event, Realty Income
Member shall have the right, but not the obligation, to require Investor Member to sell to Realty Income Member all
(but not less than all) of Investor Member’s interest in Obsidian, free and clear of all liens, for a purchase price equal
to the fair market value of such interest.

_Tax Protection Agreement –_

  - In connection with the contribution (or deemed contribution) of the EG Contributed Properties, Obsidian, Investor
Member, and Realty Income Corporation (“RI”) entered into a customary tax protection agreement (the “Tax
Protection Agreement”) pursuant to which, among other things, Obsidian and RI agreed to indemnify Investor
Member in the event that certain transactions cause Investor Member to recognize all or a portion of certain gain
deferred by Investor Member in connection with such contributions.

  - In general, the indemnification under the Tax Protection Agreement is triggered by Obsidian’s sale or other taxable
disposition of the EG Contributed Properties, certain transactions causing a taxable disposition of Investor Member’s
interest in Obsidian, or Obsidian’s failure to maintain and permit Investor Member to guarantee certain indebtedness,
in each case generally during the Tax Protection Period (as defined below).

“Tax Protection Period” means the period commencing on the May 15, 2023 and expiring on the date that is the earliest of (i)
May 15, 2030, (ii) the date of a final determination under the internal revenue code that no portion of the contribution of the
EG Contributed Properties qualified for tax-deferred treatment, (iii) the date on which Obsidian terminates any Master Lease
due to the default thereunder by an affiliate of the Investor Member, (iv) the date on which the affiliate of the Investor Member
ceases to be the tenant under such Master Lease and neither of the Master Lease Guarantors (or any of their creditworthy wholly
owned subsidiaries) is a guarantor under such Master Lease guarantee, (v) the date on which the Investor Member has
transferred to a party unrelated to Investor Member more than 50% of the original ownership interests in the Obsidian (for the
avoidance of doubt, not taking into account any dilution from the issuance of new equity interests in Obsidian or any redemption
of Investor Member’s interests by Obsidian or any indirect transfers), or (vi) upon filing for bankruptcy by the Investor Member
or any of its relevant affiliates; provided that with respect to the events in clause (iv), the Tax Protection Period shall terminate
only with respect to the applicable properties (and not other EG Contributed Properties).

_Phase I and Phase II Loans and Guaranties –_

Obsidian is an obligor under two loans made by RI, the first in the amount of $585,483,963.43 (“Phase I Loan”) and the second
in the amount of $589,468,725.59 (“Phase II Loan”; and together with the Phase I Loan, the “Loans”), each of which accrues
interest at the rate of 6.87% per annum and matures on May 16, 2030. Interest on each of the Loans is payable on the first day
of each month in arrears. Each of the Loans is prepayable at any time without premium or penalty. Obsidian, pursuant to the
terms of each Loan, is prohibited from making distributions to its equity holders that would cause the outstanding balance of
either Loan to exceed 60% of Obsidian’s assets (net of any debts which are senior or pari passu to the applicable Loan). The
payment obligations under each of the Loans are guaranteed, jointly and severally, by the Investor Member, the Parent and EG
America, LLC.
