**Senior Credit Facilities Amend and Extend**

In the second quarter of 2023, we launched an amend and extend of our Senior Credit Facilities (the “Amend and Extend”),
concurrently with the announcement of a significant deleveraging program.

The Amend and Extend addressed our upcoming $6.1 billion senior secured term loan maturities through an extension of the
maturity date to February 2028. Consenting lenders agreed to (i) extend $3.2 billion of multi-currency senior secured term
loans through a combination of the redesignation of existing facilities to new facilities with the extended maturity and newmoney commitments (the “Extended Senior Secured Term Loan Facilities”), (ii) certain amendments which took effect once
the Consent Letters were countersigned, and (iii) other amendments which will take effect following the occurrence of the
Condition Satisfaction Date (the “Conditional Amendments”). Following the occurrence of the Condition Satisfaction Date,
upon which certain consents received in the Amend and Extend and not already in effect will become operative and following
the designated term loan repayments from the Pre-Offering Transactions, we expect that approximately $300 million in
aggregate principal amount of existing term loans carrying a 2025 and 2026 maturity will remain outstanding. As part of the
Amend and Extend, we also secured an extension to the maturity date of the majority of our existing Revolving Credit Facilities
and Letter of Credit Facilities to August 31, 2027. The remaining portion of our existing senior secured term loans will be
repaid in full with proceeds from the UK Disposal to Asda, the U.S. Sale and Leaseback and/or the Non-Core Minit Mart
Disposal (Missouri and Kansas). In connection with the Amend and Extend and the utilization of Tranche D Term Facilities,
we will pay certain fees, OID, costs and expenses totaling $170 million.

The Amend and Extend successfully allocated on June 30, 2023 and the Extended Senior Secured Term Loan Facilities and
Conditional Amendments will be become operative upon the occurrence of the Conditions Satisfaction Date following the
closing of the UK Disposal to Asda. If the Conditions Satisfaction Date does not occur by December 31, 2023, none of the
maturity extensions secured in the Amend and Extend nor any of the Conditional Amendments will be implemented and certain
of the redesignation of existing facilities to new facilities to facilitate the extended maturity and new-money commitments of
the Extended Senior Secured Term Loan Facilities will be unwound. For a further description of the Amend and Extend and
our revised Senior Credit Facilities, Revolving Credit Facilities and Letter of Credit Facilities, see “Description of Certain
_Financing Arrangements— Senior Credit Facilities Agreement.”_

**The UK Disposal to Asda**

**_The UK Disposal to Asda_**

On May 30, 2023, we announced our binding agreement to sell a substantial majority of our Fuel, Foodservice and Grocery
and Merchandise business in the United Kingdom to Asda, for an initial consideration of £2.27 billion, subject to various
adjustments and agreement upon a precise transaction perimeter. Following discussions between Asda and the Group on the
perimeter of the UK Disposal to Asda and discussions with the relevant brand partners, Asda and the Group agreed that the
Starbucks Business and KFC Business in the United Kingdom and Ireland, together with their employees, would not transfer
to Asda as part of the UK Disposal to Asda and would, therefore, form part of the Retained UK&I Business immediately
following Completion. As a result of these discussions, the UK Disposal to Asda was completed on October 31, 2023 for total
cash consideration of £2 billion ($2.5 billion).

The UK Disposal to Asda is a transformational step for us. The proceeds from the UK Disposal to Asda, along with the proceeds
from the U.S. Sale and Leaseback and the Non-Core Minit Mart Disposal (Missouri and Kansas), will be used to repay certain
of our term loan facilities and Existing Notes, as described in _“Summary—Recent Developments—Senior Credit Facilities_
_Amend and Extend” and to redeem a portion of our Existing Notes. See “Capitalization”._

The UK Disposal to Asda, along with the U.S. Sale and Leaseback, is the cornerstone of our strategy to reduce total net leverage,
extend our financing maturities and reposition our capital structure for future business growth and financial resilience.
Following the UK Disposal to Asda, we will continue to operate and maximize long-term growth opportunities in the United
States, Australia, Germany, France, Italy, the Netherlands, Luxembourg and Belgium, and will continue to consider our
strategic options in the Retained UK&I Business.

The perimeter and financial metrics of the Disposed UK Business are not identical to our business division in the United
Kingdom and Ireland. As presented in our historical financial accounts and in this Offering Memorandum, our United Kingdom
and Ireland business division’s results of operations and KPIs include the Retained UK&I Business and do not reflect any
deduction for shared service center costs attributable to such operations. However, when adjusting our consolidated financial
KPIs for the Pre-Offering Transactions or the Transactions in this Offering Memorandum, including for the purposes of
calculating Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA, we have specifically removed amounts attributable to the Disposed UK Business,
as well as for the Non-Core Asset Disposals, and have given pro forma effect to the U.S. Sale and Leaseback.


-----

Following the UK Disposal to Asda, we will continue to operate our Retained UK&I Business, which will consist of (i) the
electric vehicle charging business, ‘evpoint’; (ii) non-transferring head office staff; (iii) certain brands and intellectual property
(including ‘EG’, ‘Euro Garages’, ‘Vapexchange’ and ‘Hyperform’); (iv) the Cooplands business; (v) the franchise businesses
carried on under the Starbucks brand and the KFC brand; (vi) the franchise businesses carried on under the Chaiiwala brand
and the Cinnabon brand; (vii) the Euro Grocer business; (viii) 31 operational petrol filling stations and a cluster of Foodservice
outlets in the United Kingdom that were not sold as part of the UK Disposal to Asda; (ix) two additional petrol filing stations
in the United Kingdom that were acquired subsequent to our agreement with Asda relating to the UK Disposal to Asda; and
(x) undeveloped land bank assets. Subject to the performance by the parties of certain customary closing obligations, the
transaction was completed on October 31, 2023. For a description of the key terms of the UK Disposal to Asda, see “—Sale
_and Purchase Agreement” and see “Recent Developments” for a description of the other strategic disposals currently under_
consideration in relation to the Retained UK&I Business.

**_Sale and Purchase Agreement_**

The UK Disposal to Asda was structured as the sale of the entire issued share capital of Euro Garages (Jersey) Limited (the
“Target”, and together with the Target’s subsidiaries, the “Target Group”) to Asda. The asset base of the Target Group consists
of 356 PFS and Grocery & Merchandise sites and 444 Foodservice outlets, including the LEON brand and all relevant
employees who devote more than half their time to the transferring business. EG Group retained its businesses in the United
States, Europe (other than the Disposed UK Business) and Australia, and the following, which were carved out from the Target
Group: (i) our electric vehicle charging business, ‘evpoint’; (ii) non-transferring head office staff; (iii) certain brands and
intellectual property (including ‘EG’, ‘Euro Garages’, ‘Vapexchange’ and ‘Hyperform’); (iv) the Cooplands business; (v) the
franchise businesses carried on under the Starbucks brand and the KFC brand; (vi) the franchise business carried on under the
Chaiiwala brand and the Cinnabon brand; (vii) the Euro Grocer business; (viii) 31 operational petrol filling stations and a cluster
of Foodservice outlets in the United Kingdom; and (ix) undeveloped land bank assets.

The UK Disposal to Asda was documented by way of a sale and purchase agreement between EG Finco Limited (the “Seller”),
Project America Bidco Limited (the “Purchaser”) and Bellis Acquisition Company 3 Limited (as guarantor for the Purchaser)
(as such agreement may be supplemented or amended from time to time, the “Sale and Purchase Agreement”). The Seller and
the Purchaser (or their affiliated companies) also entered into certain ancillary agreements on completion of the UK Disposal
to Asda (“Completion” and the date of Completion, the “Completion Date”) (and are expected to enter into certain other
ancillary agreements following Completion) in each case in relation to certain transitional services, integration and branding
arrangements, certain property matters and the EV charging business, the key terms of which are described further in “—
_Ancillary Agreements”._

The Sale and Purchase Agreement provided that, in the period prior to Completion, the Seller and the Purchaser would agree
to the terms of a carve-out transaction such that the Seller (and certain members of the Group) would (together) retain the
Retained UK&I Business that was formerly held by the Target Group. Under the Sale and Purchase Agreement, the purchase
price, which was paid in cash on Completion, was £2 billion (following the application of estimated net debt and working
capital adjustments). Following Completion, the parties will agree on any post-completion adjustments to account for any
differences between, respectively, a target net working capital position and an estimate of the net debt position of the Target
Group and the actual net working capital position and actual net debt position of the Target Group on the Completion Date.
Following the post-completion adjustments referred to above, the parties do not anticipate this process to result in any material
adjustments.

The Seller provided customary fundamental warranties, business warranties and indemnities (including a tax covenant) under
the Sale and Purchase Agreement. The Purchaser has purchased W&I insurance for the UK Disposal to Asda to provide
insurance recourse in the event of a breach of the majority of the business warranties or claims under the tax covenant. For
matters not covered by W&I insurance (including certain business warranties not covered by the W&I insurance and
indemnities), the Purchaser may seek direct recourse to the Seller. The Seller’s liability for a breach of business warranties is
capped at 10% of consideration. All claims under the Sale and Purchase Agreement are subject to (with certain exceptions)
customary contractual time and other limitations and an aggregate cap of the consideration.

The Sale and Purchase Agreement provides that any dispute arising out of the Sale and Purchase Agreement shall be referred
to the London Court of Arbitration.

**_Ancillary Agreements_**

On the Completion Date, we entered into a transitional services agreement with the Target Group pursuant to which we agreed
to continue to provide access to all centralized shared services (such as IT, HR, accounting, payroll, compliance and tax
functions), that were, in the 12 months prior to Completion, provided to the Target Group by us (“Centralized Services”), for


-----

a transitional period (the “TSA”). The initial term of the TSA is expected to be a period of up to two years from the Completion
Date, subject to certain rights for the Target Group to terminate, or transition away from, services early or to extend the initial
term for an aggregate period of up to a further 12 months (in 3 months increments). During the term of the TSA, we will also
provide certain of the IT services that will continue to be provided to the Target Group to Asda, for the benefit of certain other
convenience retail sites that Asda and its affiliates own from time to time, including those branded as ‘ASDA Express’. The
services provided by us to the Target Group will be deemed to be subject to a service credit for the first two years of the TSA,
as a result of which the Target Group will not be required to make any payment to us for the services (subject to certain limited
exceptions) and thereafter will be provided for a fee based on the actual cost to us of providing the services, plus an agreed
margin that will be applied to any non-third party costs. The services provided to members of the Asda group in respect of
convenience retail sites that are not part of the Disposed UK Business will be provided for a fee payable to us based on the
actual cost to us of providing the services, plus an agreed margin that will be applied to non-third party costs. Our liability for
provision of the services will be subject to limitations customary for an agreement of this nature, including an annual financial
cap on our liability of £12.2 million for most liabilities. In connection with such transitional arrangements, and as further
consideration for the UK Disposal to Asda, we have agreed that, for a period of 2 years from Completion, we will cover the
costs incurred by the Purchaser associated with the provision of Centralized Services to the Disposed UK Business, to the
extent that such services are not provided by us pursuant to the TSA; this will include our reimbursing the Purchaser for any
third party costs incurred by the Purchaser in procuring Centralized Services for the Disposed UK Business and the employment
costs (including certain redundancy costs) of any employees of the Disposed UK Business or the Purchaser who are, after
Completion, performing roles related to Centralized Services. The Seller has also agreed that it will, during the first two years
following Completion, provide quarterly contributions of £1.4125 million and £11.3 million in aggregate) to the Purchaser by
way of a contribution towards the costs that the Purchaser is expected to incur in integrating the employees of the Disposed
UK Business into the Asda group. EG Finco limited has provided certain guarantees in favor of entities transferred to Asda as
part of the UK Disposal to Asda, or the Purchaser, in respect of the obligations of the Group under: (i) the TSA; and (ii) certain
business sale agreements entered into by certain transferred entities and members of the Group in connection with
reorganizations effected prior to completion of the UK Disposal to Asda.

After the Completion Date, an affiliate of the Seller has agreed to grant a transitional sublease of part of the head office building
located at Waterside, Blackburn that is currently occupied by employees of the Disposed UK Business, Retained UK&I
Business and the Group’s non-UK businesses, to the Purchaser for occupation by certain employees of the Disposed UK
Business for a period of two years from Completion for a peppercorn rent. See “Certain relationships and Related Party
_Transactions—Transactions with Related Parties—Transactions with Asda relating to the UK Disposal to Asda.”_

On the Completion Date, the Seller and the Target also entered into a transitional brand license agreement which took effect
immediately following Completion (the “Brand Licence Agreement”). Pursuant to the Brand Licence Agreement, we granted
the Target Group a non-exclusive right to use certain of our brands, including the ‘EG’ and ‘Euro Garages’ brands, for a period
of three years, royalty free, to allow the Target Group to rebrand its sites and businesses (subject to earlier termination rights).
The Target will have a right to extend the term of the brand license for a further two years if it has not completed this debranding
process by the end of the expiry of the initial three-year term, subject to the parties agreeing a royalty fee for the use of such
brands during such extension. As the LEON brand forms part of the Target Group, the Purchaser, the Seller and certain members
of the Target Group that operate the LEON business entered into a side letter at Completion (the “LEON Side Letter”) under
which the Purchaser and such members of the Target Group agreed to act reasonably and in good faith in considering a request
from the Seller to enter into a franchise agreement for the operation of a foodservice outlet under the LEON brand outside the
United Kingdom and Republic of Ireland and the Seller has certain rights to make an offer to purchase the LEON brands or
business in the event of a future disposal of such brands or business (that is not part of a wider transaction involving the Asda
group or Target Group). The LEON Side Letter will remain in place for a period of 10 years subject to certain earlier termination
rights and events.

On May 30, 2023, the Seller, the Purchaser and Asda Stores Limited entered into a side letter in connection with the EV charger
business, which is part of the Retained UK&I Business (the “EVPoint Side Letter”). Under the EVPoint Side Letter the Seller,
the Purchaser and Asda have documented their intention that EV Point Services Limited (a member of the Group) or an affiliate
will be appointed as sole provider, operator and installer of electric vehicle charging points at Asda sites (including the sites
held by the Target Group) and have agreed to use reasonable endeavors to agree the terms and conditions of such appointment
including the terms of a framework agreement under which that appointment will be documented following Completion. The
EVPoint Side Letter will (in addition to certain earlier termination rights and events) terminate if the framework agreement has
not been entered into by the date falling 24 months from Completion.

Following the Completion Date the Seller and the Purchaser will agree the terms on which we will, in respect of the Retained
UK&I Business, occupy sites that remain owned by the Target Group, or the Target Group will, in respect of the Disposed UK
Business, occupy sites that, following completion of the carve-out transaction described above, were transferred to the


-----

ownership of the Group, including sites where the operations of the Retained UK&I Business and Disposed UK Business are
co-located. This will include rights of occupation in respect of sites on which EV charging points, including ‘evpoint’-branded
chargers, have, prior to Completion, been installed by us.

**Overview**

We are a leading independent global convenience retailer that served over 1.1 billion customers worldwide in the year ended
December 31, 2022 (over 3 million customers per day). We have a diversified portfolio of sites across three continents, which
consists of 5,937 sites after giving effect to the Transactions. Based on our site count (after giving effect to the Transactions),
we are the third largest independent convenience retailer chain globally, the fifth largest in the United States and the second
largest in Continental Europe and Australia.

Our total fuel volumes sold was 17.7 billion liters for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023 (16.1 billion liters after giving
effect to the Transactions). Our global operations span six of the ten largest fuel markets in Europe by fuel volumes sold,
namely Belgium, France, Germany, Italy, the Netherlands and the United Kingdom, all six states in Australia and 30 states
across the United States. Our Fuel operations are complemented by our Grocery & Merchandise and Foodservice operations,
under which we offer our proprietary brands as well as partner with attractive third-party brands. We seek to deliver a modern
and convenient customer retail experience by providing a “one-stop shop” retail destination that offers a broad range of products
and services to address evolving customer needs, which increasingly revolve around conveniently located stores offering onestop solutions. For the twelve months ended June 30, 2023, we generated revenue of $26.2 billion, gross profit of $3.8 billion
and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA before IFRS 16 of $1,147 million, in each case after giving effect to the Pre-Offering
Transactions.

_Gross Profit and Gross Margin_

Gross profit is calculated as revenue minus cost of sales. Gross profit is a key measure used by management to assess our
business volumes and the profitability of our sales revenue after deduction of direct costs and free of the impact of varying
levels of wholesale fuel pricing. We monitor gross profit, and other indicators derived from gross profit, because they measure
our profitability per U.S. dollar of revenue in a comparable way across periods and in relation to other companies in our
industry. We believe revenue is not a KPI for the business due to the variability across periods arising from the distorting
impact of volatile wholesale fuel pricing on reported fuel revenues.

We monitor other indicators derived from gross profit, such as gross margin to assess profitability in our categories of
operations. In our Grocery & Merchandise and Foodservice business streams, we calculate gross margin as gross profit divided
by total revenue. Fuel gross margin, or Fuel cost per liter, is a key measure used by management and is calculated as Fuel gross
profit divided by Fuel volumes.

_Adjusted EBITDA before IFRS 16 and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA before IFRS 16_

Adjusted EBITDA before IFRS 16 is a key measure used by management to evaluate our underlying operating performance,
review business trends, identify strategies to improve results and make day-to-day operating decisions. We believe this measure
allows a comparison of our results across periods and across companies in the industry in which we operate on a consistent
basis, by removing the effects on our operating performance of our capital structure (such as the varying levels of interest
expense), asset base and capital investment cycle (such as depreciation and amortization), items largely outside our control
(such as income taxes), and exceptional items that we view as not reflective of our underlying operating performance and which
we are permitted to adjust for in calculating covenant compliance under the terms of our financing agreements.

We define Adjusted EBITDA before IFRS 16 as profit/(loss) for the period before net finance costs, tax, depreciation of tangible
fixed assets, depreciation of right of use assets, amortization, impairment and profit on disposal, and excluding exceptional
items relating to certain non-recurring costs and non-cash items, and estimated lease costs under IFRS 16 deducted.

We adjust for certain exceptional items to calculate Adjusted EBITDA before IFRS 16 due to their size and nature in order aid
comparability. Therefore, in order to allow an understanding of our underlying trading performance, items recognized in
reported profit or loss before tax which, by virtue of their size and/or nature, do not reflect our underlying performance, are
shown as exceptional items. Exceptional items are those which are separately identified by virtue of their size or incidence and
include, but are not limited to, acquisition costs, impairment charges, reorganization costs, profits and losses on disposal of
subsidiaries, and other one-off items which meet this definition. All items are shown gross, unless IFRS permits netting of such
expenditure and tax on exceptional items has been calculated using the applicable statutory tax rate for taxable items.

In addition to the EBITDA from each of our regional businesses, Adjusted EBITDA before IFRS 16 also includes certain
shared service center costs.

Pro forma Adjusted EBITDA before IFRS 16 – represents our Adjusted EBITDA before IFRS 16 adjusted for estimated
equivalent results of acquired businesses in the pre-acquisition period and other EBITDA annualizations, and the estimated
synergies from acquisitions which have been determined as part of the investment appraisal which have yet to be recognized.
For the twelve months ended June 30, 2023, Pro forma Adjusted EBITDA before IFRS 16 represents Adjusted EBITDA before
IFRS 16 adjusted to include (i) the estimated EBITDA from acquisitions, group initiatives and synergies and other EBITDA
annualizations, (ii) run rate adjustment relating to the Non-Core Asset Disposals, (iii) the EBITDA impact of the UK Disposal
to Asda and (iv) annualized rent expenses from the U.S. Sale and Leaseback. We use Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA before
IFRS 16 to evaluate our leverage ratio and our ability to incur and service our indebtedness.

_Capital expenditures_

Capital expenditures represents our purchase of property, plant and equipment and intangibles for the periods presented, which,
for budgeting and tracking purposes, we categorize as maintenance capital expenditure and growth capital expenditure. We
define maintenance capital expenditure as capital expenditure required to maintain the performance of our network. We define
growth capital expenditure as consisting of (i) Capital Expenditure on Acquired Sites, defined as capital expenditure on the
integration of newly acquired sites into our existing brands and formats, including with respect to rebranding our acquired sites,
(ii) Capital Expenditure on New Sites, defined as capital expenditure on new sites, such as new-to-industry sites and new
highway PFS sites, including with respect to rolling out non-fuel offerings at these sites and (iii) Capital Expenditure on
Existing Sites, defined as capital expenditure on existing sites, including the refurbishment of existing sites, including
extensions, minor refits of our existing PFS sites, the change in the operating model of some of our existing sites and the


-----

rebranding of our existing sites. See “—Capital expenditures” for a further breakdown of our capital expenditures by
maintenance capital expenditure and growth capital expenditure and region.

_Adjusted cash conversion ratio_

Adjusted cash conversion ratio represents adjusted free cash flow divided by Adjusted EBITDA before IFRS 16. We define
Adjusted free cash flow as Adjusted EBITDA before IFRS 16 plus or minus changes in net working capital minus maintenance
capital expenditures. Adjusted free cash flow is a non-IFRS measure of liquidity, which we present because we believe that it
is widely used by certain investors, securities analysts and other interested parties as a measure of our efficiency at generating
cash. The following table provides a reconciliation of Adjusted free cash flow to Adjusted EBITDA before IFRS 16 for the

Following the Transactions, we expect our adjusted free cash flow to be impacted by our interest expenses, cash taxes and the

free cash flow generation as part of our revised financial policy and so we assess our discretionary growth capital requirements

**Key Factors Affecting Results of Operations and Financial Condition**

**_Our Business Model and Business Streams_**

Our fuel operations are complemented by our Grocery & Merchandise and Foodservice business streams, under which we offer
both our proprietary brands as well as partner with third-party brands. We seek to deliver a modern and convenient customer
retail experience by providing a “one-stop shop” retail destination that offers a broad range of products and services to address
evolving customer needs. We believe our diversified product mix can create a ‘halo effect’ through which we can generate
additional profitability from increased customer footfall and sales volumes. Our non-fuel business has become a cornerstone
of our long-term diversification strategy as we seek a more diversified earnings base. In addition, we continue to invest in being
the convenience destination of choice for our customers including by installing electrical vehicle charging points in our site
network to meet evolving customer demand.

Compared to Fuel products, our Grocery & Merchandise and Foodservice businesses are less exposed to fluctuations in the
price of a single commodity. Based on our relationships and agreements with our partners, we also have a range of flexibility
(with greater flexibility for non-branded Foodservice offerings) to control the selling prices of our products, including managing
inventory, selecting promotional offers and designing in-store layouts, each to maximize margins and enhance customer
experiences. In addition to our primary Fuel, Grocery & Merchandise and Foodservice activities, we also offer certain other
ancillary services such as car washes, lottery ticket sales and ATMs.

_Grocery & Merchandise_

Grocery & Merchandise continues to be the most stable of our business streams, both in terms of sales volume, which has
steadily grown, and gross margin, which has largely remained stable over time. We have cultivated strong relationships with
well-known retail and grocery brands such as SPAR, Rewe and Carrefour, in addition to operating our own proprietary brands,
including the Cumberland Farms’ Farmhouse Kitchen brand in the United States, which supports our convenience offering to
consumers. We also participate in rebate agreements with our Grocery & Merchandise partners whereby we receive rebates
from the supplier upon reaching specified sales volumes. As our scale has increased over time, we are able to build upon our
size to increase the level of rebate as a percentage of sales from our Grocery & Merchandise partners, allowing us to increase
our gross profit for Grocery & Merchandise. We continue to focus on further enhancement to our Grocery & Merchandise
offering, particularly in Continental Europe where our lower penetration of this market presents an opportunity for future
growth and development. We also regularly review our brand portfolio and evaluate opportunities to partner with other leading
convenience retail businesses and expand our ancillary service to further enhance our offer.

Our financial results are affected by changes in consumer preferences and perceptions, demographic trends over time and our
ability to anticipate, identify and respond to such changes and trends is key. For example, in 2022, our Grocery & Merchandise
operations were negatively impacted by changes in consumer buying behavior, due to the inflationary pressures and cost-ofliving increases seen in most regions. Margins remained consistent from 2021 to 2022, and into the first half of 2023, despite
some unavoidable underlying product cost pressures. We believe this is not only reflective of our disciplined approach to
purchasing and pricing but also of the resilience of convenience retail against the backdrop of rising prices.

_Foodservice_

We believe our strategic focus and growth in Foodservice has provided a strong platform of choice for customers, across our
multiple brand partnerships and proprietary brands. Our Foodservice brand partners include globally recognized brands such
as Starbucks, Burger King, Subway and KFC, as well as strong local brands such as Pomme de Pain and Greggs. We believe
these well-known brands increase customer confidence in our products and services and lead to increased footfall and sales
volumes. We complement our existing portfolio of partner brands through our proprietary Foodservice brands, such as
Cooplands, providing further product diversification for the Group. Our strong mix of proprietary and third party brands is part
of our effort to focus on our Foodservice offering as a means of increasing revenue and profitability across our forecourt
network.


-----

We have established a scaled, global footprint across the Foodservice market, driven by our strong international brand
partnerships and strategic acquisitions. Expansion of our Foodservice operations has transformed our sites into destinations
serving multiple customer needs, which supports our increased customer traffic and sales volumes. In 2022, inflationary
pressures on wholesale food cost prices and a lag in passing these through retail prices adversely impacted the performance of
our Foodservice operations in the second half of the year, although we saw improved operating performance in this stream in
the six month period to June 30, 2023.

_Fuel Operations_

We have Fuel retail operations in ten countries, including in six of the ten largest fuel markets in Europe, the United States and
Australia. We have continued to focus on the growth and quality of our network through the development of NTIs, knock‑downrebuilds, upgrades and conversions to our COCO model, as well as the acquisitions of businesses on a strategic basis. We
believe our wholesale supply agreements with well-known brands, such as Esso and BP, increase customer confidence in our
products and services, leading to higher customer traffic, and support our premium positioning on Fuel. We also operate a
wholesale supply business, EG Fuel, that focuses on the strategic and operational fuel supply and distribution in Continental
Europe.

Fuel revenue can fluctuate from period to period, mainly as a result of changes in wholesale fuel prices. For example, at the
onset of the COVID-19 pandemic, oil and fuel prices fell significantly but as the economy recovered from the pandemic, prices
began to increase over time. Market volatility caused by ongoing geopolitical events following the conflict in Ukraine impacted
wholesale oil prices and demand again in 2022. During the first half of 2023, international fuel prices have largely returned to
the level prior to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.

All regions except Continental Europe noted a slight decrease in volumes in 2022 due to the impact of higher than average fuel
retail prices and cautious consumer spending, with 17.6 billion liters sold in 2022 compared to 17.7 billion liters in 2021. We
sold 8.5 billion of liters of fuel in the six months ended June 30, 2023 across all regions, compared to 8.4 billion liters of fuel
sold in the six months ended June 30, 2022, with the 2022 OMV Acquisition in Germany supporting growth in fuel volumes
in Continental Europe as compared to the six months ended June 30, 2022. In the year ended December 31, 2022, Fuel margins
strengthened slightly against a backdrop of rising inflation and continued volatile macroeconomic environment in the oil
industry, including price sensitive consumers switching to lower priced competitors in certain markets, covering the increased
cost of business delivery. In the six months ended June 30, 2023, Fuel margins decreased slightly, against the backdrop of the
higher than usual margins seen throughout 2022, and as a result of adverse stock revaluations in our EG Fuel business.

At our company-owned sites, we employ a dynamic pricing strategy through specialized software, which we have improved
with our own algorithms based on the data we collect from our network of sites. In the regular course of our business, we enter
into relationships with fuel suppliers whereby we commit to purchase certain minimum quantities of fuel in order to benefit
from better pricing conditions. However, since fuel products are commodities, we have no control over the changing market
value of our inventories. As our inventory is valued at the lower of weighted average cost and net realizable value (which is
based on market price), under our inventory valuation methodology, price fluctuations impact both cost of sales and the value
of the inventory reported in our financial statements. In addition, if the book value of our inventory is above its net realizable
value on a certain balance sheet date, we are required to write down the inventory to net realizable value. Due to the pricing
arrangements under our fuel supply agreements and the high turnover levels of inventory held, the measurement of the value
of our inventory is based on the cost price of the inventory at our PFS sites.

_Electric Vehicle Charging Stations_

To meet evolving customer demands, we are in the process of rolling out EV charging stations across our network, with a focus
on the European market. As of June 30, 2023, we operated 635 electric charging points (compared to 470 as of December 31,
2022) across 189 sites in the United Kingdom and Continental Europe. We have earmarked a broader rollout of EV chargers
across hundreds of our sites through to 2026. All the EV charging points in the United Kingdom will form part of our Retained
UK&I Business. We plan to continue our rollout of EV chargers during the remainder of 2023, with a further 60 electric
charging points operating by the end of the year, a majority of which will be ultra-fast chargers. See “Business—Our Additional
_Operations—Electric Vehicle Charging Stations and Alternative Fuels—Electric Vehicle Charging Stations”._

**_Our Site Operating Models_**

We have a mix of COCO, CONCO and ‘other’ operating models, such as retailer or dealer-owned and operated sites, and these
different models result in different levels of revenue generation and costs and require different levels of capital expenditure.
We believe the COCO model provides us with greater control over our pricing policy, cost control and consistency in product
and service offerings across sites, having historically delivered higher profitability relative to sites operated under our other


-----

operating models. We therefore are consistently working towards extending the company-operated model to additional sites
and converting suitable non-company-operated sites into COCO sites. COCO conversions require some capital expenditure,
and we typically wait until the expiration of our franchise, dealership or retail agreements, as applicable, so as to not trigger
early termination fees before implementing a COCO conversion for suitable sites. In the year ended December 31, 2022 and
the six months ended June 30, 2023, we converted 53 sites and 20 sites, respectively, to our preferred COCO operating model.

We plan to continue this strategy of COCO conversions on a site specific basis where it makes economic sense, in particular
in certain European markets such as Italy and Germany. Our operating models are summarized as follows:

  - **COCO (company-owned, company-operated). COCO operations are directly managed by us and we are responsible**
for all aspects of the performance and maintenance of the site. Under the COCO model, our revenue reflects the
income received from sales of our Fuel, Grocery & Merchandise and Foodservice products and services and our cost
of goods sold reflects the cost of our Fuel, Grocery & Merchandise and Foodservice products and ancillary services.
When sales volumes and unit margins are high, our COCO sites present a greater opportunity for increased gross profit
and EBITDA than sites operating under our other operating models because we largely control prices on Fuel, Grocery
& Merchandise and Foodservice sales. However, the COCO model exposes us to a greater risk of declines in revenue
and increases in costs and to volatility in market demand. In addition, we also bear considerable operating and capital
costs in connection with COCO sites, which impacts our operating profit. As of June 30, 2023, we operated 4,314
sites under the COCO model, and approximately 34%, 100%, 96% and 100% of our sites in Continental Europe, the
United Kingdom and Ireland, the United States, and Australia, respectively, were COCO sites. All of the sites that
will be sold in connection with the UK Disposal to Asda are operated under the COCO model.

  - **CONCO (company-owned, not company-operated).** Under the CONCO model, the dealer, franchisee or retailer is
responsible for all non-fuel operations, as well as operating costs associated with the management of the site, whereas
we are responsible for any capital and maintenance costs associated with the fuel equipment and, in some instances,
we have a consignment arrangement for fuel sales and inventory. Under a consignment arrangement, fuel revenue
from the site reflects the income received from the sale of fuel products to the end customer. A commission on fuel
sales is payable by the Group to the dealer. In a number of our dealer operated sites, we receive a commission on
Grocery & Merchandise products sold by the dealer to the end customer. Fuel revenue from retailer operated sites
reflects the income received from the sale of fuel products to the end customer. A commission on fuel sales is also
payable by us to the retailer. The retailer also pays a rent to the Group, which we record as other income. As of June
30, 2023, we operated 1,474 sites under the CONCO model, and approximately 43%, 0%, 4% and 0% of our sites in
Continental Europe, the United Kingdom and Ireland, the United States, and Australia, respectively, were CONCO
sites. None of our CONCO sites will be sold in connection with the UK Disposal to Asda.

  - **‘Other’ Sites (retailer or dealer-owned and operated). ‘Other’ sites are owned and operated by a third party who**
has full responsibility for the performance and maintenance of the site. All fuel and non-fuel sales, operating costs and
capital expenditures are incurred by the dealer or retailer, unless we agree to pay certain maintenance expenses on the
assets or property we own. We either have a fuel supply arrangement in place with the third party, or, alternatively,
the fuel supply is on a consignment basis. Under a consignment arrangement, fuel prices may be set by us, and the
fuel revenue from ‘other’ sites reflects the income received from the sale of fuel products to the dealer or retailer. A
commission on fuel sales is payable by us to the dealer or retailer. Under a non-consignment arrangement, fuel revenue
from such site reflects the income received from the sales of fuel products to the dealer or retailer at a price set by the
dealer, retailer or operator and established in an agreement. In certain of our dealer owned sites, we receive a
commission on convenience retail products sold by the dealer to the end customer. The costs associated with
transportation of fuel to the sites are borne by us and included in our distribution costs. As of June 30, 2023, we
operated 744 sites under the ‘other’ sites model, all of which are in Continental Europe, primarily in Germany, Italy
and Benelux, with approximately 23% of our sites in Continental Europe operated under ‘other’ site models. None of
our ‘other’ sites will be sold in connection with the UK Disposal to Asda.

**_Geographic Mix_**

The geographic scope of our business has expanded significantly since our inception and our financial results are affected by
our mix of total revenue from sales generated across geographic areas. Our range of fuel and non-fuel products have varying
margins in the different geographic regions in which we operate and, therefore, our geographic mix impacts our results of
operation. However, geographical diversification also provides us with a degree of natural hedging against certain external
factors, such as variations in weather, localized economic downturns and other localized events that may have a temporary or
sustained impact on our operations.


-----

For the years ended December 31, 2021 and 2022 and the six months ended June 30, 2023, we reported our results of operations
in four key geographical areas – Continental Europe, United Kingdom & Ireland, United States and Australia. Following the
UK Disposal to Asda, our business will be composed of three key geographical areas of operations – Europe (in which we will
report the Retained UK&I Business), the United States and Australia. Our key geographic areas are described in more detail
below.

**_Foreign Currency Exchange Rates_**

Our results of operations are subject to foreign currency translation and transaction effects because we have operations in
Australia, Belgium, France, Germany, Italy, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, the United Kingdom and Ireland and the United
States, which are, and will continue to be, conducted primarily in the respective local currency. As we present our consolidated
financial statements in U.S. dollars, we must translate the assets, liabilities, revenue and expenses of all of our operations with
a functional currency other than the U.S. dollar into U.S. dollars at the closing rate for assets and liabilities and at the average
rate for the period for revenue and expense with all resulting exchange differences recognized in other comprehensive income.
Consequently, increases or decreases in the value of these currencies against the dollar may affect the value of our assets,
liabilities, revenue and expenses with respect to our non-U.S. dollar businesses in our consolidated financial statements, even
if their value has not changed in their functional currency, which creates a foreign currency translation risk.

We have or may have in the future intra-group and external loans where the denomination of the loan is in a currency other
than the U.S. dollar. As a result, we are and expect to be subject to certain shifts in currency valuations, such as between the
U.S. dollar and the pound sterling, euro or Australian dollar. See also “—Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures About
_Market Risk—Foreign Currency Risk”._


-----

In order to aid in the comparability of information between reporting periods and business units, we sometimes describe our
results on a constant currency basis. A significant amount of our operations do not have the U.S. dollar as the functional
currency and therefore our financial performance, which is reported in U.S. dollar, is impacted by the change in exchange rates.
Constant currency performance is calculated by translating performance of non-U.S. dollar regions using the foreign exchange
rates applicable in the comparative period and allows users to compare our performance on a consistent basis.

**_COVID-19 Pandemic_**

We have continued to adapt to the challenges caused by or related to COVID-19 and related variants. For example, revenue in
the first few months of 2022 and in 2021 was impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic following decreased site footfall due to
travel restrictions across some of the regions in which we operate. During the year ended December 31, 2021, especially in the
first half of the year, our Fuel operations in particular continued to be impacted by the lockdown measures imposed by national
and state governments in response to the COVID-19 pandemic. While there was a recovery across the majority of regions
towards the end of 2021, overall volumes were adversely impacted by continued restrictions and work from home guidance
during 2021. Our Australian business was impacted more heavily by the COVID-19 pandemic than our other regions in the
year ended December 31, 2021, with severe lockdown restrictions in place for a large portion of the second half of the year.
Despite lower footfall in our stores, our convenience earnings remained resilient as a result of higher margins and investment
made in our non-fuel offering and in particular as a result of strong sale volumes and stable gross margin in our Grocery &
Merchandise operating segment. During the first half of 2023, we have continued to experience reduced Fuel sale volumes
globally, in part as a result of continued reduced footfall caused by a shift to hybrid working, reducing travel requirements for
employees. However, this has been offset by higher gross margins in our Fuel operations.

We also faced certain other ongoing obstacles during 2021 and 2022, including a stressed labor market which led to challenges
finding, hiring and retaining employees and increased wage pressures, with wages across the convenience retailer, restaurant
and retail industries in general continuing to rise, which directly contributed to increased operating expenses. The COVID-19
pandemic also accelerated a customer trend towards convenience shopping and home delivery, and even beyond the pandemic,
as customer behavior has transitioned to more hybrid routines, convenience has become a critical factor to our customers,
particularly in the grocery and foodservice sectors. As a result, we believe we are well positioned to meet our customers’
convenience needs, and we are focused on improving this even further through our digital strategy, which includes self-service
kiosks and rapid delivery through app-based delivery platforms. These digital initiatives are being rolled out in all countries in
which we operate.

During the years ended December 31, 2021 and 2022, we also received support from governments, including the UK
government, in connection with our response to the COVID-19 pandemic. In 2021, this support included furlough and job
retention scheme reliefs, tax payment deferral schemes and business rates relief. For example, in the year ended December 31,
2021, we recognized government grant income of $10 million in relation to furlough program, such as the Coronavirus Job
Retention Scheme (“CJRS”) in the United Kingdom and its equivalents in other countries. In 2022, this support included tax
payment deferral schemes and business rates relief.

We also benefited from the business rates holiday for the retail, hospitality and leisure sector in the United Kingdom of $3
million and $25 million in the years ended December 31, 2022 and 2021, respectively. Of the indirect taxes which were deferred
during 2020, the outstanding balance as at December 31, 2022 was $445 million, which is repayable over the period to
September 2027.

**Factors Affecting Comparability of Our Financial Statements**

**_Acquisitions and Disposals_**

Historically, acquisitions have been a significant driver of the growth in our geographic scale, breadth of offerings, revenue
and profit margins. We have completed a number of selective acquisitions and disposals of varying sizes from 2021 through
2023, which may impact the comparability of our financial results between periods including as a result of purchase price
accounting, cost savings and synergies. Since we consolidate the results of operations of each acquired business in our financial
statements from the completion date of each acquisition and carve out the results of operations of each disposed business from
our financial statements from the completion date of each disposal, our historical financial periods are not directly comparable
to one another.

Following the closing date of an acquisition, our results are consolidated with the results of the acquired business and are
thereafter impacted by the revenues and expenses of the acquired business. In addition, our results are affected by other items
such as (i) our ability to realize synergies, (ii) selling, general and administrative functions such as sales, marketing, finance,


-----

human resources, information technology and management, (iii) the consolidation of our purchasing functions and increases in
margin due to our application of best practices and (iv) any costs we incur to realize synergies and similar items.

From time to time, we also dispose of business units or locations. As of the closing date of a disposal, the results of operations
and assets and liabilities attributable to the disposed business are no longer under the control of the Group and therefore are no
longer presented in our financial statements. We have historically generated profit from our disposals, which would positively
impact our cash position. However, disposals could also result in lower revenue, impairments of goodwill and a lower amount
of total assets on our balance sheet.

We account for acquisitions using the acquisition method of accounting. As a result, the purchase price for the acquired business
is allocated to identifiable assets acquired and liabilities assumed based upon their respective fair values as of the date of the
acquisition. The excess of the purchase price over these allocations is assigned to goodwill, which is not amortized for
accounting purposes but is subject to testing for impairment at least annually. The allocation of the purchase price to the assets
acquired in the acquisition may result in an increase in amortization and depreciation expense because we will record the fair
value of the acquired intangible assets and adjust the book value of the acquired tangible assets to their fair value. We evaluate
the remaining depreciable lives of the tangible assets to reflect the estimated useful lives for purposes of calculating periodic
depreciation, and we will amortize the intangible assets over their estimated useful lives. We will also review the value of the
inventory and will adjust it to fair value, which may change the costs and expenses recognized by us upon the sale of this
acquired inventory.

Amsric Acquisition and the LEON Acquisition by drawing on a £220 million term loan facility under our Senior Credit

result of these acquisitions. The Amsric sites will not be disposed of in connection with the UK Disposal to Asda.

_LEON Acquisition_

On May 9, 2021, we completed the acquisition of LEON Restaurants (“LEON”). The acquisition enabled us to further enhance
our Foodservice portfolio. As part of the acquisition, net assets of $60 million were acquired for consideration of $139 million,
generating goodwill of $79 million. Transaction costs of $3 million relating to stamp duty, professional and legal fees were
recognized as exceptional administrative expenses in the 2022 income statement. We have included the results of operations
of LEON in our consolidated financial statements since May 9, 2021. We financed the LEON Acquisition and the Amsric
Acquisition by drawing on a £220 million term loan facility under our Senior Credit Facilities Agreement, which was completed
in December 2021, therefore our debt and cash interest expense increased as a result of the acquisition of LEON and Amsric
Group. The LEON sites were disposed of in connection with the UK Disposal to Asda.


-----

_United States_

Sprint Acquisition

On December 14, 2021, we completed the acquisition of 34 company-operated fuel and convenience retail locations in Georgia
and South Carolina, USA and the proprietary ‘Sprint Kitchen’ Foodservice brand from Sprint, allowing us to expand our
footprint in the United States. The consideration for the acquisition was $283 million and the net assets recognized were $92
million, with goodwill of $191 million. Transaction costs of $1.5 million relating to professional and legal fees were recognized
as exceptional administrative expenses in the income statement for the year ended December 31, 2021. We have included the
results of operations of Sprint in our consolidated financial statements since December 14, 2021. We financed this acquisition
from cash on our balance sheet.

Mercury Acquisition

On June 1, 2021, we completed the acquisition of eight PFS sites from Mercury Fuel Service, Inc (“Mercury”) in Connecticut.
We already operated a network of Cumberland Farms locations in Connecticut and the addition of the Mercury sites has enabled
us to further expand the presence of the Cumberland Farms brand in the state. As part of the acquisition, net assets of $13
million were acquired for consideration of $34 million, generating goodwill of $21 million. We have included the results of
operations of Mercury in our consolidated financial statements since June 1, 2021.

These acquisitions have affected our results and limit the comparability of our results from period to period. Potential future
acquisitions may also impact our results in the future.

_Synergies Resulting from Acquisitions_

Acquisitions enable the consolidation of many of the functions of an acquired entity in order to achieve synergies. For example,
the OMV Acquisition was completed to further enhance our footprint in Continental Europe and to realize expected synergies,
rather than solely generate cash flows from its existing assets. Acquisitions we complete may also lead to increased sales
volumes, improved margins and customer retention through, among other measures, the offering of complementary products
and services to an expanding customer base in a wider geographic network and the use of our scale to procure additional
premium partnerships and favorable pricing terms in our supply contracts. These factors have contributed to the successful
integration of the acquisitions that we have made and the realization of synergies from such acquisitions. Our results for the
period during which an acquisition takes place are affected by the inclusion of the results of the acquired sites or business in
our consolidated results from the date of their combination or acquisition, but the full impact of a business combination or
acquisition is typically only reflected in our financial statements in the subsequent period as synergies and cost savings begin
to be realized. As a result, synergies that have already been and potentially can be realized from acquisitions we undertake may
limit the comparability of our results from period to period. See “Summary Consolidated Historical and As Adjusted Financial
_Information and Other Data—Other Financial and Operating Data—Key Performance Indicators and Non-Financial Data.”_
Our acquisitions also entail risks. See “Risk Factors—Our acquisitions, divestitures or group initiatives may not be successful
_and we may not achieve the returns, synergies, cost savings or other benefits initially anticipated from them.”_

_Disposals_

From time to time, we also dispose of business units or locations.

Europe

_UK Disposal to Asda_

On May 30, 2023, we announced our binding agreement to sell a substantial majority of our Fuel, Foodservice and Grocery
and Merchandise business in the United Kingdom to Asda. The transaction was completed on October 31, 2023 for
consideration of £2 billion. The proceeds will be used to repay our external debt. The UK Disposal to Asda is a transformational
step for us and provides a platform for us to further invest and focus on maximizing long-term growth opportunities and
shareholder value across the remaining international business. We will continue to operate in the United States, Australia,
Germany, France, Italy, the Netherlands, Luxembourg and Belgium, and will continue to consider our strategic options in the
Retained UK&I Business where the Cooplands bakery business and certain other foodservice brands will also be retained. The
Disposed UK Business has been presented as an asset held for sale in the EG Group Condensed unaudited consolidated interim
financial statements. See “The Transactions” and “Summary Consolidated Historical and As Adjusted Financial Information
_and Other Data—Other Financial and Operating Data.”_

In April 2023, pursuant to the Non-Core Minit Mart Disposal (Missouri and Kansas), we completed the sale of 26 non-core

**Description of Key Income Statement Items**

**_Revenue_**

We provide three primary categories of products and services to our customers: Grocery & Merchandise, Foodservice and Fuel.
We also provide ancillary services, such as car washes, lottery ticket sales and ATMs, through our forecourt operations which
are recognized within other sales.

Revenue is recognized when we have a contract with a customer and a performance obligation has been satisfied, at the
transaction price allocated to that performance obligation. We do not adjust any of the transaction prices for the time value of
money due to the nature of our transactions being completed shortly after the transaction is entered into with the customer.


-----

Revenue from the sale of fuel and goods in store is recognized when the transaction is completed in store or at the filling station.
Revenue from fuel sales to authorized dealers is recognized when the goods are delivered to the specific site location and
control passes.

The treatment of fuel duty is determined by local laws and regulations as to when the duty becomes legally payable and who
carries the risks and obligations to the tax authorities. In all markets where fuel duty is applicable to fuel purchases and sales,
the cost of sales and revenues are reported including these duties, as our role in the transaction is that of principal.

Within the Group, there are a number of ‘dealer’ or ‘retailer’ arrangements in place, whereby a third party will be responsible
for some part of the operation of a site. When we act as principal, revenue is recognized in respect of the gross amount of
consideration paid by the customer. In line with IFRS 15, when we do not control the goods which are transferred, we act as
an agent and recognize revenue only in the amount of any fee or commission to which we expect to be entitled in exchange for
arranging for the specified goods or services to be provided by the other party.

We operate customer loyalty programs where customers accumulate points for purchases made that subsequently entitle them
to discounts on future purchases, and account for these programs in accordance with IFRS 15. Revenue from loyalty points is
recognized when the customer redeems the points. Revenue for points that are not expected to be redeemed is recognized in
proportion to the pattern of rights exercised by customers.

Revenue from the provision of services includes dealer and franchise revenues, commissions received for ancillary services
and car wash revenues, and is presented within other sales. Also included within other sales are include Grocery & Merchandise
stock sales to dealers in Europe, where we facilitates the sale and purchase of dry stock between a wholesale supplier and our
portfolio of dealers. Revenue from the provision of services such as car washes, lottery ticket sales and ATMs, is recognized
when the service is provided as that is the point in time at which the customer benefits from the service. Where we act as an
agent selling goods or services, only the commission income is included within revenue.

See Note 3 to the 2022 EG Group Audited Financial Statements included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum for further
detail.

**_Cost of Sales_**

Cost of sales represents direct costs incurred in the sale of goods and services including, among other things, commissions paid
to dealers, the purchase and delivery costs of Fuel, Grocery & Merchandise and Foodservice products supplied to our customers.
We refer to supplier incentives, rebates and discounts (such as volume-related discounts from suppliers and income received
from suppliers to support specific in-store promotional activities for supplier products) collectively as commercial income.
Commercial income is recognized as a deduction from cost of sales on an accruals basis based on the expected entitlement that
has been earned up to the balance sheet date for each relevant supplier contract.

We operate a number of brands under franchise agreements across our jurisdictions. Costs paid to franchise owners are
presented within cost of sales.

**_Distribution Costs_**

Distribution costs represent all direct costs of running our sites and include rental costs, the depreciation of property, plant and
equipment for site assets, utilities, staff and maintenance costs, site conversion costs and lease payments.

**_Administrative Expenses_**

Administrative expenses represent the central and regional overhead costs of the business, such as the cost of our head office
functions, including those of our IT, finance and human resource functions, utilities and transaction costs related to acquisitions.
Depreciation of plant, property and equipment for regional and central offices and amortization of intangible assets are also
charged to administrative expenses.

**_Profit on disposal_**

Profit or loss on disposal is calculated the difference between the net proceeds received from a disposal and the carrying value
of the asset being disposed of.


-----

**_Other Operating Income_**

Other operating income represents gains/losses on the disposal of property, plant and equipment and income received on the
termination of concession arrangements.

**_Share of Profit/(Loss) of Equity Accounted Investments_**

Share of profit/(loss) of equity accounted investments represents amounts in joint ventures’ and associates’ financial statements
prepared in accordance with IFRS adjusted by us for equity accounting purposes.

**_Finance Income_**

Finance income is recognized in the consolidated income statement in the year or period to which it relates using the effective
interest rate method. Finance income comprises:

  - interest receivable, which is recognized in the consolidated income statement as it accrues using the effective interest
method;

  - foreign exchange gains arising on financing; and

  - finance income, which is recognized in the consolidated income statement in the year in which it occurs.

**_Finance Costs_**

Finance costs are recognized in the consolidated income statement in the year or period in which they occur. Finance costs
comprise:

  - interest payable, which is recognized in the consolidated income statement as it accrues using the effective interest
method

  - foreign exchange losses arising on financing;

  - finance costs incurred on finance leases, which are recognized in profit or loss using the effective interest method; and

  - financing costs of raising debt.

**_Tax_**

Tax represents the sum of the tax currently payable and deferred tax. Current and deferred tax are recognized in profit or loss,
except when they relate to items that are recognized in other comprehensive income or directly in equity, in which case the
current and deferred tax are also recognized in other comprehensive income or directly in equity respectively.

Current tax is the expected tax payable or receivable on taxable profit or loss for the applicable year or period. Taxable profit
differs from net profit as reported in the income statement because it excludes items of income or expense that are taxable or
deductible in other periods or items that are never taxable or deductible. Our liability for current tax is calculated using tax
rates that have been enacted or substantively enacted by the balance sheet date.

Deferred tax is provided using the balance sheet liability method, providing for temporary differences between the carrying
amounts of assets and liabilities for financial reporting purposes and the amounts used for taxation purposes.

Deferred tax is calculated at the tax rates that are expected to apply in the year or period when the liability is settled, or the
asset is realized based on tax laws and rates that have been enacted or substantively enacted at the balance sheet date. Deferred
tax is charged or credited in the income statement, except when it relates to items charged or credited in other comprehensive
income, in which case the deferred tax is also dealt with in other comprehensive income.

Deferred tax assets are recognized to the extent that it is probable that taxable profits will be available against which deductible
temporary differences can be utilized. The carrying amount of deferred tax assets is reviewed at each balance sheet date and
reduced to the extent that it is no longer probable that sufficient taxable profits will be available to allow all or part of the asset
to be recovered.


-----

Deferred tax assets and liabilities are offset when there is a legally enforceable right to set off current tax assets against current
tax liabilities, when they relate to income taxes levied by the same taxation authority and when we intend to settle our current
tax assets and liabilities on a net basis.

Grocery & Merchandise

Revenue from our Grocery & Merchandise operations increased by $105 million, or 5%, from $2,148 million for the six months
ended June 30, 2022 to $2,253 million for the six months ended June 30, 2023 driven by increased revenue from the United
States and Europe (including Continental Europe and the United Kingdom and Ireland), partially offset by decreased revenue
from Australia.

The increase in Grocery & Merchandise revenue in Europe was driven primarily by inflationary price increases and a strong
focus on product mix and pricing optimization in Continental Europe and the impact of investment in new sites and Asda ‘On
the move’ conversions, in addition to inflationary price increases in the United Kingdom and Ireland. Grocery & Merchandise
revenue from our United States operations increased primarily due to pricing initiatives. In Australia, the reduced Grocery &
Merchandise revenue was primarily driven by reduced tobacco sales.

Foodservice

Revenue from our Foodservice operations increased by $68 million, or 11%, from $627 million for the six months ended June
30, 2022 to $695 million for the six months ended June 30, 2023 driven by increased revenue from the United States,
Continental Europe and the United Kingdom and Ireland and Australia.

The increase in Foodservice revenue in Europe was driven primarily by increased footfall and new store openings in Continental
Europe and strong sales across all brands, supported by new site openings in the United Kingdom and Ireland. Foodservice
revenue in the United States increased primarily due to the growth of our in-store Foodservice offering resulting from various
promotional activities, which more than offset the reduced revenue impact from the closure of certain non-profitable
Foodservice outlets. Foodservice revenue from our Australian operations remained materially unchanged for the periods
between the six months ended June 30, 2022 and the six months ended June 30, 2023, noting that Foodservice operations have
now ceased in Australia.

Fuel

Revenue from our Fuel operations decreased by $1,193 million, or 10%, from $12,192 million for the six months ended June
30, 2022 to $10,999 million for the six months ended June 30, 2023 driven by decreased revenue from the United States, Europe
(including Continental Europe and the United Kingdom and Ireland) and Australia.

The decrease in Fuel revenue in the United States, Europe and Australia was primarily due to lower average fuel retail prices
as a result of global oil prices normalizing after the highs experienced in 2022 caused by Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, and, in
the case of the United States, lower Fuel volumes sold. In Continental Europe, the decrease was partially offset by the six
months ended June 30, 2023 benefiting from the full consolidation for the entire period of the six months of results from the
OMV Acquisition whereas the six months ended June 30, 2022 only reflected the full consolidation of two months of OMV
financial results.

Grocery & Merchandise

Gross profit from our Grocery & Merchandise operations increased by $27 million, or 4%, from $640 million for the six months
ended June 30, 2022 to $667 million for the six months ended June 30, 2023. This increase was primarily driven by new sites,
increased footfall and COCO conversions in Continental Europe, investment in new sites and Asda on the Move conversions
across the United Kingdom and Ireland, strong sales, mainly driven by pricing initiatives, in the United States, and unchanged
results in Australia, which were driven primarily by an increased mix of higher margin products, which was offset by declining
tobacco sales.

Foodservice

Gross profit from our Foodservice operations increased by $35 million, or 10%, from $354 million for the six months ended
June 30, 2022 to $389 million for the six months ended June 30, 2023. This increase was driven primarily by the impact of
increased footfall and new store opening in Continental Europe, increased sales and pass through of cost price increases which
had a lag in 2022 for some brands, further supported by new site openings in the United Kingdom and Ireland, the closing of
underperforming food concessions, increased in-store Foodservice sales and increased overall profitability in the United States
and unchanged results in Australia.

Fuel

Gross profit from our Fuel operations decreased by $45 million, or 5%, from $993 million for the six months ended June 30,
2022 to $948 million for the six months ended June 30, 2023. This decrease was driven by adverse inventory revaluations in
EG Fuel in Europe, highly competitive market conditions driving a reduction in fuel volumes sold, with price sensitive
consumers switching to lower price competitors in the United States and changes in market dynamics and consumer behavior
due to cost of living pressures in Australia, partially offset by a combination of new sites and the Asda Fuel proposition and
‘Asda On the Move’ conversions driving footfall at converted sites in the United Kingdom and Ireland, albeit at a slightly lower
fuel margin.

Distribution costs decreased by $32 million, or 2%, from $1,672 million for the six months ended June 30, 2022 to
$1,640 million for the six months ended June 30, 2023. This decrease was primarily due to a reduction in the calculated
impairment charge required for the six months ended June 30, 2023 of £101 million when compared to the six months ended
June 30, 2022 charge of $152 million. This reduction is then offset partially due to inflationary price increases.

Leaseback, an increase of $18 million when compared to the prior period. In addition, the increase in the Group’s amortization

Finance costs increased by $196 million, or 56%, from $352 million for the six months ended June 30, 2022 to $548 million

Grocery & Merchandise

Revenue from our Grocery & Merchandise operations decreased by $54 million, or 1%, from $4,484 million for the twelve
months ended December 31, 2021 to $4,430 million for the twelve months ended December 31, 2022 driven by decreased
revenue from Europe (including Continental Europe and the United Kingdom and Ireland) and Australia, partially offset by
increased revenue from the United States.

The decrease in Grocery & Merchandise revenue in Europe and Australia was driven primarily by currency translation effects
and adverse foreign exchange rate movements. Grocery & Merchandise revenue from our United States operations increased
primarily due to due to the 2021 Sprint Acquisition, inflationary prices increases and promotional activity driving improved
footfall and from enhanced product mix.

Foodservice

Revenue from our Foodservice operations increased by $218 million, or 21%, from $1,062 million for the twelve months ended
December 31, 2021 to $1,280 million for the twelve months ended December 31, 2022 driven by increased revenue from the
United States, Continental Europe and the United Kingdom and Ireland and Australia.

The increase in Foodservice revenue in Europe was driven primarily by increased opening hours and footfall versus as
compared to 2021, which was impacted by reduced operations as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic, as well as our investment
in branded third-party foodservice outlets and inflationary price increases in our European operations. Foodservice revenue in
the United States increased primarily due to the 2021 Sprint Acquisition, inflationary price increases and the rollout of new
outlets and promotional activity to drive sales.

Fuel

Revenue from our Fuel operations increased by $4,076 million, or 20%, from $20,346 million for the twelve months ended
December 31, 2021 to $24,422 million for the twelve months ended December 31, 2022 driven by increased revenue from the
United States, Europe (including Continental Europe and the United Kingdom and Ireland) and Australia.

The increase in Fuel revenue in Europe was primarily driven by the acquisition of 2021 OMV Acquisition and the increased
Fuel retail prices seen globally following Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. Increased Fuel revenue in the United States was also
primarily due to global increase of fuel retail prices. The increase in Fuel revenue in Australia was primarily driven by exiting
prolonged COVID-19 restrictions in early 2022 and increased Fuel retail prices in 2022 due to high wholesale fuel costs
throughout the year following Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.

$26,263 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. Excluding the impact of foreign exchange rates, cost of sales increased
27%. This increase was primarily due to increased wholesale oil prices caused by ongoing geopolitical events following the
conflict in Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. Excluding the impact of foreign exchange rates, cost of sale increased 27%.
