Grocery & Merchandise

Gross profit from our Grocery & Merchandise operations decreased by $13 million, or 1%, from $1,338 million for the year
ended December 31, 2021 to $1,325 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. This decrease was primarily due to foreign
exchange movements in Continental Europe, the United Kingdom and Ireland and Australia and reduced lottery sales as a result
of reduced discretionary customer spending in the United Sates, partially offset by enhanced sales mix, including increased
beverage sales in the United States. Excluding the impact of foreign exchange rates, Grocery & Merchandise gross profit
increased by 5% in Continental Europe, driven by increased footfall and improved sales mix of higher margin products, 10%
in the United Kingdom and Ireland driven by the increased sales linked to our ‘Asda on the Move’ initiative and 3% in Australia,
largely driven by improved product mix in our convenience retail offering.

Foodservice

Gross profit from our Foodservice operations increased by $91 million, or 15%, from $614 million for the year ended December
31, 2021 to $705 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. When translated at a constant currency rate, Foodservice gross
profit increased 28%. This increase was primarily driven by increased operating hours against the backdrop of reduced
operation in 2021 in some countries as part of the restrictions in place in relation to the COVID-19 pandemic in Continental
Europe. This increase was also driven by continued growth in our Foodservice operations in the United Kingdom and Ireland,
driven by ongoing site development during the year, including the opening of eight NTI forecourts, and by the annualized
impact of our U.K. Foodservice acquisitions made throughout 2021, as well as the rollout of eleven new Foodservice outlets
the United States during 2022.

Fuel

Gross profit from our Fuel operations increased by $175 million, or 9%, from $1,935 million for the year ended December 31,
2021 to $2,110 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. When translated at a constant currency rate, gross profit in the
United Kingdom and Ireland increased by 10% from 2021 to 2022, gross profit in Continental Europe increased by 13% from
2021 to 2022, with OMV contributing $64 million of Fuel gross profit in the year ended December 31, 2022, and gross profit
in Australia increased by 7% from 2021 to 2022. This increase was primarily driven by supportive fuel margins in all regions
(except Germany), which offset a reduction in volume resulting from volatile fuel market conditions, as higher prices impacted
volumes as price sensitive consumers moved to lower priced competitors, and increased fuel margins observed in the United
States as a result of such market volatility. In Germany, our fuel margins in the second half of 2022 were negatively impacted
by the impact of price indexing on our contracted fuel prices. This impact has not continued into 2023. The Sprint Acquisition
also contributed an additional $21 million of Fuel gross profit for the year ended December 31, 2022. These results were
partially offset by decreased gross profit in Continental Europe and Australia due to foreign exchange movements of the euro
and Australian dollar against the U.S. dollar.

_Distribution Costs_

Distribution costs increased by $409 million, or 14%, from $2,987 million for the year ended December 31, 2021 to
$3,396 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. Excluding the impact of foreign exchange rates, distribution costs


-----

increased by 19%. This increase was primarily due to the full year impact of the Group’s 2021 LEON Acquisition, Amsric
Acquisition, Cooplands Acquisition and Sprint Acquisition, which were completed in May 2021, September 2021, October
2021 and December 2021 respectively, and the OMV Acquisition which was completed in May 2022, as well as the weakening
of all translated currencies as compared to 2021 against the U.S. dollar. In addition to this, the Group’s impairment charge
booked on tangible fixed assets and right of use assets increased by $115 million due to adverse movements in the performance
of certain sites, together with increases to discount rates used when calculating the fair value of the sites from 2021 to 2022.

_Administrative Expenses_

Administrative expenses decreased by $19 million, or 3%, from $566 million for the year ended December 31, 2021 to
$547 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. Excluding the impact of foreign exchange rates, administrative expenses
increased by 9%. This increase was primarily due to inflationary pressures, including related to cost of living increases on head
office and regional salaries, as well as contractual increases and IT, and the continued investment in our shared service center.

_Other Operating Income_

Other operating income decreased by $14 million, or 17%, from $82 million for the year ended December 31, 2021 to
$68 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. This decrease was primarily due to the reduction in the exceptional profits
recognized on disposals of $67 million from 2021 to 2022, following the sale of a number of our sites in the United Kingdom
in 2021 following the outcome of the CMA’s review of our shareholders’ acquisition of Asda, which was partially offset by
the revaluation of an unfavorable contract provision following the resolution of our dispute with Ampol in April 2022, which
resulted in a decrease in the carrying value of provisions by $43 million.

the year ended December 31, 2022. Excluding exceptional items (comprising $15 million of debt extinguishment losses and
$41 million of transaction-related finance costs in the year ended December 31, 2021), net finance costs increased by
$316 million from $419 million for the year ended December 31, 2021 to $735 million for the year ended December 31, 2022.

short-term borrowing facilities, in addition to interest on lease liabilities, the amortization of debt arrangement fees and nonutilization fees. Our external interest expense and debt servicing costs increased as a result of variable interest rate increases in
the year.

**Liquidity and Capital Resources**

Our Group Treasury function manages our liquidity and capital resources activities. Historically, our principal sources of funds
have been cash generated from our operating activities and borrowings under our Senior Credit Facilities, including our
Revolving Credit Facilities, and the Existing Indentures. Our principal uses of cash are to fund debt service obligations, working
capital and capital expenditures and, historically, had been to complete acquisitions. As of June 30, 2023, we had cash and cash
equivalents of $1,423 million (not including $139 million of cash held for sale, primarily related to the UK Disposal to Asda).
Following the UK Disposal to Asda and the Conditions Satisfaction Date, commitments under the Revolving Credit Facilities
will be $378 million (equivalent) and commitments under our Letter of Credit Facilities will be $638 million (equivalent).
Drawings under the Revolving Credit Facilities are available in U.S. dollars, euro and pound sterling. The Letter of Credit
Facilities operate as a committed bank guarantee facility, which is regularly utilized to provide credit support for fuel purchases
and rental obligations. Group Treasury is actively redirecting this activity toward the surety bond market. See “Description of
_Certain Financing Arrangements—Senior Credit Facilities Agreement.”_

Our principal source of liquidity on an ongoing basis is expected to be our operating cash flows and borrowings under our
Revolving Credit Facilities and Letter of Credit Facilities. Our ability to generate cash depends on our future operating
performance, which, in turn, depends to some extent on general economic, financial, industry and other factors, many of which
are beyond our control. See “Risk Factors.”

Although we believe that our expected cash flows from operations, together with available borrowings under our Revolving
Credit Facilities, will be adequate to meet our anticipated working capital and general corporate needs for the next twelve
months, we cannot assure you that our business will generate sufficient cash flows from operating activities or that future debt
financing will be available to us in an amount sufficient to enable us to pay our debts when due, including the Notes, or to fund
our other liquidity needs. The availability of our Revolving Credit Facilities is dependent upon conditions, including ongoing
compliance with a maintenance covenant tested quarterly as described further under “Description of Certain Financing
_Arrangements—Senior Credit Facilities Agreement.”_


-----

**Cash Management**

Our middle office, which is a part of our Group treasury function and which manages our liquidity on a daily basis, is comprised
of a team of four in Blackburn, a regional treasury of two in the United States and a cash manager in each of Australia, Germany
and Italy. The introduction of CashForce, our new treasury management system, benefits our near- to medium-term liquidity
analysis to minimize any call on the Revolving Credit Facility, with surplus cash invested in AAA government backed money
market accounts in either the United States or the United Kingdom. In terms of cash flow, the biggest outflows are seen at
quarter end, when monthly outflows such as salary, VAT & customs & excise payments are supplemented with quarterly
outflows of interest expense and bank fees.

**Hedging**

Group Treasury actively manages foreign exchange risk and has recruited a dedicated Front Office Risk Manager to support
this activity. Most foreign exchange activity historically has been accommodated with spot trades for liquidity purposes.
Forward contracts are more regularly used in M&A transactions to mitigate potential exchange rate movement between
signature and completion of either a significant acquisition or disposal, including in connection with the UK Disposal to Asda
on a deal contingent basis where we have hedged substantial sales proceeds in pound sterling to provide certainty of debt
prepayments due in U.S. dollar, euro and Australian dollar.

Where we consider necessary, we may also use foreign exchange forward contracts to hedge the exposure we have servicing
debt held by certain our subsidiaries with a different functional currency than the currency of such debt instrument. See “—
_Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures About Market Risk—Foreign Currency Risk”._

While we may enter into additional hedging agreements in the future, we may also elect not to do so or the terms on which we
hedge may not be satisfactory or may fail to adequately protect us from changes in foreign exchange rates or interest rates.

**Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures About Market Risk**

In the ordinary course of business, we are exposed to a variety of market risks including market risk (including foreign currency
risk and interest rate risk), credit risk and liquidity risk. We monitor and manage these risks as a part of our overall risk
management. The following section discusses the significant financial risks to which we are exposed. This discussion does not
address other risks to which we are exposed in the ordinary course of business, such as operational risks. For further detail, see
Note 34 to the 2022 EG Group Audited Financial Statements included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum.

**_Interest Rate Risk_**

Interest rate risk is the risk that the fair value or future cash flows of a financial instrument will fluctuate because of changes in
market interest rates. Certain of our credit facilities bear interest at variable rates and therefore our earnings and cash flow are
subject to fluctuation from changes in the applicable benchmark rate. Increases in short-term interest rates will increase debt
service requirements and reduce earnings and net cash flows. Hedging activities are evaluated regularly to align with interest
rate views and a defined risk appetite, ensuring the most cost-effective hedging strategies are applied.

In light of the present uncertainty over the outlook of interest rates, we have hedged against potential scenarios where interest
rates move further higher beyond current expectations through a combination of interest rate caps and swaps. Interest rate caps


-----

provide us, in exchange for a premium cost, with an insurance against interest rate increases by providing a pay-out if rates go
above an agreed strike rate. If rates stay lower than the strike rate, we continue to benefit from the lower market floating rate.
We have entered into interest rate caps against both our floating rate Euro and U.S. dollar exposure. Specifically, €850 million
of our floating rate Euro debt is capped at a strike rate of 4% for two years ending 30[th] September 2025 and $1.1 billion of our
floating rate U.S. dollar exposure is capped at a strike 5.5% for two years ending 30 September 2025. We are also evaluating
the addition of interest rate swaps, which would allow us to lock in the average rate of the prevailing interest rate forward curve
for the tenor of the hedge and therefore provide more certainty of cash flows. While we may enter into additional hedging
agreements in the future, we may also elect not to do so or the terms on which we hedge may not be satisfactory or may fail to
adequately protect us from changes in interest rates.

**_Credit Risk_**

Credit risk refers to the risk that a counterparty will default on its contractual obligations resulting in financial loss to us. Credit
risk arises from cash and cash equivalents, deposits with banks and financial institutions, derivatives in an asset position, as
well as credit exposures to wholesale and retail customers, including outstanding receivables and committed transactions. Sales
to retail customers are settled in cash or using major credit cards. In the year ended December 31, 2022, we had unsecured
trade and other receivables of $768 million (compared to $639 million in 2021) and cash and cash equivalents of $466 million
(compared to $646 million in 2021), reflecting our maximum exposure to credit risk. These receivables are normally settled
when due and are spread across a number of counterparties so the likelihood of material losses arising as a result of this exposure
is considered insignificant for the reasons set out below.

Our trade receivable balances comprise a number of individually small amounts from unrelated customers, over a number of
geographical areas. Concentration of risk is therefore limited.

We have adopted a policy of only dealing with creditworthy counterparties and obtaining sufficient collateral where
appropriate, as a means of mitigating the risk of financial loss from defaults. We regularly monitor our exposure and the credit
ratings of our counterparties, taking into account, among other factors, the financial position of customers, our past experience
and other factors.

We have no significant concentration of credit risk. The credit risk on liquid funds and derivative financial instruments is
limited because the counterparties are banks with high credit ratings assigned by international credit-rating agencies.

**_Liquidity Risk_**

Liquidity risk is the risk of not being able to fulfill present or future obligations if we do not have sufficient funds available to
meet such obligations at the time they become due. Liquidity risk arises mostly in relation to cash flows generated and used in
working capital and from financing activities, particularly by servicing our debt, in terms of both interest and principal, and our
payment obligations relating to our ordinary business activities.

Ultimate responsibility for liquidity risk management rests with the Board, which we believe has established an appropriate
liquidity risk management framework for the management of our short, medium and long-term funding and liquidity
management requirements. We manage liquidity risk by maintaining adequate reserves, banking facilities and reserve
borrowing facilities, by regularly monitoring forecast and actual cash flows, and by matching the maturity profiles of financial
assets and liabilities.


-----

**_Market risk_**

Our activities expose us primarily to the financial risks of changes in foreign currency exchange rates and interest rates (see
“—Foreign Currency Risk”). We enter into a variety of derivative financial instruments to manage our exposure to interest rate
and foreign currency risk, including forward foreign exchange contracts to hedge the exchange rate risk arising on purchase of
fuel in U.S. dollars by our European subsidiaries.

We have not applied cash flow hedge accounting on forward foreign exchange contracts.

**_Foreign Currency Risk_**

Our results of operations are subject to foreign currency translation and transaction effects because we have operations in
Australia, Belgium, France, Germany, Italy, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, the United Kingdom and the United States, which
are and will be conducted primarily in the respective local currency, and because we source products from suppliers worldwide.
As we present our consolidated financial statements in U.S. dollars, we must translate the assets, liabilities, revenue and
expenses of all of our operations with a functional currency other than the U.S. dollar into U.S. dollars at then-applicable
exchange rates. Consequently, increases or decreases in the value of these currencies against the U.S. dollar may affect the
value of our assets, liabilities, revenue and expenses with respect to our non-euro businesses in our consolidated financial
statements, even if their value has not changed in their original currency, which creates translation risk.

We are mainly exposed to the euro in relation to the servicing of euro-denominated debt held by our subsidiaries with a sterling
functional currency and the servicing of U.S. dollar-denominated debt held by our subsidiaries with a sterling functional
currency.

The Dollar Notes will be denominated in U.S. dollars and the Euro Notes will be denominated in euro, and changes in foreign
exchange rates will therefore give rise to foreign exchange exposure with respect to the Euro Notes.

**Significant Accounting Judgements and Key Sources of Estimation Uncertainty**

In the application of our accounting policies, we are required to make judgements, estimates and assumptions about the carrying
amounts of assets and liabilities that are not readily apparent from other sources. The estimates and associated assumptions are
based on historical experience and other factors that are considered to be relevant. Actual results may differ from these
estimates.


-----

The estimates and underlying assumptions are reviewed on an ongoing basis. Revisions to accounting estimates are recognized
in the period in which the estimate is revised if the revision affects only that period, or in the period of the revision and future
periods if the revision affects both current and future periods.

In preparing the EG Group Unaudited Financial Statements, the significant judgements made by management in applying the
Group’s accounting policies and the key sources of estimation uncertainty were the same as those that applied to the 2022 EG
Group Audited Financial Statements with the exception of the judgements exercised in respect to the U.S. Sale and Leaseback
which took place in the three months ended June 30, 2023, the Amend and Extend and the UK Disposal to Asda, as described
in footnote 1 to the EG Group Unaudited Financial Statements included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum.

**_Significant judgements in applying the Group’s accounting policies_**

In the process of applying our accounting policies, we have made the following judgements that have the most significant effect
on the amounts recognized in the financial statements (apart from those involving estimations, which are dealt with below) and
have been identified as being particularly complex or involve subjective assessments.

_Exceptional Items_

We consider that an adjusted profit measure provides useful information for the underlying trends, performance and position
of the Group. These measures are consistent with how business performance is measured internally by the board of directors.
Profit before exceptionals is not a recognized measure under IFRS and may not be directly comparable with adjusted measures
used by other companies.

We exercise judgement in determining the items to classify as exceptional items. This assessment considers the nature of the
item, cause of occurrence and the scale of impact of that item on reported performance. Reversals of previous exceptional items
are recognized as exceptional items. We exercise judgement in ensuring there is an equal focus by management in classifying
both expenses and revenue items as exceptional.

_Indefinite Life Brands_

The brands of Cumberland Farms and Cooplands are well-known long-standing brands in the United States and in the United
Kingdom and Ireland, respectively, and as a result of the reputation and association with quality there is no foreseeable limit
to the period over which the asset is expected to generate net cash inflows. The brands are therefore deemed to have, as of the
year ended December 31, 2022, an indefinite useful economic life and the values of $337 million and $20 million, respectively,
will not be amortized, but will be assessed for impairment annually.

**_Key sources of estimation uncertainty_**

The key assumptions concerning the future, and other key sources of estimation uncertainty at the balance sheet date, that have
a significant risk of causing a material adjustment to the carrying amounts of assets and liabilities within the next financial
year, are discussed below.

_Impairment of Property, Plant and Equipment and Intangibles_

Property, plant and equipment are reviewed for impairment if events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying
amount may not be recoverable. In performing the review, assets are grouped together into the smallest group of assets that is
largely independent of our other cash-generating streams.

Goodwill and indefinite life brands are reviewed for impairment on an annual basis. We allocate goodwill to groups of cashgenerating units, where each country represents a group of cash-generating units.

When a review for impairment is conducted, the recoverable amounts for cash-generating units are the higher of fair value less
cost of disposal, and value-in-use. In assessing value-in-use, the estimated future cash flows (which is a key source of estimation
uncertainty) are discounted to their present value using a pre-tax discount rate that reflects current market assessments of the
time value of money and the risks specific to the asset for which the estimates of future cash flows have not been adjusted.

Fair value is determined based on forecast earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization (“EBITDA”, which is
a non-IFRS measure) and EBITDA valuation multiples of comparable corporations and market transactions. For the purpose
of the impairment test, management uses estimates and assumptions to establish the fair value of our cash-generating units. If
these assumptions and estimates prove to be incorrect, the carrying value of the goodwill may be overstated.


-----

_Fair Values in Business Combinations_

In assessing the fair value of assets and liabilities acquired in business combinations, estimation is used in a number of areas.
To assist in this work, we engage external valuation experts to assess the fair value. Management then reviews the work and
assess the results.

_Measurement of provisions_

We recognize provisions for liabilities when it is more likely than not that a settlement will be required and the value of such a
payment can be reliably estimated. Contingent liabilities identified through business combinations are recognized on the
balance sheet as provisions in accordance with IFRS 3. In the year ended December 31, 2022, we have recognized provisions
totaling $691 million (compared to $839 million in 2021) for environmental costs, dilapidations and onerous contracts. The
provision for environmental costs and dilapidations is based on the current cost escalated at an inflation rate and discounted at
a risk-free rate. The provision for onerous contracts is based on the lower of our current estimates of cost of fulfilling the
contracts and any compensation or penalties and discounting to present value when the effect of time value of money is material.
These provisions are estimates and the actual costs and timing of future cash flows are dependent on future events and market
conditions.

Because actual outflows can differ from estimates due to changes in laws, regulations, prices and conditions, the carrying
amounts of provisions are regularly reviewed and adjusted to take account of such changes.

Any difference between expectations and the actual future liability will be accounted for in the period when such determination
is made. The carrying amount of provisions will be impacted by changes in the discount rate.

For further details of these significant accounting judgements and key Sources of estimation uncertainty, see Note 3 to the 2022
EG Group Audited Financial Statements included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum.

**INDUSTRY**
**Overview**

The global C-Store industry has three primary components: retail fuel, grocery & merchandise, and foodservice. The industry
is large and highly fragmented, and in recent years has experienced a number of divestitures and consolidation from major fuel
producers and/or refiners, grocery retailers, independent operators and chains. Chain stores generate the majority of fuel sales
in the C-Store industry. Although there are fewer sites, chain stores can sell more than three times the number of gallons per
month than smaller operators. Fuel offerings are the predominant driver of C-Store traffic. Historical and projected retail fuel
volumes and margins remain relatively stable across all geographies that we operate in. In more recent years, C-Stores have
improved the range of non-fuel products and services, such as grocery & merchandise and Foodservice products and services,
they offer in order to appeal to the increasingly “time-strapped” consumer. C-Store operators seek to provide these customers,
such as families with limited time for traditional shopping, with “one-stop” shopping solutions. Grocery & merchandise, and
foodservice products and services remain attractive, are expected to grow at positive rates and, generally are not threatened by
the growth of online retailers, for which sales of individual convenience retail products are less profitable. The pandemic
accelerated a customer trend towards convenience shopping and home delivery, but even beyond the pandemic, as customer
behavior has transitioned to more hybrid routines, convenience is a critical factor, particularly in the grocery and foodservice
sector.

**Fuel**

Historically, the retail fuel market has been stable, with fuel volumes growing at a moderate rate before the COVID-19
pandemic in the countries where we operate. The different geographic markets in which we operate are at various stages of
development. In particular, in the most developed markets, larger players have optimized their networks and site rationalization
has occurred, leading to an increase in average throughput per site and enhanced profitability. In addition, major fuel producers
and/or refiners and grocery retailers, which have historically held a significant share of the fuel retail market, continue to
refocus their core operations away from retail fuel services, giving rise to consolidation opportunities.

We expect fuel volumes within our current operating geographies to decrease slightly in the near future, largely driven by
anticipated vehicle efficiency improvements and an decline in average vehicle travel distance, which we believe is due to
changing consumer behavior after the COVID pandemic (i.e., greater tendency towards at-home behaviors including working
and eating meals at home). This decline is expected to be partially offset by structurally higher fuel unit margin profitability,
measured in cents per liter or gallon, and increased European vehicle fleet.

**Grocery & Merchandise and Foodservice**

In 2022, in the countries in which we currently operate, the grocery & merchandise market had sales of €260 billion and the
foodservice market had sales of €948 billion. These growing and attractive industries have benefited from positive trends,
notably emerging consumer trends and limited exposure to internet encroachment. These consumer trends include increases in
food consumption away from home, dual-income families, “on-the-go” meal solutions and increases in the number of cars on
the road. Foodservice and forecourt operators have in turn looked to upgrade their offerings, providing restaurant-quality food
to appeal to an increasingly time-strapped consumer looking for convenient solutions. Changing consumer habits have also
enabled fuel operators to expand their offerings, remain high-margin and increase profitability. The overall quality of
foodservice and forecourt operators’ offerings have improved as they look to differentiate and drive higher-margin inside sales,
diversifying from an industry that was historically dependent on lower margin tobacco and beverage sales. This increase in
quality of the offerings is forecasted to lead to continued margin growth across all of our geographies from 2022 to 2027. All
figures related to the development of the grocery & merchandise and foodservice markets are quoted from Euromonitor
International, Retail 2023 edition, extracted in September 2023. Unless otherwise stated, all value data citations are in retail
value (retail selling price excluding sales tax), in million euros (current terms), at a fixed 2022 exchange rate. In addition, data
from Consumer Foodservice 2023 edition, extracted in September 2023, was used. This data is quoted in foodservice value
(retail selling price including sales tax), in million euros (current terms), at a fixed 2022 exchange rate. Unless otherwise stated,
all market size CAGR figures are reported in local currency.

**Electric Vehicles (EV)**

The Company also operates in the growing market for electric vehicles through its deployment of EV charging points. C-Stores
globally began to start install EV chargers over a decade ago and have continued to deploy EV chargers since. During that time,
the market for Evs has experienced growth, with 10 million Evs sold in 2022. This figure represents 14% of all new car sales
in 2022, up from 9% in 2021 and less than 5% in 2020. Globally, China, Europe and the United States represent the largest
markets for Evs. EV sales in Europe increased by more than 15% in 2022, with Evs representing more than 20% of all new
cars sold in the continent. EV sales in the United States increased 55% in 2022, representing 8% of new cars sold in the country.
Global EV sales in the first quarter of 2023 were 25% higher than the year prior, representing strong growth and supporting
estimates of 14 million EV sales for the year, a 35% year-on-year increase.

The strong growth in the EV industry is supported by robust support from government policies in all major markets, with the
European Union and the United States both passing supportive legislation in recent years. The European Union has adopted
new CO2 standards for cars and vans aligned with its “Fit for 55” ambitions, which seeks to reduce emissions by at least 55%
by 2030. In the United States, the Inflation Reduction Act, California’s Advanced Clean Cars II rule, and recently proposed
emissions standards from the Environmental Protection Agency all support the country’s target of 50% market share for Evs
by 2030. Despite widespread support from a policy perspective, EV penetration faces headwinds caused by consumers buying
fewer new vehicles than in the past. The average age of cars and light trucks on the road in the United States increased to an
all-time high of 12.5 years in 2023, up from 9.7 years in 2003, due to greater efficiency and engineering in existing vehicle
fleets, and depressed consumer demand for new vehicles due to higher interest rates and levels of inflation.

Regarding charging infrastructure, public charging points are becoming increasingly necessary to support and enable wider EV
uptake. Specifically, publicly accessible fast chargers along highways can enable longer journeys and address range anxiety
among drivers. At the end of 2022, there were 2.7 million public charging points worldwide, of which more than 900,000 were
installed in 2022, representing a 55% increase from 2021 and in-line with the pre-pandemic growth rate of 50% between 2015
and 2019. In 2022, the supply of publicly accessible fast chargers increased by 330,000 globally, the majority of which were
in China. In Europe, there were over 70,000 publicly accessible fast chargers as of the 2022, an increase of around 55% as
compared to 2021. An agreement between the European Investment Bank and the European Commission will make over
€1.5 billion available for alternative fuels infrastructure, including fast chargers, by the end of 2023. Throughout the United

National Electric Vehicle Infrastructure Formula Program, a program established by the U.S. Infrastructure Investment and

**_The United States_**

The U.S. market is the largest convenience retailer market in the world with approximately 150,200 sites that sell fuel. The
U.S. market is very fragmented, with few operators with leading market position only in certain regions and approximately
60% of convenience stores owned by single store operators. The top 15 chains account for 36% of total U.S. sites and are
growing share primarily through acquisitions in an increasingly consolidated market. The majority of convenience retailers
have a forecourt fuel offering, selling 514 billion liters in 2022 and processing 160 million transactions per day. The U.S. fuel
market has a long track record of growing USD cents per liter, which is expected to offset any modest future volume declines.
The position of the National Association on Convenience Stores position on U.S. fuel demand includes some system-wide
decline due to the adoption of Evs and alternate energy sources. Improved fuel efficiency is expected to be the main catalyst
for declines in fuel demand.

The U.S. grocery & merchandise and foodservice markets are developed, with sales of €159 billion and €652 billion in 2022,
respectively, which are projected to grow between 2022 and 2027 at compound annual growth rates of 3.3% and 5.0%,
respectively, according to Euromonitor International. In particular, there is a trend toward larger store concepts that can support
expanded product offerings and partnerships with branded quick service restaurants. These enhancements tend to appeal to
emerging consumer preferences and provide “one-stop” shopping solutions for “time-strapped” consumers.

**_Europe_**

_France_

After a period of consolidation, the number of forecourts in France has continued to decline, from approximately 11,000 in
2013 to approximately 10,500 in 2021. Retail sales through grocery & merchandise channels, helped by inflationary pressures,
increased by 6% in 2022 to €11.1 billion. A larger proportion of office workers returning to offices and continued in the postCOVID-19 pandemic normalization of tourism and transportation activity also contributed to the sector’s strong performance
last year. Recently, supermarket chains have announced they intend to sell fuel at lower prices to increase store traffic, which
is likely to affect margins across the French market in the near-term After a brief recovery from the decline of 2020, French
retail fuel volumes are expected to steadily decrease from 2023 due to anticipated vehicle efficiency improvements and a
decline in average vehicle travel distance, which we believe is due to changing consumer behavior after the COVID-19
pandemic. France also has plans to end the sale of fossil fuel burning cars by 2040.

Recovery was also seen by forecourt retailers in 2022, due to a rebound in traffic after two years of low traffic in tourist and
transportation locations. Forecourt retailers are also tending to trade up in France, with better foodservice options and a more
local offering (for example, increased food options from nearby farmers), which has helped to drive growth. Given this and
other factors, forecourt grocery & merchandise sales are expected to increase by 1.3% annually between 2022 and 2027,
although this growth rate would be lower than the expected growth rate for the broader grocery & merchandise sector. On the
foodservice side, while the total number of consumer foodservice outlets remained well below pre-COVID-19 pandemic levels,
there were signs of recovery in 2022, due to the strong performance of quick service restaurants, which continued to gain
market share at the expense of other types of outlets. Within the quick service space, delivery and to-go accounted for almost
two thirds of value sales, with this share being particularly high in the case of burger, pizza and Asian outlets. Takeaway
accounted for 23.3% of all foodservice sales in 2022, compared to 14.2% in 2017, with this proportion expected to expand
further over the forecast period, as consumers seek greater convenience.

_Belgium_

In Belgium, in 2022, the number of forecourts was approximately 3,100, though the proportion of unmanned PFS sites remains
high. The increasing number of unmanned stations and expansion of non-fuel retail offerings may lead to the differentiation of
service stations into two main groups. Those in busier locations will offer a wide variety of extra services, while low-volume
stations will ultimately convert to unmanned sites. Forecourts operate under a mix of major fuel brands, brands owned by major
fuel producers and/or refiners and hypermarket brands. Diesel is expected to remain the most-sold fuel at Belgium forecourts
underpinned by an increase in the large-scale uptake of commercial fuel cards. Major fuel companies have developed the use


-----

of fuel cards as a marketing tool for the commercial end of the market, each offering the user various value-add services as a
way to differentiate from the fierce competition. After the declines in 2020 and 2021, fuel retail volumes rebounded moderately
in 2022, but are expected to decrease from 2023 driven by the electrification of the car fleet and other incentives to decarbonize
the transport sector. Non-fuel retailing is especially crucial in Belgium, where the fuel price and, effectively, the profit from
the fuel, are limited by the government.

Forecourt retailing is a small part of the grocery & merchandise market in Belgium, accounting for 11.6% of sales in 2022
according to Euromonitor International, and is expected to grow at a compound annual growth rate of 1.9% between 2022 and
2027, whereas the overall grocery & merchandise sector is projected to experience a compound annual growth rate of 2.7%
over the same period, according to Euromonitor International. With respect to foodservice, consumer spending on takeaway
foodservice has decreased as a proportion of overall foodservice spending to 20.5%, down from a high of 29.4% during the
COVID-19 pandemic, but still above pre-COVID-19 pandemic levels of approximately 14%.

_The Netherlands_

The retail fuel market in the Netherlands is highly fragmented and comprises approximately 4,150 sites. Unmanned stations
are a significant feature of the Dutch market, accounting for more than half of retail sites and operating at a price discount
compared to manned stations, increasing competition across the industry. Retail fuel market volumes have declined by a 2.1%
compound annual growth rate between 2018 and 2022, a trend that is expected to continue given improvements in car fuel
efficiency and increased EV adoption. Fuel margins have been traditionally robust, with little or no hypermarket activity in
fuel retailing; however, declining long-term demand and the growing proportion of automated service stations will likely weigh
on future fuel margins.

The total grocery & merchandise market is expected to grow at a 3.4% compound annual growth rate between 2022 and 2027,
according to Euromonitor International. As convenience retailers tend to have higher average unit prices than other grocery
retailers, it is expected that convenience retailers will see a small decline in sales value in 2023, linked to rising inflation. As
such, consumers will look for ways to cut back their spending on groceries, having an impact on the growth of convenience
retailers. However, during the following years, the category is forecast to see modest growth as long terms trends, such as
consumer interest in convenience and on-the-go consumption, will remain relevant and drive sales.

_Italy_

In Italy, there are approximately 21,700 forecourts, resulting in relatively low average fuel volumes sold per site. This is in part
due to structural factors, such as the rugged topography of the country but primarily due to over-supply in the market compared
to other European countries. The number of forecourts in Italy is expected to decline due to rising regulatory requirements and
economic pressure on small, low-volume sites. The discount sector, which typically consists primarily of supermarkets and
hypermarkets, has yet to establish a significant presence in Italy, there has been limited downward pressure on prices than in
other European markets. As a result, automated sites, however, have increased their market penetration but not to such an extent
that might have a material impact on the overall market. If the discount segment becomes further established, it is likely that
we would see further pressures on retail margins and this would force network consolidation as well as the diversification of
non-fuel offerings.

The forecourt grocery & merchandise and foodservice markets in Italy are challenging, comprising only a small percentage of
overall convenience spending. Furthermore, Italian consumers generally prefer full-service dining to foodservice, limiting the
potential size of the market. To this end, takeaway spending represented only 23.6% of consumer foodservice spending in 2022,
as compared to 67.2% spent on eat-in foodservice.

_Germany_

The German retail fuel market consists of roughly 14,450 forecourts and, historically, integrated refiners, including BP and
Shell have had a market-leading position. Fuel retailers have expanded their alternative fuel offerings, supported by government
policy to decarbonize the transport sector. As a result, many players are partnering to operate EV charge points, and the country
has the largest network in Europe of hydrogen refueling stations.

Total oil demand is still recovering from the lows of 2020, and it is expected to reach its post-pandemic peak in 2024, and then
is expected to decline. A switch to alternatively powered vehicles, particularly electric vehicles in the passenger car market,
and increasing fuel efficiency have resulted in a decrease in road fuel demand. Retail fuel margins are expected to remain


-----

relatively low by European standards. As a result, fuel retailers are expected to continue developing non-fuel offerings to
maximize forecourt revenue as demand for liquid fuels declines.

Grocery & merchandise sales in Germany have grown after the COVID-19 pandemic, with growth expected to accelerate from
€12.8 billion in sales in 2022 to €15.2 billion in sales in 2027 (3.4% compound annual growth rate), according to Euromonitor
International, due to the development of more sophisticated convenience retail propositions. The German Foodservice industry
is also expected to deliver a strong compound annual growth rate of 7.3% between 2022 and 2027, with consumer spending on
takeaway offerings representing 22.9% of 2022 foodservice spending.

_The United Kingdom_

In the United Kingdom, there are approximately 8,350 forecourts owned by a combination of supermarkets, independent CStore companies and major fuel producers and/or refiners. Supermarkets such as Tesco, Morrisons, Sainsbury’s and Asda
operate approximately 1,500 sites, with major fuel producers and/or refiners also representing a large proportion of total sites.
The dominance of discounted hypermarket sites, and the emergence of the four large dealer groups, has meant that to remain
competitive, suppliers currently operate a high throughput, low margin just-in-time delivery model. As a result, UK retail fuel
prices remain some of the lowest pre-tax in Europe.

In 2022, forecourt retailers, often located at petrol stations, continued to grow and build upon momentum from increased local
shopping during the COVID-19 pandemic by expanding their offerings. Forecourt convenience sales in the United Kingdom
are forecast to grow at a 4.0% compound annual growth rate between 2022 and 2027, lagging behind the 4.5% expected annual
growth in the overall UK grocery & merchandise market. The grocery & merchandise and foodservice markets had sales of
€47 billion and €69 billion in 2022, respectively, and are projected to grow between 2022 and 2027 at compound annual growth
rates of 4.5% and 5.7%, respectively, according to Euromonitor International.

**_Australia_**

There are currently approximately 7,100 grocery & merchandise outlets in Australia. The number of fuel stations has decreased
dramatically since the 1970s as a result of rationalization. However, the number of sites has stabilized in recent years. The New
South Wales government is developing new mixed communities which need to have access to services, which may create
demand and opportunity for new fuel station site development across the region. Retail fuel volumes increased at a compound
annual growth rate of approximately 4.6% from 2014 to 2019, before decreasing due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Fuel volumes
in 2022 continue to lag behind highs from before the COVID-19 pandemic by approximately 25%, but have increased steadily
year-on-year, growing by 33% between 2021 and 2022.

The Australian grocery & merchandise and foodservice markets have witnessed meaningful growth, with total sales for these
industries in 2022 being €7.7 billion and €35.4 billion, respectively. Furthermore, grocery & merchandise sales are expected
to grow at a compound annual growth rate from 2022 to 2027 of 1.9%, largely expected to result from increasing urbanization,
with time-strapped consumers driving demand for convenience. Meanwhile foodservice sales are expected to grow at a CAGR
of 6.2% over the same timeframe, according to Euromonitor International.

**BUSINESS**

**Overview**

We are a leading independent global convenience retailer that served 1,143 million customers worldwide in the year ended
December 31, 2022. We have a diversified portfolio of 5,937 sites across three continents after giving effect to the Transactions.
Based on our site count, we are the third largest independent convenience retailer chain globally (after giving effect to the
Transactions), the fifth largest in the United States, the second largest in Continental Europe and the second largest in Australia.

Our total fuel volumes sold was 17.7 billion liters for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023 (16.1 billion liters after giving
effect to the Transactions). Our global operations span six of the ten largest fuel markets in Europe by fuel volumes sold,
namely Belgium, France, Germany, Italy, the Netherlands and the United Kingdom, all six states in Australia and 30 states
across the United States. Our Fuel operations are complemented by our Grocery & Merchandise and Foodservice operations,
under which we offer our proprietary brands as well as partner with attractive third-party brands. We seek to deliver a modern
and convenient customer retail experience by providing a “one-stop shop” retail destination that offers a broad range of products
and services to address evolving customer needs. For the twelve months ended June 30, 2023, we generated revenue of $26,203
million and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA before IFRS 16 of $1,147 million, in each case after giving effect to the Pre-Offering
Transactions.

each of these countries (for these purposes, we have aggregated the sites we have in Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg)

**The History and Evolution of Our Business**

The Issa family’s involvement in the petrol filing station and forecourt business began in 2001 when they founded Euro Garages
and subsequently rapidly expanded the business through organic growth and successful acquisitions of businesses and sites
from major fuel producers and/or refiners. Prior to its acquisition of EFR Midco B.V. (“EFR”) in 2016, Euro Garages operated
forecourt sites across the United Kingdom with petrol filling stations under the brand names of its fuel suppliers, Esso, Shell
and BP. In addition, Euro Garages operated Grocery & Merchandise and Foodservice concessions as part of its forecourts and
as standalone sites. EFR, established in 2007 as Delek Europe, was the European fuel retail and marketing assets arm of the
Delek Group. Its name was changed to EFR in February 2015 when it was acquired by TDR Capital. In 2016, Euro Garages
acquired EFR, which was by then a leading independent convenience retailer operator in Continental Europe with over 1,100
sites across Belgium, France, Luxembourg and the Netherlands. Together, Euro Garages and EFR became a pan-European
leader in the convenience retailer sector, initially under the trade name Intervias. In September 2017, the business was rebranded “EG Group.”

Since the acquisition of EFR, our business has evolved to become a global convenience retailer operator, entering new
geographies and consolidating existing markets to increase geographic reach and profitability. As part of our growth strategy,
we have completed a number of selective acquisitions of varying sizes, including multiple large-scale acquisitions, and also
added numerous individual sites to its portfolio through organic growth and NTI sites. More recently, we have also divested a
number of our assets where we found suitable market opportunities to exit on attractive valuations, and have used the proceeds
to pay down our debt and focus on growth and investment in our remaining business.

The UK Disposal to Asda was a transformational step for us. The proceeds from the UK Disposal to Asda, along with the

The UK Disposal to Asda is the cornerstone of our strategy to reduce total net leverage, extend our financing maturities and

as well as for the Non-Core Asset Disposals, and have given pro forma effect to the U.S. Sale and Leaseback.

_Continental Europe_

In 2018, we expanded our presence in Continental Europe through the acquisitions of Esso Italy, Esso Germany and NRG
convenience retailers in the Netherlands. This involved the acquisition of 1,173 Esso PFS sites in Italy in February 2018, 97
NRG convenience retailers in the Netherlands in April 2018 and 1,019 Esso PFS sites in Germany in October 2018.

In January 2021, as a result of the KMS Acquisition, we acquired ten petrol filling stations, six Burger King restaurants and
ten gaming halls in Germany. On June 30, 2021, we completed the acquisition of two existing KFC drive-thru restaurants in
south Germany from Klink Betriebe Gmbh & Co. In January 2022, we acquired M&L Gastronomiegesellschaft GmbH and
Geiger Fast Food GmbH in Germany for consideration of $33 million. The portfolio acquired was made up of seven KFC
stores. On May 1, 2022, we also acquired 285 OMV PFS sites in Germany for consideration of $541 million. These acquisitions
formed part of our growth strategy and enabled us to further expand into the European foodservice market. As per the German
Anti-Trust Authorities’ clearance decision, we agreed to divest 48 sites in order for the OMV Acquisition to proceed, 24 of
which were in our existing estate and 24 in the OMV estate. These divestments were completed in the third quarter of 2022.
As of June 30, 2023, our Continental European portfolio consisted of 3,271 sites, including 3,245 PFS sites, 696 Grocery &
Merchandise outlets and 277 Foodservice outlets.

_United States_

In 2018, we entered the United States, the world’s largest convenience retail market, with the acquisitions of the Kroger
convenience retail locations, which operated in 18 U.S. states, and Minit Mart, through which we expanded into five additional


-----

U.S. states. The Kroger acquisition, completed in April 2018, added 762 convenience retail locations to our portfolio, while
the Minit Mart acquisition, completed in December 2018, added an additional 235 convenience retail locations to our portfolio.

In addition, we further expanded our presence in the United States by completing the acquisitions of Fastrac in July 2019,
which added 54 sites to our portfolio, and Certified Oil in August 2019, which added an additional 70 sites to our portfolio.
Furthermore, in October 2019, we completed the acquisition of Cumberland Farms, which added 568 convenience retail
locations to our portfolio and was a significant leap forward in strengthening our presence in the United States.

Through our acquisition of Cumberland Farms, were able to build upon their successful model for their non-fuel offering,
through which they offer high-quality local and national brands as well as a broad range of higher margin private label and
fresh food products. Cumberland Farms’ stores measure approximately 3,500 square feet on average. This sizeable retail space
allows Cumberland Farms to offer a wider variety of private label and fresh food products alongside a comprehensive selection
of third-party branded products, increasing revenue and profit per site. The Cumberland Farms’ acquisition was also in line
with our strategic focus on Grocery & Merchandise and Foodservice, and the geographical proximity of its operations to our
other U.S. convenience retail locations in the northeastern United States and Florida created enhanced opportunities for
synergies, helping accelerate our efforts to roll-out of this model across our U.S. site network.

In December 2020, we completed the Schrader Oil acquisition through which we acquired assets from Schrader Oil at 18
company-operated fuel and convenience retail locations in Colorado and rolled them under the Loaf ‘N Jug banner. In June
2021, we completed the Mercury Acquisition through which we acquired assets from Mercury at eight leased locations in
Connecticut. In December 2021, we completed the Sprint Acquisition through which we acquired 34 company-operated fuel
and convenience retail locations in Georgia and South Carolina and the proprietary ‘Sprint Kitchen’ Foodservice brand.

More recently in May 2023, as part of our efforts to rationalize our portfolio and optimize our capital structure, we entered into
an agreement for the sale and leaseback of a portfolio of 414 sites across Cumberland Farms, Fastrac, Tom Thumb and Sprint
banners in the United States through our U.S. Sale and Leaseback, for which we received gross proceeds of $1.5 billion. See
“Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—The U.S. Sale and Leaseback Transaction.” In addition, in April 2023, we
completed the sale of 26 non-core company operated Minit Mart locations in Missouri and Kansas for net proceeds of $48
million. Furthermore, in August 2023, we announced our agreement to sell a further 63 convenience retail locations in Kentucky
and Tennessee to Casey’s General Stores, Inc., of which the sale of 55 sites was completed in November 2023 for net proceeds
of $84.4 million.

As of June 30, 2023, after giving effect to the Transactions, our portfolio in the United States consisted of 1,582 sites, including
1,508 PFS sites, 1,514 Grocery & Merchandise outlets and 311 Foodservice outlets.

_Australia_

In April 2019, we expanded our footprint to Australia through the completion of the FuelCo Acquisition, through which we
became one of Australia’s largest independent fuel retailer by fuel volume and are now the second largest by site count as a
result of acquiring Woolworths Group’s convenience retail locations. We continue to consolidate our presence in Australia and
over the last year have completed the rebranding of all our sites to EG from Woolworths, with respect to the banners above
stores, and to Ampol from Caltex, with respect to fuel-branding on all site canopy and site pylons.

As of June 30, 2023, our portfolio in Australia consisted of 525 sites, with each of our sites including a PFS site and a Grocery
& Merchandise store.

**Our Strengths**

We believe the following strengths have contributed to our success.

**Leading independent global convenience retailer with diversification and scale across key geographies, products and**
**services**

We are a leading global independent convenience retailer with a diversified portfolio of sites across ten countries in three
continents, which consists of 5,937 sites after giving effect to the Transactions. We are the third largest independent
convenience retailer chain globally based on site count (after giving effect to the Transactions) and we sold approximately 17.7
billion liters of fuel for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023 (approximately 16.1 billion liters after giving effect to the
Transactions). We believe that our scale and diversification across leading regions and markets improves our resilience and
allows us to maintain profitability through varying business cycles in different geographies.

In the United States, we have an established presence across 30 states and we are the fifth largest independent convenience
retailer operating based on site count. In Europe, we are the second largest independent convenience retailer based on site count
with operations in six of the ten largest national fuel markets by volume. In each of these markets, we are among the three
largest independent retailers by site count. We are also the second largest independent convenience retailer by site numbers in
Australia.

We believe that our diversified footprint reduces our exposure to the economic, political and weather-related risks of any single
country, providing us with balanced exposure to multiple national economies with different economic cycles and
macroeconomic fundamentals. Our geographic diversification is shown in the following chart, which sets forth our gross profit

We believe that a core advantage of our scale and diversification across geographies is that it allows us to apply our operating
model and processes across our global portfolio to drive individual site and corporate revenue and profitability. We benefit
from cost efficiencies and shared best practices resulting from our large global network, which allows us to realize significant
economies of scale, including favorable procurement terms, lower above-site costs as a percentage of sales and favorable
working capital levels. For example, we minimize our operating expenses and maximize our operations controls through lean
and efficient above-site management at our shared service center, which manages the procurement, finance, human resources,
fuel pricing, commercial, IT, legal and real estate functions across our entire European network. For instance, we use the
Fairbanks fuel management system to keep track of volume at our pumps across our network and have dedicated fuel pricing
teams to monitor data and set fuel prices across our network. In addition, our leading global and local market positions and our
flexible operating model position us as an attractive partner to popular Grocery & Merchandise and Foodservice brands, which
in turn tends to attract increasing customer traffic to our network.

**Resilient financial performance and robust profits from core business**

We believe we have achieved strong and resilient financial performance through a combination of organic growth, strategic
acquisitions and a focus on maximizing synergies from acquisitions through rapid integration of the acquired assets into our
platform. Our geographic spread and diversification by product has also increased our financial resilience and performance in
different market conditions.

After giving effect to the Pre-Offering Transactions, our gross profit and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA before IFRS 16 for the
twelve months ended June 30, 2023 were $3.8 billion and $1,147 million, respectively. For the full year to December 31, 2022,
our historical gross profit rose by 6% year-on-year to $4.4 billion, supported by the performance of all our three business
streams – Grocery & Merchandise, Foodservice and Fuel – whereas Adjusted EBITDA before IFRS 16 decreased by 5% to
$1.4 billion. Below is a breakdown of our gross profit and Adjusted EBITDA before IFRS 16 by geographic region (in each
case, after giving effect to the Pre-Offering Transactions and deducting shared service costs):

  - In the United States, for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023, our gross profit was $1,841 million and our Adjusted
EBITDA before IFRS 16 was $465 million. In comparison, our gross profit was $1,850 million and our Adjusted
EBITDA before IFRS 16 was $488 million for the year ended December 31, 2022.

  - In Europe, for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023, our gross profit was $1,582 million and our Adjusted EBITDA
before IFRS 16 was $378 million. In comparison, our gross profit was $1,567 million and our Adjusted EBITDA
before IFRS 16 was $425 million for the year ended December 31, 2022.

  - In Australia, for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023, our gross profit was $400 million and our Adjusted EBITDA
before IFRS 16 was $124 million. In comparison, our gross profit was $414 million and our Adjusted EBITDA before
IFRS 16 was $132 million for the year ended December 31, 2022.

Fuel prices at the pump can experience some volatility depending on macroeconomic factors, such as inflation and global oil
prices, and this occasionally causes short-term fluctuations in the gross margin we generate per liter of fuel volume sold. Our
long-term gross margin for fuel has been consistently increasing over time, offsetting the impact of decreasing fuel volumes,
the inflation-linked increases in site operating costs and the extreme oil volatility seen in 2022 driven by the Russian invasion
of Ukraine. High margin Grocery & Merchandise and Foodservice operations tend to contribute to increasing customer traffic
to our sites, supporting sales volume and margin expansion and diversifying our profits away from fuel operations.

Our business is highly cash generative and we benefit from limited working capital requirements, with a strong as pro forma
adjusted cash conversion ratio of 83% for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023 after giving effect to the Pre-Offering
Transactions. Our typically well invested sites require only limited maintenance capital expenditure, which amounted to $127
million for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023.

We believe that our resilience was demonstrated during the COVID-19 pandemic. As our operating countries experienced
lockdown restrictions at different times, we kept operations running in the remaining locations and applied what we had learned
at the affected sites across our network by sharing best practices. We believe this softened the aggregate financial impact of the
COVID-19 pandemic on the Group as a whole and strengthened our ability to adapt to the developing stages of the pandemic.

**Established business models with high percentage of stores owned and operated business by the Group**

Our operating business model has powered the growth of our site network from a single UK site in 2001 to 5,937 sites across
three continents and ten countries (after giving effect to the Transactions). Our growth journey has been facilitated by our
acquisitions and our new-to-industry (“NTI”) opening program. A significant proportion of our sites are company owned and
company operated (“COCO”), which is our preferred model in most countries, and our sites are typically larger than the average
site size in most of the markets in which we operate, allowing us to generate greater revenue per site. The table below shows
how the average annual volume of fuel sold at one of our sites compares to the average for the relevant region.

We have a dynamic approach to managing our site estate, whereby we can achieve growth in the number of sites we operate
through acquisitions – although we anticipate being highly selective and strategic with respect to these in the near term – or the
development of NTI sites. In addition to growing our site numbers, we continuously look to upgrade the quality of our estate
through knock-down-rebuilds (“KDRs,” known as ‘raze-and-rebuilds’ in the United States) site conversions and refreshes, and
to dispose certain sites to align our network with our strategic priorities.

We have a mix of COCO, company-owned, not company-operated (“CONCO”), and third party owned and operated sites. Our
different models result in different levels of revenue generation and require different levels of capital expenditure.

Our operating models can be described in more detail as follows:

  - COCO operations are directly managed by us and for these we control all aspects of the performance and maintenance
of the site. The COCO model is our preferred operating model in most countries. Through this model, we have an
opportunity to control important factors that have a direct impact on the customer experience and profitability of each
site, such as site layout and quality, better customer service, product and service offering selection, fuel and non-fuel
pricing policies, staff scheduling and cost control. The COCO model is usually more profitable than our other
operating models, as it allows us to capture full profit margins at any given site.

  - At CONCO sites, the dealer, franchisee or third party retailer is responsible for all non-fuel operations, as well as the
operating costs associated with the management of the site, whereas we remain responsible for any capital and
maintenance costs associated with the fuel equipment, and in some instances we have a consignment arrangement for
fuel sales and inventory.


-----

  - Other sites are owned and operated by a third party who has full responsibility for the performance and maintenance
of the site. We either have a fuel supply arrangement in place with the third party, or, alternatively, the fuel supply is
on a consignment basis.

We have a track record of performance improvement through the conversion of sites to COCO to benefit from greater control
of operations, with EG assuming responsibility for all employees on site. While this model means we incur the full cost base
of the site, with COCO we benefit from the site’s full margin potential with little to no conversion costs typically incurred. We
currently plan to focus on our sites in Germany and Italy for COCO conversions. At the same time, our ability to use different
operating models provides us with flexibility to tailor our approach to the requirements of each specific site, expand our nonfuel offerings, and to adjust our capital expenditure and other costs accordingly.

**Attractive fuel and non-fuel offerings underpinned by long term relationships with key brands**

A majority of our sites have branded retail “one-stop” backcourts that seek to satisfy the multiple needs of our customers. In
addition to fuel, these sites offer a wide range of food and non-food products specifically tailored to address the everyday
household needs and preferences of its local customers.

We continuously review our brand portfolio and evaluate opportunities to partner with additional leading Fuel, Grocery &
Merchandise and Foodservice brands. Our offering is further complemented by a portfolio of our own brands, including
Cooplands, the UK’s second largest bakery business, Go Fresh, which is present mainly in the Benelux region, and Cumberland
Farms, Fastrac, Certified Oil, Sprint, Kwik Shop, Loaf ‘N Jug, Quik Stop, Tom Thumb, Turkey Hill and Minit Mart, which are
present in the United States.

The Cumberland Farms brand in particular is central to our US strategy, since its brand value is underpinned by the sizable
retail space available at most Cumberland Farms sites. Also, its large warehouse and distribution facilities are in close proximity
to our other US sites providing opportunities to grow this brand. Following the Cumberland Farms Acquisition in October
2019, we have been able to leverage Cumberland Farms’ food production capability and private label brands, including its
Farmhouse Kitchen brand, to expand our capacity to offer our customers competitively priced alternatives to global and regional
brands, increasing the attractiveness and variety of our fresh food offerings and providing us with a greater number of products
that are exclusively available from our stores to further differentiate us from our competitors. As part of our efforts to leverage
this brand, we took the decision at the end of 2021 to commence a rebranding program of a number of sites in the United States
from our Tom Thumb brand to our Cumberland Farms brand, with 26 being completed during 2022 and an additional five in
the six months ended June 30, 2023.


-----

We proactively engage and work with well-known regional and global retail brand partners to deliver Fuel, Grocery &
Merchandise and Foodservice offerings that satisfy our customers’ evolving expectations. Brands are deployed on a site-bysite basis through a selection process driven, in part, by local and regional tastes and preferences. As a result of the scale and
quality of our network and our strong track record as convenience store operators, we are able to attract well-recognized global
and regional brands to partner with us. For instance, we partner with Fuel brands such as Esso, BP, Shell, Texaco and Ampol,
well-known Grocery & Merchandise brands such as SPAR, Carrefour and Louis Delhaize, and globally recognized Foodservice
brands such as Starbucks, KFC, Burger King and Subway, as well as strong local foodservice brands such as Greggs and
Pomme de Pain. We continue to strengthen our brand partnerships with our Foodservice brand partners with 102 new sites
opening in the year ended December 31, 2022, a demonstration of our commitment to expand the brand offerings.

As direct operators of the third-party branded stores, outlets and concessions located at our sites, we act as brand ambassadors
for our partners, which we believe reflects the trust our partners have in our operational capabilities. We believe these valuable
and well-known brands increase customer confidence in our products and services, leading to higher customer traffic and sales
