**High quality real estate portfolio**

Our retail network consists of 5,937 sites after giving effect to the Transactions across the globe, many of which are strategically
located in high traffic areas. These include 3,719 company-owned sites after giving effect to the Transactions, comprising
freehold sites, leasehold sites, as well as sites that are partially freehold and partially leasehold and concession sites. Our


-----

concession sites give us the right to develop these sites according to the terms of the development proposal we provided to the
respective seller during the open bid process.

A large proportion of our real estate portfolio in the United States and Europe consists of freehold or long leasehold sites. As
of June 30, 2023, after giving effect to the Transactions, 30% of our property portfolio based on the number of sites was
freehold, comprising 1,795 sites, 56% of our property portfolio based on the number of sites was leasehold (including long
leasehold), comprising 3,342 sites, 1% of our portfolio based on the number of sites was a hybrid of freehold and leasehold,
comprising 68 sites, 9% of our portfolio consisted of third-party sites, comprising 545 sites, and 3% of our portfolio based on
the number of sites was concessions, comprising 187 sites. While the value of our real estate portfolio fluctuates depending on
market conditions and other factors (see “Risk Factors—Ownership and leasing of a broad portfolio of real estate exposes us
_to potential losses and, liabilities and fluctuations in market price”), we believe that our global real estate footprint including_
a large number of freehold and long leasehold sites provide us with long term stability. Despite current market conditions and
the interest rate environment leading to depressed valuations for commercial real estate across Europe and the United States,
we still have significant real estate value underpinning our business. According to the Real Estate Reports, based on current
interest rate levels and market conditions, the aggregated sales price of our properties (after giving effect to the Transactions)
is more than $4.0 billion (equivalent) on the basis that they are fully equipped operational entities and taking into account their
trading potential and EBITDA generation. See “Business—Property—Real Estate Reports.”

The quality of our estate is also complemented by our portfolio of 263 highway and highway-like sites in Europe (including
seven in the United Kingdom after giving effect to the Pre-Offering Transactions). Our highway sites tend to have higher fuel
margins and include Grocery & Merchandise and Foodservice offerings. Most of our highway sites operate under our COCO
model, allowing us to benefit from the full margin on Fuel, Grocery & Merchandise and Foodservice offerings.

Our valuable real estate portfolio also provides a potential source of liquidity. Over the last few months we have been able to,
and in the future may continue to, selectively monetize portions of our real estate portfolio to take advantage of favorable
trading conditions and pursue our strategic priorities, including deleveraging on attractive terms. See “—Our Strategies—
_Rationalization of portfolio and focus on robust capital structure.”_

**Strong management team led by our co-founders**

We have an experienced and dedicated management team focused on sustainable and profitable growth for our business, with
a number of team members having over 25 years of experience with the Group or in the industry. Our global managers include
our visionary founders and co-CEOs, Zuber Issa and Mohsin Issa, who both have extensive expertise in the convenience retail
sector. Following the Issa family’s acquisition of their first site in 2001, they have led the business to become one of the leading
global independent convenience store operators. We believe that the entrepreneurial spirit of our management team creates a
culture focused on long-term, profitable growth and cash generation.

As disclosed in “Recent Developments,” upon completion of the potential sale to Zuber Issa of the majority of the Retained
UK&I Business, he intends to step down as Co-CEO, remaining on our Board as non-executive director. Mohsin Issa would
then become our sole CEO and would continue leading our strategy going forward, supported by our strong senior management
team responsible for day-to-day operations, including John Carey, President and CEO of EG America, Imraan Patel, Chief
Strategy and Business Officer and Michael Bradley, Chief Financial Officer. John Carey was appointed President and CEO of
EG America with effect from October 1, 2023, with a mandate to drive forward our growth strategy in the United States, our
largest market by both revenue and sites.

Our decentralized management structure is composed of seven country or regional managers, each with extensive industry
experience. They are responsible for day-to-day operations in Australia, the Benelux region, France, Germany, Italy, the United
Kingdom and Ireland and the United States. The Nomination Committee of our Board ensures a robust leadership talent pipeline
and succession plans for the Board and senior management are in place, taking account of risk areas, gender and diversity.

**Our Strategies**

Our strategy is to continue our disciplined approach to growing our market share, enhancing our profitability, ensuring that our
business is run sustainably and generating robust cash flows to drive further deleveraging and investment.

**Focus on growing our market share and optimizing our existing operations and asset base**

We aim to continue to optimize our operations to ensure that we are deriving maximum value and market share from our
existing asset base. We aim to achieve this through organic growth, developing NTI sites in strategic locations and redeveloping
certain sites as part of our KDR program, as well as through continuing to extract synergies from past acquisitions and, where


-----

an attractive opportunity presents itself, undertaking strategic acquisitions or divestments and realizing value from our real
estate portfolio on a disciplined basis. The map below shows our current global footprint (after giving effect to the
Transactions).

United States

In the United States, we operate across 30 states and are the fifth largest independent convenience retailer in the country, with
a scaled coast-to-coast national footprint and various avenues for additional growth.

We believe the U.S. market provides a significant opportunity to focus on our operating initiatives, strengthen our core business
and drive sustainable growth. Going forward, we believe it could provide a blueprint for our global initiatives to improve
performance while minimizing capital spend to support our financial policy goals, focusing on the following value propositions:

  - Winning Offer: Expand offerings with a focus on dispensed beverage, food and margin enhancing private label while
maintaining a hyper-localized approach to enhance the customer experience.

  - Winning Fuel: Drive volume growth through investment in growing segments (diesel/ B2B) while maintaining the
Group’s focus on a premium offering to maximize margin.

  - Winning Customer: Engage with our active customer base through an enhanced omnichannel experience with a focus
on loyalty.

  - Winning Efficiency: Continue to focus on our expansive cost reduction measures to drive enhanced profitability.

A key aspect of our U.S. strategy is to capitalize on the brand equity of Cumberland Farms, which we plan to do through store
rebranding initiatives as well as expanding Cumberland Farms’ well-developed private label offerings and food production
capacities. As part of these efforts, we have already commenced rebranding a number of our sites in the United States from our
Tom Thumb brand to our Cumberland Farms brand, with 26 such rebrandings being completed during 2022 and an additional
five being completed in the six months ended June 30, 2023. In addition, we believe there are opportunities to increase the
Grocery & Merchandise and Foodservice contribution from our sites through actions such as price book optimization and
reduction of product waste.

We plan to increase our Foodservice offerings in the United States, which accounted for only 3% of our gross profit in the
region for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023. We aim do this both by expanding our proprietary brands as well as
leveraging our existing partnerships with established third-party brands. We also plan to expand our SmartPay mobile
application, as well as deploy our proprietary brands, throughout our non-Cumberland Farms estate. The SmartPay program is


-----

a mobile application which allows us to offer and promote lower retail prices to SmartPay users in a targeted manner through
payment programs and marketing and customer savings promotions. Launched in 2013, this program has already reached $6
billion in fuel sales and saved members more than $200 million, and we believe it has significant potential for further growth.
In addition, we opened 13 NTI sites in the United States during 2022, while a further two NTI sites opened this year.

Europe (Continental Europe and United Kingdom and Ireland)

We are the second largest independent fuel and convenience store business in Continental Europe, with a strong presence in
key markets and a significant opportunity for additional growth.

A key part of our European strategy is to invest in our Foodservice and non-fuel offerings in the region. Our efforts to achieve
this include a rollout of well recognized Foodservice brands and outlets across Continental Europe, with 277 such outlets open
as of June 30, 2023. Our growth strategy has historically also included pursuing inorganic growth when the appropriate
opportunity presents itself. For instance, we completed the acquisition of OMV’s German forecourt business, consisting of 285
sites in southern Germany on May 1, 2022, of which 24 were divested as part of obtaining regulatory approval for the
transaction (in addition to 24 of our existing German sites). While we intend to remain disciplined and focused on reducing net
leverage, we continue to follow a disciplined approach to acquisition opportunities both in existing markets as well as potential
new ones, with a focus on driving competency, capability, scale and balance sheet efficiencies. We also continued our
expansion in Europe through additional NTI sites, with three such sites opening in 2022 and a further four so far this year.

In addition, we recognize the accelerating shift towards alternatively fueled vehicles in Europe and the rest of the world and
plan to accelerate the roll-out of ‘evpoint,’ our proprietary electric vehicle charging proposition throughout Europe. We had
470 EV chargers across the United Kingdom and Continental Europe at the end of 2022 and have added a further 192 chargers
as of June 30, 2023.

Our European estate also represents the highest proportion of CONCO sites, with 2,202 dealer, franchisee or retailer operated
sites at the end of 2022, largely across Italy and Germany. A key part of our growth strategy for Continental Europe is to review
and identify dealer‑operated sites which we can convert to our preferred COCO model. During 2022, 52 conversions took place
and a further 20 took place in the six months ended June 30, 2023. We typically incur little to no costs in connection with
COCO conversions, unless we decide to convert CONCO sites to COCO sites before our contracts with the relevant dealers,
franchisees and retailers expire, in which case we may need to pay early termination fees.

Australia

We are the second largest independent convenience store retailer by site numbers in Australia and aim to further consolidate
our presence in the region.

Our 525 COCO sites in Australia already include Fuel and Grocery & Merchandise offerings, however, we have been
transforming the network through continued upgrades and rebranding. In 2022, we opened seven NTI stores and have eight
sites currently under construction. We also recently rebranded from Woolworths to EG in our Grocery & Merchandise stores
and from Caltex to Ampol for Fuel.

We are focused on expanding our offers to our customers in Australia and have launched a delivery service across our network
with our delivery partners such as UBER, Menulog and DoorDash. These partnerships have allowed us to expand our Grocery
& Merchandise online offers to include virtual stores under brands such as Eats2U, Olivers and Ben & Jerry’s. We have also
expanded our B2B partnerships and have entered into partnerships with motoring associations and large consumer
organizations such as electricity providers. Through these partnerships, we provide targeted online fuel offers to these
organizations.

**Enhance Foodservice offerings and continue to grow, invest in and realize identified synergies from proprietary**
**Foodservice brands**

An increasingly important part of our strategy is the development of our Foodservice business, especially in light of the secular
growth this sector is expected to experience over the next few years, driven by changing lifestyles and consumer preferences.
Our scaled, global footprint across the Foodservice market, driven by our strong international brand partnerships and strategic
acquisitions, provides us with a strong platform from which to capitalize on this growth trend.

We have been successfully operating Foodservice outlets for over a decade and we are a partner of choice for many leading
third‑party brands. Across the Group, we will continue to operate 1,201 Foodservice outlets after giving effect to the
Transactions. We believe that there is significant scope to further expand our Foodservice business, especially since


-----

Foodservice offerings on a backcourt platform remain underdeveloped across most countries in which we operate in terms of
the quality and choice provided at most outlets. We are strongly positioned to fill this gap since we are already a significant
operator of scale of Foodservice sites and have established a position as a leading franchisee for our brand partners. In recent
years, our expanded Foodservice operations have transformed our sites into destinations serving multiple customer needs,
which supports an increase in customer traffic and sales volumes, and we intend to replicate this across selected sites across
the Group. This is reflected in the recent growth of our Foodservice gross profit, which for 2022 was $705 million compared
to $614 million in 2021, a year-on-year increase of 15%, and for the six months ended June 30, 2023 was $389 million, an
increase of 10% from the six months ended June 30, 2022.

We have made continued investment in Foodservice outlets globally with a total of 102 new outlets opening in the year ended
December 31, 2022. At the same time, we have continued to invest in and grow our proprietary Foodservice brand network.

**Pursue a multi-pronged strategy for energy transition**

As the world transitions to a lower carbon future, and the demand for electric vehicles is expected to increase, we believe the
long-term trend towards electrification of vehicles presents a significant opportunity for us, and one which we are wellpositioned to capitalize on given the site network we already own. We have a multi-pronged strategy to provide EV charging
stations (also referred to herein as charge points, charging points or chargers) and alternative fuels across our platform and a
key aspect of this plan is our electric vehicle charging point strategy, in particular ‘evpoint’ – our proprietary branded, ultrafast electric vehicle charging proposition.

We believe ‘evpoint’ has the potential to become one of Europe’s leading charge point operators. Our flagship location at
Frontier Park in Blackburn, United Kingdom, the home of six ultra-fast chargers, opened in August 2022. We already installed
‘evpoint’ ultra-fast chargers at over 20 trial sites across the United Kingdom and Continental Europe in 2022 and a further 33
sites in the first half of 2023. We have also earmarked a broader rollout across hundreds of our sites through to 2026. The
Retained UK&I Business will include all of our EV chargers in the United Kingdom following the UK Disposal to Asda. With
between two and six charging points per site, and innovations in charging hardware, including load-balancing technology means
several customers can use a single location simultaneously.

In the United States, our strategy has been to partner with leading third-party charge point operators on EV charge points. These
partnerships allow us to leverage our network and reach but minimize the need for deploying our own capital. As such, our EV
charge points in the United States will have third party branding, compared to our EV charge points in Europe that will primarily
have our own branding. We currently do not have any near-term plans for an EV charger roll-out in Australia, but continue to
review our strategy in this area.

We have continued our rollout of EV chargers across the United Kingdom and some sites in Continental Europe. While we
will divest most of our roadside locations in the United Kingdom when we complete the UK Disposal to Asda, we have
deliberately retained 31 well-developed sites in the UK to maintain our presence in this mature, attractive and innovative market
and to use our residual footprint there as a platform to test, adapt and fine-tune our European EV charger offering as well as
the introduction of other developing applications.

As of June 30, 2023, we operate 635 electric charging points (compared to just 250 in 2021 and 470 as of December 31, 2022)
across 189 sites in the United Kingdom and Continental Europe and have identified hundreds of additional sites that, due to
their locations and nature, are suitable for additional electric charging points as part of the next wave of site developments
through to 2026. We plan to continue our rollout of EV chargers during the remainder of 2023, with a further 60 electric
charging points operating by the end of the year, a majority of which will be ultra-fast chargers. We believe one of our key
strengths in the EV charging point market lies in our expansive forecourt footprint. For many of our competitors, their key
challenges and costs include finding suitable and cost-efficient locations on which to install EV chargers. However, our
forecourts provide us access to locations, and we plan to make continued, efficient investments in this space in order to roll out
further electric charging points. The performance of our trial EV chargers has provided us comfort that the profit margins
achievable on the sale of energy through EV chargers provide a strong business case for a broader roll out. To support this
vision, we are working with other market participants for the deployment of infrastructure and services to support energy
transition demand across our network. See “Business—Our Additional Operations—Electric Vehicle Charging Stations and
_Alternative Fuels.”_

We believe our EV charging stations create a ‘halo effect’ by driving increased customer footfall to their locations. Our chargers
are concentrated at locations that have fulsome Grocery & Merchandise and Foodservice offerings, and we have found that the
presence of electric charging stations helps drive increased customer footfall for such other offerings as well, since customers
will typically spend time at the forecourt while their vehicle is being charged. This increases the implied profit margin of our
electric charging stations, and we believe this provides us with an advantage over standalone electric charge point providers


-----

that do not have the advantage of our large and well-developed forecourt network. Similarly, we also find that our EV chargers
that are on well-developed forecourts benefit from higher utilization, since customers who visit the forecourt using electric
vehicles will often use that time to top-up their charge. We expect to continue to benefit from this virtuous cycle following the
UK Disposal to Asda as we have agreed to enter into a right to occupation arrangement with Asda that would allow us to
continue to use the forecourts being sold for our existing EV chargers and to have the right to deploy additional EV chargers
on any Asda sites (including standalone forecourt sites and Asda supermarkets) in the future, including but not limited to CStore sites sold pursuant to the UK Disposal to Asda. In addition to providing this ‘halo effect’ and higher profit margins than
traditional fuel products, EV chargers also assist with our working capital management by reducing our need for liquid fuel
inventory.

We are conscious that alternative forms of power, other than electric, are being explored as a means to fuel cars, light vehicles
and trucks. Beyond EV chargers, we are also actively considering how compressed natural gas (“CNG”), liquefied petroleum
gas (“LPG”) and hydrogen may form part of a broader strategic program of retail fuels at our sites to sit alongside traditional
transport fuels, with a particular focus on the potential for hydrogen to power light and heavy-duty vehicles. See “Business—
_Our Additional Operations—Electric Vehicle Charging Stations and Alternative Fuels— Alternative Fuels.”_ In addition, we
are also exploring ways to reduce our carbon footprint through our energy usage. We have already switched to renewable
electricity at a number of sites across the UK and Continental Europe, including all our sites in Luxembourg. Additionally, all
of our ‘evpoint’ branded chargers sell electricity only generated from renewable energy sources. We install solar panels
wherever feasible at NTI and KDR sites, including petrol filling stations and all suitable Foodservice sites, as well as our UK
head office. Thus far in 2023, we have generated more than 1,808,992 kWhs of electricity using solar panels. We also continue
to explore battery storage with the aim of securing self-generated electricity, and in early 2023 we installed our first battery
storage unit at our head office in the United Kingdom. Our EV chargers also generate carbon credits for us which we are
currently in the process of obtaining certification for, following which we may be able to monetize our carbon credits as we
grow our EV charging station network.

**Rationalization of portfolio and focus on strong capital structure**

During 2023, we have undertaken a number of major steps towards deleveraging and addressing our debt maturities. In May
2023, we completed the sale and leaseback of a portfolio of our US assets, comprising 414 sites across our Cumberland Farms,
Fastrac, Tom Thumb and Sprint brands, with gross proceeds of $1.5 billion (the “U.S. Sale and Leaseback”) and we announced
the UK Disposal to Asda for consideration of £2 billion, which was completed on October 31, 2023. In addition, we also
completed or announced a number of smaller transactions, comprising (i) the disposal of 26 company operated Minit Mart
locations in the Missouri and Kansas resulting in net proceeds of $43 million in April 2023 and (ii) the sale of 55 company
operated Minit Mart locations in Kentucky and Northern Tennessee with net proceeds of $84.4 million. The net proceeds from
the UK Disposal to Asda, the Amend and Extend, the U.S. Sale and Leaseback and the Non-Core Minit Mart Disposal (Missouri
and Kansas) are being used to repay our existing senior secured debt, contributing to a total gross debt reduction of $3,816
million since June 30, 2023.

In June 2023, we successfully undertook an amendment and extension process to extend the maturities of $3,169 million of
euro, dollar and sterling denominated term loan facilities to 2028 under our Senior Credit Facilities Agreement (the “Amend
and Extend”), which will take effect on the Conditions Satisfaction Date (as defined herein). See “Description of Certain
_Financing Arrangements—Senior Credit Facilities Agreement.” As a result of this activity and our other efforts, we expect to_
reduce total net leverage from 6.3x for the year ended December 31, 2022 to 5.1x after the completion of this Offering and
giving effect to the use of proceeds contemplated herein. See “Capitalization” and “Summary Consolidated Historical and As
_Adjusted Financial Information and Other Data—Other Financial and Operating Data.” We remain committed to achieving_
and maintaining a net leverage multiple in the mid 4x range in the near- to medium-term, which we aim to achieve through
organic growth in earnings and free cash flow generation and through working capital initiatives and reduced discretionary
growth capital expenditures.

After giving effect to the Transactions, we will have third party debt of $229 million maturing in February 2025, $71 million
maturing in March 2026, $671 million maturing in April 2027, $3,662 million maturing in February 2028 and a further $1,589
million maturing in November 2028.

We believe that our diversified business and robust asset base put us in a strong position to access multiple pools of liquidity
to help reduce the overall quantum of our debt. For example, in order to manage our debt quantum and capital structure we
may consider releasing value from our owned real estate, potential asset sales, and/or third-party minority equity funding for
emerging businesses or concepts such as ‘evpoint’, in addition to relying on a disciplined approach to capital expenditure,
organic growth and free cashflow generation. We believe that we continue to have multiple potential levers to support our


-----

deleveraging objective and we will continue to consider these on a selective basis where we believe they make financial sense
and align with our strategic vision.

**Continued investment in, and review of, our site network**

As an entrepreneurial business, we are always looking to drive growth by investing in our site network and developing our
retail offerings. We aim to continue to capitalize on opportunities to grow, although, especially in the current environment, we
plan to do so through a disciplined approach that is in line with our financial policy.

A key pillar of our organic growth plans is growing our footprint through the building and operation of NTI sites, which provide
us with greater ability to apply our preferred multi-format operating platform offering Grocery & Merchandise, Foodservice
and Fuel (including lower-carbon fuels) products. These NTI sites are typically larger than our existing sites and often quickly
develop into some of our best-performing sites. In line with this strategy, we opened 31 NTI sites in 2022 (compared to 30 in
2021), out of which 13 were opened in the United States, eight in the United Kingdom and Ireland (of which seven will be sold
pursuant to the UK Disposal to Asda), seven in Australia and three in continental Europe. In the six months ended June 30,
2023, we have completed the opening of another seven NTI sites, out of which two opened in the US, one in the Disposed UK
Business and four in Continental Europe. Since June 30, 2023, we have opened another six NTI sites and are currently working
on bringing another forty-two to market. We have continued to grow our land bank to support future new site openings, which
we expect will support our roll-out of additional NTI sites across all of our regions.

In addition, we aim to continue to examine our site network, looking for opportunities to re-invigorate sites through KDRs and
through expansion of our offerings through either extension to existing buildings or through the purchase of adjacent land and
construction of new facilities. Our decision to undertake a KDR depends upon a variety of factors, including potential traffic
flow and customer footfall, the ability to set up or increase our Grocery & Merchandise and Foodservice offerings, the existence
of local competitors and local amenities and the site’s potential profitability. Although our plan is to focus more on organic
growth and become increasingly selective when we consider inorganic growth opportunities, we aim to continue assessing
strategic acquisition opportunities when the appropriate business proposition presents itself. When we review acquisition
targets, we look for a strategically well-located portfolio of sites and real estate of good quality, generally underpinned by
freehold value irrespective of geography.

During 2022, we completed the acquisition of OMV’s high‑quality German forecourt business, consisting of 285 sites in
Southern Germany, for a consideration of €495 million ($541 million). On a smaller scale, we also completed a KFC acquisition
in Germany, which enhanced our growing Foodservice business by providing seven additional sites, for €27 million ($33
million). For a full list of our acquisitions since 2021, see “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and
_Results of Operations—Factors Affecting Comparability of Our Financial Statements—Acquisitions and Disposals.” We_
believe we can add additional value to such sites by leveraging our supply chain network and expertise, expanding brand
partnerships in both fuel and non-fuel operations and introducing our proprietary brands where appropriate, and generating
economies by leveraging EG Group’s advantageous commercial arrangements and negotiating strength.

**Our Operations**

We have developed our market positions in these regions by, among other things, relying on our extensive site network, diverse
offering portfolio, partnerships, flexible operating models, experienced management team and multinational regulatory
expertise and operational capabilities.

**_Our Products and Services_**

We provide three primary categories of products and services: Fuel, Grocery & Merchandise and Foodservice. We operate
primarily through partnerships with well-known brands across our product and service offerings. We also offer our own-brand
Fuel, Grocery & Merchandise and Foodservice products and services at several of our sites, and plan to explore ways to further
expand our offerings.

In addition, we provide certain ancillary products and services, which we believe represent attractive cross-selling
opportunities, complement our main business activities and allow us to further diversify our sources of revenue. These products
and services include car washes, lottery ticket sales, ATMs, hotels, restaurants, in-store and outdoor click-and-collect lockers
and video games.

**_Our Management Structure_**

Our management structure combines the expertise of our senior management team, comprising our global and country
managers, with the day-to-day support of our local management team.

Our senior management team includes our co-founders and co-CEOs, Zuber Vali Issa and Mohsin Issa, and it oversees the
overall operations, business model and strategies of the Group. In addition, our senior managers benefit from support by TDR
Capital, one of our principal shareholders and management consultants. Our country managers lead our operations in Australia,
the Benelux region, France, Germany, Italy, the United Kingdom and the United States. We believe that our management
structure incorporates appropriate flexibility for our country managers to take the actions they need to implement our global
strategies and initiatives in light of national market considerations. As disclosed in “Recent Developments,” upon completion
of the potential sale to Zuber Issa of the majority of the Retained UK&I Business, he intends to step down as Co-CEO,
remaining on our Board as non-executive director. Mohsin Issa would then become our sole CEO and would continue leading
our strategy going forward, supported by our strong senior management team responsible for day-to-day operations, including
John Carey, President and CEO of EG America, Imraan Patel, Chief Strategy and Business Officer and Michael Bradley, Chief
Financial Officer. John Carey was appointed President and CEO of EG America with effect from October 1, 2023, with a
mandate to drive forward our growth strategy in the United States, our largest market by both revenue and sites.

Our local management teams oversee the day-to-day operations at our sites and manage our compliance with local regulations.
For example, our local management teams monitor key performance indicators at a local level and determine staff scheduling
and product placement at our sites in line with localized market trends. For more information on our employees, see “—
_Employees.”_

Our management teams also work together to operate a Group-wide shared service center that manages our accounting,
reporting, information technology, human resources functions and other central corporate functions from our headquarters in
Blackburn, United Kingdom. Our shared service center provides back-office functions for our European operations and allows
us to manage the Group on a cost-efficient basis.

**_Our Operating Models_**

We have a mix of COCO, CONCO, and other retailer or dealer owned and operated sites. Our operating models can be described
in more detail as follows:

(1) COCO operations are directly managed by us and for these we control all aspects of the performance and
maintenance of the site. The COCO model is our preferred operating model. Through this model, we have
an opportunity to control important factors which have a direct impact on the customer experience and
profitability of each site, such as site layout and quality, customer service, product and service offering
selection, fuel and non-fuel pricing policies, staff scheduling and cost control. The COCO model is usually
more profitable than our other operating models as it allows us to capture profit that would otherwise be
payable to the site operator.

(2) At CONCO sites, the dealer, franchisee or retailer is responsible for all non-fuel operations, as well as the
operating costs associated with the management of the site, whereas we remain responsible for any capital
and maintenance costs associated with the fuel equipment, and in some instances we have a consignment
arrangement for fuel sales and inventory.

(3) Other sites are owned and operated by a third party who has full responsibility for the performance and
maintenance of the site. We either have a fuel supply arrangement in place with the third party, or,
alternatively, the fuel supply is on a consignment basis.

_Fuel Operations in Europe_

After giving effect to the Transactions, we operated 3,276 petrol filing stations in Europe as of June 30, 2023. After giving
effect to the Transactions, we sold 7.5 billion liters of fuel in Europe for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023 under the BP,
Esso, Shell and Texaco brands, our proprietary Firezone brand and certain minor oil brands.

Fuel price is a significant driver of competition in the forecourt industry and is driven by a variety of factors, including
maximum price limits set by governments, such as those in Belgium and Luxembourg. In addition, lower margins per liter in
Italy and Germany, due to local market conditions and fewer COCO locations, tend to have a dilutive effect on the overall
Group fuel margin. Within these parameters, historically we have had more freedom to set prices at our COCO sites, as opposed
to our other operating models where a third-party dealer, franchise or retailer makes the pricing decisions, and particularly at
our manned PFS locations with Grocery & Merchandise and Foodservice offerings. At our unmanned stations that offer a nofrills service, we typically sell fuel at a discount to attract customers and increase sales volumes. Our experience has
demonstrated that at manned PFS sites that we own and operate, the lower, more competitive pricing that we offer does not
generally increase sales volumes sufficiently to compensate for lost profit margins. We believe that, alternatively, an attractive
Grocery & Merchandise and/or Foodservice offering at manned PFS sites tends to increase customer footfall and sales volumes
because of the ‘halo effect’ provided by well-known Grocery & Merchandise and Foodservice brands at PFS sites. This allows
us to increase our prices and thus our fuel margins at such sites. In addition, we seek to realize cost savings through the
negotiation of more favorable terms for our fuel supply contracts.

We have dedicated fuel pricing teams that monitor fuel prices in real time in Europe. Our fuel pricing teams receive daily
updates from each site on local competitor prices, cost targets, historical records per site and the impact of cost movements on
volume in order to set daily prices. The daily prices are then communicated to the site managers. Real-time monitoring of fuel
prices allows us to react to market movements and adjust cost margins while live volume data helps us optimize our fuel
inventory management and control working capital.

In the regular course of our business, we enter into relationships with fuel suppliers whereby we commit to purchase certain
minimum quantities of fuel in order to benefit from better pricing conditions. We purchase fuel for each brand directly from
the relevant major fuel producer and/or refiner. Typically, at the end of each fuel supply contract period, we are also able to
change fuel suppliers and negotiate key terms such as price, payment and delivery terms and minimum volumes. We believe
that our long term relationships with our fuel suppliers reduce our exposure to re-contracting or termination risks. The average
length of our fuel supply contracts is five years. Since fuel products are commodities, we have no control over the changing
market value of our inventories. As our inventory is valued at the lower of weighted average cost and net realizable value
(which is based on market price), under our inventory valuation methodology, price fluctuations impact both cost of sales and
the value of the inventory reported in our financial statements. See “Summary Consolidated Historical and As Adjusted
_Financial Information and Other Data–Other Financial and Operating Data.” In addition, if the book value of our inventory_
is above its net realizable value on a certain balance sheet date, we are required to write down the inventory to net realizable
value. Due to the pricing arrangements under our fuel supply agreements and the high turnover levels of inventory held, the
measurement of the value of our inventory is based on the cost price of the inventory at our PFS sites.

Grocery & Merchandise Operations in Australia

since rebranded our Woolworths branded sites in Australia to EG.

Since the FuelCo Acquisition, we have expanded our Grocery & Merchandise offering in Australia. We have introduced a new
coffee and bakery offer in over 240 of our stores. We have also launched a delivery services offer across our network, with our
delivery partners such as UBER, Menulog and Door Dash. These partnerships also have allowed us to expand our online offers

Fuel Operations in Australia

We had 525 PFS sites in Australia as of June 30, 2023 and sold 2,471 million liters of fuel through these sites in the twelve
months ended June 30, 2023. Our fuel supplier in Australia is Ampol.

Our sites are typically in close proximity to Woolworths supermarkets in residential urban and rural areas or on main roads for
consumers in transit. We have a national presence in Australia, with 83% of our sites on the east coast where the majority of
Australia’s population resides. As part of our relationship with Woolworths, we have an agreement until 2033 pursuant to
which we are the only network that allows consumers to redeem Woolworth Group Supermarket fuel discounts at all locations
nationally coupled with other offers such as loyalty benefits under Woolworth Loyalty programs. We have also expanded into
new B2B partnerships with businesses that have large consumer bases, such as energy providers and motoring associations to
complement our fuel offers and to attract customers to our network.

Petrol prices tend to move up and down in cyclical patterns in Australia’s largest capital cities. The market is categorized by
petrol prices steadily decreasing for a period followed by a sharper increase. This pattern is also known as a petrol price cycle.
It is a movement in the retail price from a low point (or trough) to a high point (or peak) to the following low point. These
cycles can take between one to five weeks depending on the location. These gasoline retail price cycles do not typically occur
in each capital city at the same time, as prices are set competitively in each market and vary because of differences in the fuel
supply chains and lead times across Australia. The stage of the price restoration cycle we are in affects our Fuel margin, which
can vary on a daily, weekly and monthly basis and can cause some variation in our gross earnings. Over a larger time horizon,
our retail gross profit is more consistent, especially as prices in our other rural and regional markets are more stable. Large
spikes in oil prices or long, gradual increases or decreases in oil prices may from time to time impact our fuel gross profit and
stock valuations.

As part of the FuelCo Acquisition, EG Group agreed to continue FuelCo’s strategic partnership with Ampol (formerly operating

entered into a 15-year commercial alliance covering loyalty, fuel discount redemption, and wholesale supply across the FuelCo

**_Our Additional Operations_**

_Electric Vehicle Charging Stations and Alternative Fuels_

To meet evolving consumer demands, we have a multi-pronged strategy to provide electric charging stations and alternative
fuels. See “—Our Strategies—Pursue a multi-pronged strategy for energy transition.”


-----

_Electric Vehicle Charging Stations_

Key to our EV charging point strategy is ‘evpoint’ – our proprietary branded, ultra-fast electric vehicle charging proposition
that we believe has the potential to become one of Europe’s leading charge point operators. Our flagship location at Frontier
Park in Blackburn, United Kingdom the home of six ultra-fast chargers, opened in August 2022. We already installed ‘evpoint’
ultra-fast chargers at over 20 trial sites across the United Kingdom and Europe in 2022 and a further 33 sites in the first half of
2023. We have also earmarked a broader rollout across many hundreds of our sites through to 2026. With between two and six
charging points per site, and innovations in charging hardware, the latest load-balancing technology means several customers
can use a single point simultaneously. Our Retained UK&I Business will include all of our EV chargers in the United Kingdom
& Ireland following the UK Disposal to Asda.

Our focus is to use our existing forecourt space to create a network of ultra-fast enroute charge points for our highway and
roadside locations, as well as creating ‘destination’ charge points that provide fast charging at locations where customers are
likely to spend an extended period of time, such as malls and large supermarkets. For our roadside C-Store sites, we believe
the ultra-fast chargers provide convenience and rapid charging to time-constrained customers, as well as an attractive
destination to wait and explore our Foodservice and Grocery & Merchandise offerings.

The performance of our trial EV chargers has provided us comfort that the profit margins achievable on the sale of energy
through EV chargers provide a strong business case for a broader roll out. In addition, our EV chargers also create a ‘halo
effect’ by driving increased customer footfall to their locations. These chargers are also concentrated at locations that have
well-developed Grocery & Merchandise and Foodservice offerings, and we have found that the presence of EV chargers helps
drive increased customer footfall for such other offerings as well, since customers will typically spend time at the forecourt
while their vehicle is being charged. This increases the implied profit margin of our electric charging stations, and we believe
this provides us with an advantage over standalone electric charge point providers that do not have the advantage of our large
and well developed forecourt network. Similarly, we also find that our EV chargers that are on well-developed forecourts
benefit from higher utilization, since customers who visit the forecourt using electric vehicles will often use that time to topup their charge. We will continue to benefit from this virtuous cycle following the UK Disposal to Asda, since we have agreed
to enter into a right to occupation arrangement with Asda that will allow us to continue to use the forecourts being sold for our
existing EV chargers and we have entered into the EVPoint Side Letter with Project America Bidco Limited and Asda Stores
Limited, under which the intention to appoint EV Point Services Limited (a member of the Group) or an affiliate as sole
provider, operator and installer of EV chargers at Asda sites (including standalone petrol forecourt sites and Asda supermarkets)
was documented, including but not limited to C-Store sites sold pursuant to the UK Disposal to Asda.

We have been rolling out EV chargers across the United Kingdom and some sites in continental Europe. As of June 30, 2023,
we operated 662 electric charging points (compared to just 250 in 2021) across 169 sites in the United Kingdom & Ireland and
Continental Europe and have identified hundreds of additional sites that, due to their locations and nature, are suitable for
additional electric charge points as part of the next wave of site developments. We plan to continue our rollout of EV chargers
during the remainder of 2023, with a further 60 electric charging points operating by the end of the year, a majority of which
will be ultra-fast chargers. Based on our current capital allocation plans, we plan to undertake around $20 million to $50 million
of capital expenditure per year for the next five years to build out our EV charging network, which would allow us to include
around 100-200 additional locations to our network per year, each equipped with between two to four EV chargers. However,
our key strength in this area is our ability to use our extensive site network to quickly ramp up this roll-out if demand and
market conditions are suitable. To this end, we have already identified sites across our network that would be capable of hosting
EV chargers, and we could seek external investment to support a roll-out to these sites if market opportunity presents itself. In
particular, there is potential access to public funding to build out EV charging networks in a number of regions in which we
operated, in particular the United States and Europe, and we continue to explore the possibility of accessing such funding. In
the United States, our strategy has been to partner with leading third party charge point operators on EV charge points. Such
public-private partnerships, or partnerships with private sources of capital, would allow us to use our network and reach but
minimize the need for deploying our own capital. The availability of such third party or public capital is particularly prevalent
in the United States, and as such we expect that our EV charge points in the United States will have third party branding,
compared to our EV charge points in Europe that will primarily have our own branding. We currently do not have any near
term plans for an EV charger roll-out in Australia, but intend to revisit our Australian strategy in 2024.

To grow our EV charging network while remaining disciplined with respect to our capital expenditure, we are working with
leading market participants for the deployment of infrastructure and services to support energy transition demand across our
network at a competitive cost. Our EV chargers also generate carbon credits for us, which we may monetize as we grow our
EV charging station network. In addition, we intend to make our EV chargers compliant with the open-source Open Charge
Point Protocol (“OCPP”), which will make us less vulnerable to any individual system supplier. We also intend to develop and
use our own software at our charging stations, which will provide us with valuable data relating to EV usage and charging


-----

pattens which we may be able to monetize in the future. We may also explore additional opportunities in this space, including
relating to proprietary software and technology.

Alternative Fuels

We are also actively considering how compressed natural gas, LPG and hydrogen may form part of a broader strategic program
of retail fuels at our sites to sit alongside traditional transport fuels, with a particular focus on the potential for hydrogen to
power light and heavy-duty vehicles. As part of the hydrogen strategy, we made a strategic investment in Hydrogen Vehicle
Systems Limited (“HVS”). Our investment in HVS, which will form a part of the Retained UK&I Business following the UK
Disposal to Asda, allows us insight into the development of the market for hydrogen commercial vehicles. By working with
the HVS team, we are expanding our thought leadership as well as starting to explore infrastructure planning to support
hydrogen refueling at key sites across our portfolio in the United Kingdom. Following our acquisition of OMV, we inherited a
minor stake (1.2%) in H2 Mobility in Germany. That venture has allowed fuel-cell vehicle drivers to refuel at hydrogen filling
stations throughout Germany and we believe that our involvement will allow us to gain an accelerated insight into the market
for hydrogen filling and position us to introduce hydrogen refueling at key sites in the future.

EG Fuel, our wholesale supply business, manages the entire supply chain of Neste MY Renewable Diesel, which is a diesel
replacement made from vegetable oils (such as used cooking oil) and fats, in-house. EG Fuel distributes this fuel directly from
the depot to business customers, such as transport, postal and construction companies. Neste MY Renewable Diesel claims to
reduce carbon emissions by around 75–95% compared to fossil fuel diesel. EG Fuel also supports customers with
documentation on carbon savings for their carbon reporting.

More than 120 of our 465 PFS sites in the Netherlands now offer customers Neste MY Renewable Diesel. In January 2023,
EG Fuel partnered with KLM Equipment Services (“KES”) to supply Neste MY Renewable Diesel for its vehicle fleet at
Amsterdam’s Schiphol airport, to be used across the airport fleet of around 1,900 vehicles.

_EG Fuel_

EG Fuel, our wholesale supply business, is responsible for managing our strategic and operational fuel supply chain activities.
EG Fuel currently manages the purchase, storage and distribution of ground fuels sold across our PFS sites as well as sales to
third-party wholesale and business-to-business customers and fuel suppliers. As discussed above under “—Alternative Fuels”,
EG Fuel also currently works on our alternative fuels strategy.

In addition, EG Fuel sells lubricants to different customers such as car dealerships and small and medium-sized businesses in
the Netherlands and Belgium.

EG Fuel handles fuel purchases in Europe, including through our own fuel terminal network across Belgium, France,
Luxembourg and the Netherlands. EG Fuel typically manages all fuel replenishment planning in-house with a mandate to
optimize distribution costs, working capital and business continuity while taking into account seasonality and local demands.
Our planning tools read stock levels in a fuel tank electronically, which allows us to “push” products, balance inventory and
manage working capital. We are able to track in real time where trucks are on the road in order to advise sites of estimated
arrival times as well as make any last-minute changes if required. Our on-board truck computers have the ability to e-mail or
print proof of delivery documents as soon as the delivery is complete.

EG Fuel partners with third-party haulers under typically three-to-five year contracts. We typically outsource our fleet, other
than in the Netherlands, where we have a hybrid model comprising of a third-party fleet and our own fleet. Our own fleet of
trucks mainly serves our business-to-business fuel customers, but also serves our own PFS sites. We have actively sought to
strategically reduce our fleet size to optimal levels in recent years, through improved planning and optimization, by renewing
fleet age and capacity and by adapting the above-described model based on optimal cost.

**ESG & Sustainability**

As a retailer with global operations and supply chains, our impacts are extensive and varied. We focus on the ESG issues that
are most relevant to our business and our stakeholders, and on the issues where we have the greatest ability to effect change.

In early 2022, we conducted a comprehensive ESG materiality assessment to identify and define our priorities. Based on this
materiality assessment, we set out our ESG strategy which covers three focus areas: Planet, Colleagues and Communities. We
have set certain specific performance improvement targets in each of these areas. In addition, we are committed to taking a
responsible approach to our ESG ‘fundamentals’ – these are issues that form part of our business as usual activity (such as


-----

health and safety and data protection). In 2023, we are focusing on embedding our new ESG strategy into the business, and
continue to work on delivering against our set targets.

_Planet_

We recognize that the world needs to achieve net zero emissions by 2050 at the latest. We aim to play our part in tackling
climate change by reducing emissions, scaling up products and services that foster lower-carbon mobility, and reducing our
waste. Our targets include:

(1) Own operations (Scope 1 and 2): Reduce our carbon footprint by at least 50% by 2030 (compared to 2021)
and reach net zero by 2050.

(2) Products and supply chain (Scope 3): Explore a carbon reduction target in 2023 / 2024; and

(3) Expand our lower-carbon mobility offerings, including electric vehicle charging.

_Colleagues_

We believe everyone should have the opportunity to create a better future. Therefore, on top of creating job opportunities, we
also aim to provide an inclusive culture where all our colleagues can develop, progress and share our success.

In 2021, we carried out our inaugural ‘Better Together’ Group-wide colleague survey, to measure colleague engagement and
experience. Following on from this, in 2022, our teams worked to create action plans, conduct listening sessions with
colleagues, and implement improvements to workplace policies and processes. We are also committed to work on increasing
the number of women in senior leadership positions in our group. Women currently account for 30% of our senior leadership
group (compared to 23% in 2021). In addition, HR leads conduct quarterly colleague engagement reviews and report this into
the Remuneration Committee. Out target is to improve our engagement score year-on-year, from 62% in 2021, and based on
the results of our 2023 survey, we are on track to meet that target.

_Communities_

We believe that where a person starts in life should not determine where they end up, and aim to create a better future for our
wider communities. Our targets:

(1) Extend our community programs across all our operating markets;

(2) Start to roll out our volunteering policy.

**_Sale and Leaseback Transactions_**

In May 2023, we completed the sale and leaseback of a portfolio of our U.S. assets, comprising 414 sites across our Cumberland
Farms, Fastrac, Tom Thumb and Sprint brands, for a gross consideration of $1.5 billion, the net proceeds from which have
been or will be used to pay down our existing debt. See “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—The U.S. Sale and
_Leaseback Transaction” and “The Transactions—Sale and Leaseback Transaction.” In addition, we also completed a smaller_
transaction involving the sale and leaseback of three sites in New South Wales, Australia for a gross consideration of $11
million in May 2023. These transactions were part of our broader strategy to deleverage and maintain a robust capital structure
in the medium term. See “—Our Strategies—Rationalization of portfolio and focus on robust capital structure.”

**_Ownership of Properties_**

As of June 30, 2023, after giving effect to the Transactions but excluding any retailer-owned, dealer-owned or authorized
distributor sites, land banks or closed sites, approximately 30% of our property portfolio was freehold, comprising 1,795 sites,
approximately 56% of our property portfolio was leasehold, including long leasehold comprising 3,342 sites, approximately
1% of our portfolio was a hybrid of freehold and leasehold, comprising 68 sites, and approximately 3% of our portfolio was
concessions, comprising 187 sites. For concession sites, we are required to bid for our rights to the site, and if we win the
respective bid, we have the right to operate the site according to the terms of our bid.

We continue to monitor our lease agreements in order to take advantage of our ability to renegotiate rental payments across our
portfolio when possible. For example, in the Benelux region, we have designated coordinators that review, on a quarterly basis,
all leases set to expire in the coming two years and negotiate renewals. We do not have a fixed process for lease contract
renewals, although typically we approach landlords several months before lease expiry to negotiate renewals. Certain of our
leases, including most of our leases in France, have automatic renewal clauses.

**_Highway Concessions_**

As of June 30, 2023 (after giving effect to the Transactions), our property portfolio included 263 highway and high-way like
sites in Europe, which are among our most profitable operations. Highway concession operations depend on authorizations
from governmental regulatory agencies in the countries in which we operate, which are subject to bids, expiration and
limitations on renewal. For example, some of our highway concessions are granted under the European sealed-bid process. As
part of the strategic review of our business operations, we regularly review opportunities to renew suitable highway concessions
and obtain new highway concessions in desirable locations and a have a positive track record of renewing concessions and
winning tenders.

**Real Estate Valuation and Real Estate Reports**

The value of our freehold and leasehold properties is subject to fluctuation and depends upon a number of factors including
market conditions and interest rates. From time to time, we undertake internal valuations or engage third parties to undertake a
valuation of our real estate portfolio. Prior to the reports described in this section, the last time we had a third party real estate
report issued was in 2019, when we commission CBRE to prepare a valuations of our real estate portfolio (the “CBRE Report”).
The value ascribed to our real estate portfolio in the CBRE report was approximately $6.9 billion, although we note that our
property portfolio has undergone a number of changes since that time. We subsequently prepared an updated management
estimate of our real estate portfolio in July 2022, pursuant to which we estimated the value of our real estate portfolio to be $10
billion ($3.5 billion of which relates to properties which were subsequently sold pursuant to the UK Disposal to Asda and the
U.S. Sale and Leaseback). Both the CBRE Report and our internal management estimates of real estate value were based a
number of assumptions, projections and estimates and we cannot assure you that the assumptions or projections used, estimates
made or procedures followed in the CBRE Report or in preparing our internal management estimates were correct, accurate or
complete.

In recent months, the value of commercial real estate in the markets in which we operate has been significantly depressed. A
key reason behind this is that the commercial real estate market is highly correlated with the level of interest rates and the yields
on government debt, which in certain markets may be used as a benchmark to price commercial mortgages. As a result, the
valuations given to our real estate portfolio may be lower than what we believe to be the underlying value of our real estate
portfolio and lower than its historical value or what would otherwise be given in better economic conditions. For example,
using the average base interest rates, spreads and overall investor cost of capital for the last 10 years and Rent Coverage of


-----

2.00x – 2.50x, Eastdil Secured arrived at a valuation of $2,949 million for our real estate portfolio in the United States versus
$2,489 million based upon current rates. See “—Real Estate Reports – Key findings.”

Interest rates in each of the regions in which we operate have significantly increased since mid-2022 and may remain at these
higher levels for longer than initially anticipated. This increase in interest rates has also increased the cost of commercial
mortgages in each of the markets in which we operate. The yields on corporate bonds issued by REITs and other large
institutional property investors have also increased significantly in this period. Such increase in yields, along with declining
share prices of a number of such large property investors, has increased the relative cost of capital for real estate acquisitions,
which in turn has depressed commercial real estate prices. Based on our internal assessment, this depression in commercial real
estate prices has also negatively impacted the value of our real estate portfolio. While we believe this depression in the value
of our commercial real estate is temporary and that the value will revert to closer to its historical value once market conditions
improve and interest rates stabilize, there can be no assurance regarding whether, or over what time fame, this will happen.
See, “Risk Factors—Disruptions in the financial markets, uncertain economic conditions, changes in interest rates and yields
_on government bonds and recent inflationary pressure could adversely affect the value of our real estate, which is subject_
_to fluctuation.”_

In light of the abovementioned changes in commercial real estate values, and in order to understand the value of our real estate
portfolio in current market conditions, in September 2023, we retained Cushman & Wakefield Netherlands B.V. (“Cushman

The Real Estate Reports are intended to be an estimate of the market price of the underlying properties based on current market

**_Overview of Market_**

Both Real Estate Reports contain an overview of the relevant market prepared by the Report Providers. Some of the factors
that have led to the depression of market price of commercial property in the current macro-economic environment are
highlighted in these market overviews, which we have summarized below. Each market overview is based on the relevant
Report Provider’s assessment of the market and, while it is based on information we believe to be accurate, neither the Report
Providers nor we take any responsibility for the accuracy of this information.

_C&W Report_

The C&W Report provides a summary of certain negative trends in the European real estate market. For the first six months in
2023, the average sale volumes are 50% below their average level from the relative periods in 2017-2019 (which the C&W
Report considers a more appropriate baseline for comparison in light of heightened investment activity in real estate during the
COVID-19 pandemic). The decline is attributed primarily to rising interest rates, economic uncertainty and unavailability of
credit. Using the decline in the market value of REITs as a real-time guide, the report provides that Continental European retail
real estate values have fallen 21.8% peak-to-trough, while retail real estate values in the United Kingdom have fallen by 52.1%.
Longer term valuations are expected to be contingent on the yields of 10-year government bonds, which according to the report
are expected to settle in 2.5% to 3.5% range for both the United Kingdom and Continental Europe. Real estate valuations have


-----

an inverse relationship with Cap Rates, and Cap Rates have risen across Europe as real estate values have fallen in recent
months. According to the C&W Report, Cap Rates are forecasted to steadily decline from 2024 till 2027.

_Eastdil Report_

According to the Eastdil Report, the convenience store and fuel station industry has proven to be relatively recession resilient
in response to the current macroeconomic volatility. There are over 150,000 convenience stores operating in the United States.
About 80% of these stores sell fuel, and the industry continues to be dominated by single-store operators, which account for
approximately 60% of all stores. In 2022, U.S. convenience stores served approximately 165 million customers daily,
accounting for over 10% of total retail and food service sales.

According to the Eastdil Report, the broader commercial real estate market outlook in the United States remains dependent on
the future of interest rates and the yields on U.S. treasuries, with the market current expecting the rates to be “higher for longer,”
which has led to a depression in real estate prices. Since June 2022, each major U.S. treasury has sustained significant increases
in rates, with 1-year treasury bills increasing from 2.06% to 5.47%, 2-year treasury notes increasing from 2.58% to 5.14%, 5year treasury notes increasing from 2.85% to 4.83%, 7-year treasury notes increasing from 2.89% to 4.86%, 10-year treasury
notes increasing from 2.87% to 4.82%, and 30-year treasury bonds increasing from 3.06% to 4.94% as of October 4, 2023. On
average, this reflects an increase of 229 basis points. This increase in risk-free rates has been reflected in the bond market,
where yields on corporate bonds issued by REITs have increased significantly. Along with declining share prices, this has
increased the relative cost of capital for real estate acquisitions, which in turn has depressed commercial real estate prices.

**_Methodology, Assumptions and Basis of Broker’s Opinion of Pricing_**

_C&W Report_

The C&W Report determines the broker’s opinion of pricing of each property on the basis of existing use (trading) of such
property as an operational C-Store. The broker’s opinion of pricing included in the C&W Report was provided using the local
currency for each country and has been converted into U.S. dollars at the closing rate as at October 1, 2023.

The opinion of pricing contained in the C&W Report of all properties was based on their existing use and based on financial
information we provided to Cushman & Wakefield. These included trading figures for 2022 and 2023 (year-to-date) for each
relevant property, which included retail and bunkering fuel volumes, fuel margins, shop turnover excluding VAT/IVA taxes,
shop margins, Foodservice turnover excluding VAT/IVA taxes, Foodservice margins, other income and site-by-site EBITDA
values.

The C&W Report was produced without any detailed physical inspection of any property, environmental audit, tests of services
and amenities or investigations as to the condition of the properties. The valuation analysis also did not take into account any
specific, current physical conditions of a property. In addition, the C&W Report was based on a number of assumptions relating
to the property portfolio, including:

  - that the value of properties subject to the C&W Report was linked to their trading potential. This was based on their
assumption that properties sold on the basis of their trading or underlying trading potential are designed or adapted
for a specific use, and the resulting lack of flexibility typically means that the pricing a particular property is
intrinsically linked to the trading potential of such property;

  - that we have the ability to obtain/renew existing licenses, consents, certificates and permits;

  - that each property is operated in accordance with its authorized use under planning legislation and in accordance
with the use registered with the relevant regulatory agency;

  - that the properties are not adversely affected by any existed or proposed environmental law;

  - that there are no abnormalities as to the repair and condition of the properties;

  - that the properties possess a good and marketable title free from any onerous restrictions or conditions;

  - that all title, legal, tenure, lettings, planning, taxation, statutory and local authority requirements are complied with;
and


-----

  - various other assumptions regarding tenure, letting, taxation, town planning, and the condition and repair of
buildings and sites—including ground and groundwater contamination.

To arrive at a broker’s opinion of pricing Cushman & Wakefield also took into account: a) the legal interest in the land and
buildings; b) the trade inventory, usually comprising all trade fixtures, fittings, furnishing and equipment; and c) the market’s
perception of the trading potential of each property, together with an assumed ability to obtain or review existing licenses,
consents, certificates and permits. The broker’s opinion of pricing presented in the C&W Report was arrived at using
comparable transactional evidence. Various initial yields were applied to petrol filling stations, depending upon their country,
specific geographic location, trading history and profitability. The presence or absence of local competition and the alternative
use potential of the site were also considered, in addition to evidence of rent for comparable sites. Furthermore, the C&W
Report also took account of the condition and size of the properties being assessed and the current petroleum and economic
market conditions. The site information used to perform the brokers’ opinion of pricing was solely provided by EG Group and
consisted of:

   - information about tenure, plot area and other land registry details per site;

   - an overview of site area, shop area and sale area per location;

   - historic trading figures (2022 and 2023 YTD) for each property to include a profit and loss account;

   - revenue broken down by income stream, margin for each, operating expenditure and EBITDA. By way of
example this included:

`o` retail and bunkering fuel volumes;

`o` fuel margins;

`o` shop turnover excluding VAT/IVA taxes;

`o` shop margins;

`o` Foodservice turnover excluding VAT/IVA taxes;

`o` Foodservice margins, other income; and

`o` site-by-site EBITDA values.

_Eastdil Report_

The Eastdil Report determines the broker’s opinion of pricing of each property on the basis of existing use (trading) of such
property as an operational C-Store, and is intended to be a guide of the likely pricing of our freehold properties.

Eastdil Secured’s opinion of pricing was arrived at using comparable transactional evidence of leasing and sales transactions
(without inspection of the underlying properties), adjusted to reflect the characteristics of the 952 convenience and fuel
properties and the store support campus, subject to a number of assumptions and limitations, including the ones identified
below:

  - Eastdil Secured did not make any third-party inquiries with respect to ownership and title, building structure and
condition, planning, environmental or other statutory information. Eastdil Secured assumed that there are no adverse
factors relating to these that would impact on pricing;

  - Eastdil Secured have not independently verified any of our sources of information and have assumed that
information provided by us to them is accurate and can, if necessary, be verified;

  - Eastdil Secured have assumed that there would be a willing lessor and willing lessee as well as a willing seller and a
purchaser in terms of demand for the properties in the open market;

  - Eastdil Secured’s opinions reflect appropriately sized institutional portfolio property pricing and no premium has
been applied on account of the properties being offered for sale to the market on an individual basis. Eastdil Secured
have assumed there would be an orderly disposal of the properties;

  - Eastdil Secured have assumed that freehold assets are free from any material landowner rent charge that may affect
pricing. If the properties should form part of a wider title, Eastdil Secured have assumed that they could be disposed
of independently and without restriction.


-----

  - Eastdil Secured have assumed that mixed interest assets are partially encumbered by a mix of nominal ground
leases, easements, or other lease payments;

  - Eastdil Secured have assumed all properties have valid planning permission and appropriate licensing for their
existing use;

  - Eastdil Secured have assumed that the properties are in a well maintained and in marketable condition and are
compliant with all building, accessibility and fire safety regulations;

  - Eastdil Secured have assumed that the properties have standard configuration appropriate to their use;

  - Eastdil Secured have assumed that full access and egress rights exist for the property, along with sufficient parking;

  - Eastdil Secured have assumed that the properties are connected to all main services including water, drainage,
electricity and telecommunications;

  - Eastdil Secured have assumed that there are no environmental issues such as contamination, flooding, ground
conditions, invasive or protected plants or species that would cause the properties to be inoperable.

  - Eastdil Secured have made certain assumptions around rental pricing, capital pricing and lease terms. In particular,
the Eastdil Report (as described above) presents four valuation scenarios on the basis of different methodologies,
supported by assumptions (i) on different rent coverages, which are the ratio of asset-level earnings before interest,
taxes, depreciation, amortization, and rent costs (reduced by ground rent expense for leasehold assets)
(“EBITDAR”) for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023 to the estimated year one sale-leaseback rent expense for
the portfolio (“Rent Coverage”), (ii) on pricing based on historical based rates, spreads and overall investor cost of
capital for approximately the last ten years and (iii) based on recent comparable transactions involving marketleading convenience and gas companies to determine enterprise value; and

  - Eastdil Secured have not deducted any costs for downtime during which the properties are not leased.
