**_Footprint Expansion Strategy_**

We look to expand our footprint by identifying potential sites to knock down and rebuild, opening NTI sites and extending our
COCO model to additional sites. While selecting and developing each site, we pay close attention to land prices, which vary
significantly across locations, and consider several other factors, such as potential traffic flow and customer footfall, the ability
to set up or increase our Grocery & Merchandise or Foodservice offerings at each site, the existence of local competitors and
local amenities and the site’s potential profitability.

_Newly Acquired Sites and Land Banks_

We will selectively evaluate opportunities to expand our footprint by acquiring new sites, with acquisitions ranging in size
from single sites, to collections of multiple sites, to larger acquisitions of full businesses such as Cooplands, Kroger convenience
retail locations, FuelCo or Cumberland Farms. While we remain open to such acquisitions in the future if an attractive
opportunity presents itself, our current strategy is to focus on organic growth.

In addition, we acquire land banks in opportunistic locations where we would like to operate our business. Our timescale from
initial site selection at the land bank through to the prospective new site opening for business can range between one and three
years.

_“Knock-Down Rebuild” Sites_

We continue to identify potential sites for knock-down-rebuilds (“KDRs”, known as ‘raze-and-rebuilds’ in the United States),
as we have historically seen an uplift in the performance of knocked-down rebuilt sites. Based on our experience, an uplift in
a rebuilt site is typically achieved within one month of reopening the site and that uplift continues to improve over the next two
years. During each of 2022 and 2021, we undertook four KDRs, and in the six months ended June 30, 2023 we did not undertake
any KDRs.


-----

In the twelve months ended June 30, 2023, we spent $11.2 million on KDRs across the Group. Our timescale from closing an
existing site through to the KDR being completed is typically twelve to twenty weeks.

_New-to-Industry Sites_

In addition to acquiring new sites and rebuilding existing sites, we often set up new-to-industry (“NTI”) sites, which are new
sites that are opened in locations where no site existed before and thus where we would not have the opportunity to acquire
already operating businesses. Across our portfolio, we opened 31 NTI sites in 2022, 30 NTI sites in 2021 and 7 NTI sites in
the six months ended June 30, 2023.

In the twelve months ended June 30, 2023, we spent $129 million on NTI sites across the Group. Our timescale from initial
site selection through to the new-to-industry site opening for business generally ranges between one to three years.

**Employees**

As of December 31, 2022, we had approximately 56,647 employees located across the regions in which we operate. Full-time
equivalents are calculated based on an analysis of the number of hours worked as of December 31, 2022 for which individual
personnel were actually paid, based on an assumed working week of forty hours and either four-or five-week months. Of these
employees, approximately 31,449 (or 56%) are located in Europe, approximately 20,368 (or 36%) are located in the United
States and approximately 4,823 (or 9%) are located in Australia.

In light of the seasonal nature of our industry, we also maintain a flexible workforce, including hourly, part-time and temporary
workers, which allows us to adjust staffing levels on relatively short notice to match anticipated demand at our sites.

We aim to be an employer of choice and are committed to ensuring colleagues are respected and their views are valued. We
keep an anti-bullying and anti-harassment policy, which is part of our employee handbook. We maintain appropriate training
and colleague communication programs and closely monitor employee activities to ensure that both strategy and colleague
engagement are aligned to keep us at the forefront of a competitive marketplace.

**_Works Councils and Trade Unions_**

We cooperate with local trade unions and work councils in countries where trade unions and/or work councils are active. In
these jurisdictions, we normally have framework agreements, tariff contracts or other general agreements in place, which are
agreed through discussions with the works councils and consider local labor laws. These agreements govern, among other
things, working conditions, working hours and the definition of tariff groups. These agreements can be negotiated for a limited
or unlimited term, and can be cancelled by either party in favor of renegotiation.

We believe we have good relationships with our employees and open and constructive working relationships with such
employee representation bodies across our various regions.

**_Employee Benefits_**

We operate various post-employment schemes across our Group companies, including both defined benefit and defined
contribution plans, including a retirement benefit plan, jubilee benefits for long years of service, a bridge pension plan for
employment terminated by us before the normal retirement date and other termination benefits payable when an employee
accepts voluntary redundancy in exchange for certain benefits.

**Insurance**

Our Group-wide insurance coverage includes policies for risks associated with our business, including with respect to
environmental liabilities. These policies provide insurance cover for material property damage, material accidents and material
business interruption, in addition to standard corporate insurance, including crime and directors and officers insurance. We do
not currently maintain insurance coverage that is intended to address cybersecurity and data protection risks.

We believe that our insurance coverage is sufficient for the risks associated with our operations and that our policies are in
accordance with customary industry practices. However, there can be no guarantee that the coverage we maintain will be
sufficient to cover the cost of defense or other damages in the event of a significant claim. The nature of our business exposes
us to various liability claims which may exceed the level of our insurance.


-----

**Information Technology**

We own, operate and continue to invest in multiple IT systems, including servers, software products and licenses and
networking equipment located in multiple locations such as at tier 1 cloud providers, private data centers, our offices and our
sites. Our IT technology enables the management of products, pricing levels and stock as well as the recording of sales,
payments, including upcoming contactless payment systems, and waste levels for all of our sites. For example, we operate our
own pricing system using our Price Advantage software which we have improved with our own algorithms based on the data
we collect from our network of sites. Using own system of adapted pricing software in this way allows us to control fuel retail
pricing centrally, monitor fuel prices in real-time and adjust margins in line with volume gains and losses. It also allows us to
set daily site prices based on local competitor prices, price per liter targets and historical records per site on the impact of price
movements on volume. We then use our technology to automate prices for display on signs at integrated PFS sites in minutes.
Using our own system with our algorithms also provides operators with analytics capabilities to better understand prior pricing
behavior of suppliers and competitors and forecast future market movements.

Central reporting provides our management with tools and reports to oversee our business operations. Network and security
engineers are employed (on a full-time basis) to design, build, maintain and monitor our network and IT security position. We
use SAP Success Factors and site time and attendance biometric systems to manage and monitor staff utilization, schedules
and costs. For disaster recovery, we backup and replicate to alternative locations. We have invested in the latest products from
SAP ServiceNow and Microsoft to enhance the capabilities in the technology systems.

**Intellectual Property**

We own a number of trademarks important to our business. Our material trademarks are registered or pending applications for
registrations in various jurisdictions. There are no claims pending against us challenging our right to use any of our material
trademarks in any country.

We also have the authority to utilize trademarks and brands of the third parties with which we partner, pursuant to the terms of
our agreements with them.

**Regulation**

Our operations are directly subject to, and indirectly affected by, extensive regulation that varies from country to country and
region to region. These regulations govern, among other things, environmental, health and safety protection (including
regulations specific to the fuel market, such as for petroleum storage certificates, the management and disposal of hazardous
materials, air emissions and water discharge and the cleanup of contaminated sites), EV charging-related regulations, food
safety and labeling regulations, product quality, employee representation, minimum wage laws, privacy and data protection,
and tax laws in Europe, the United States and Australia. We may also assume regulatory liabilities and make provisions in
respect of our business combinations and acquisitions. We oversee regulatory obligations of acquired companies and use a
number of compliance management systems to align the policies and protocols of acquired companies with those of the Group,
where applicable. We have not been subject to any material fines or legal or regulatory action involving non-compliance with
applicable regulations and are unaware of any material non-compliance with or liability from relevant regulations.

**Health and Safety**

We are committed to maintaining the highest standards of health and safety practices for our colleagues, customers, visitors,
contractors and anyone affected by our business activities. We therefore consider good health, environment and safety
management as an essential part of the business performance and culture aiming for “ZERO accidents & incidents.” We
formally monitor health and safety incident rates. Our health and safety policies and procedures include, but are not limited to:

(1) Managing risk and promoting health and safety culture;

(2) Dedicated health & safety teams in every market in which we operate;

(3) Appropriate training for all employees to adhere to legal compliance and best practice;

(4) Proactively and regularly conducting regular risk assessments and root cause analyses to provide and
maintain safe and healthy working environments to reduce occupational injuries or illnesses;

(5) formal monitoring of health and safety incident rates via a procedure of logging and reporting incidents on a
software system; and


-----

(6) completing quarterly audits of health and safety performance.

We also have reporting systems and support functions for food and health and safety including:

1. Food Safety Managers;

2. Safety Managers;

3. Technical Advisers;

4. Quality Assurance Advisers; and

5. Primary Authority Partnerships (PAPs).

Health & Safety Committees are in place across the business for each region, reporting in the Group’s Health & Safety Manager,
who has direct access to the Group General Counsel and Company Secretary, and quarterly reports are presented to the
Executive Risk & Disclosure Committee and the Board. Our employees are provided with Health & Safety training and bespoke
training is identified and provided based on roles, including NEBOSH, IOSH, Food Safety RSPH Levels 2, 3 and 4.

We are also committed to ensuring that there is no modern slavery or human trafficking in our supply chains nor in any part of
our business. Our policy in this regard reflects our commitment to acting ethically and with integrity in all our business
relationships and to implementing and enforcing systems and controls that aim to ensure that slavery and human trafficking is
not taking place in our supply chains.

**Litigation**

We have been and, from time to time, may continue to become a party to claims and lawsuits incidental to the ordinary course
of our business. On April 1, 2022, we resolved our Australian Federal Court proceedings with Ampol relating to a fuel supply
agreement that was novated from Woolworths to EG in 2019. Pursuant to the settlement agreement, it was decided that Ampol
would be the exclusive supplier to all stores within our Australian network under a fuel supply agreement on updated
commercial terms. Both parties also agreed to discontinue their claims against the other party. The updated commercial terms
resulted in a decrease in the carrying value of provisions by $43 million.

In addition, we often also assume liabilities and make provisions in respect of acquisitions. Where claims or lawsuits are
introduced against any of our Group companies, we review them to determine whether provisions are required to be made for
them and in what amounts. We are not aware of any material litigation pending or threatened against any Group company.

Risk Committee include the following:

financial information including key judgments and disclosures;

  - Overseeing the external auditor relationship, recommending to the board their appointment and remuneration and

across EG Group, delivers the Group’s strategic objectives and is aligned with shareholder interests. The roles and
responsibilities of the Nomination Committee include:


-----

  - Proposing appropriate remuneration structures for executive management and the workforce and ensuring the

all proposed structures; and

of the Nomination Committee are as follows:

management; and

**Shareholders’ Arrangements**

On May 2, 2018, Zuber Vali Issa, Mohsin Issa, Optima Bidco and Optima Group S.à r.l., among others, entered into a
shareholders’ agreement (the “Shareholders’ Agreement”), which governs various rights of the shareholders of Optima Bidco
in relation to their direct shareholding in Optima Bidco and indirect shareholding in the Group. The Shareholders’ Agreement
was amended and restated on October 8, 2019 in connection with the issuance of preference shares, subsequently amended on
February 19, 2020 and amended again on November 11, 2020 in connection with a further issuance of preference shares.

Pursuant to the Shareholders’ Agreement, both Zuber Issa and Mohsin Issa, acting through Optima Bidco (Jersey) Limited (the
“Individual Shareholders”), on the one hand, and TDR Capital, acting through Optima Group S.à r.l. (the “TDR Shareholder”),
on the other hand, are entitled to appoint or remove directors in certain circumstances. Each of the Individual Shareholders and
the TDR Shareholder are entitled to appoint and remove (i) two members of the board of directors of Optima Bidco and each
member of the Group so long as such shareholder, together with its affiliates, together hold 35% or more of the share capital
of Optima Bidco, and (ii) one member of the board of directors of Optima Bidco and each member of the Group so long as
such shareholder, together with its affiliates, together hold between 15% and 35% of the share capital of Optima Bidco. The
maximum number of directors for the board of Optima Bidco is five and, subject to certain actions which required the consent
of the Individual Shareholders and the TDR Shareholder, as summarized below, all decisions of the board of directors may be
made by a majority of the votes cast.

The Shareholders’ Agreement provides that certain actions in relation to the Group may not be taken without the consent of
either of the Individual Shareholders (or any of the directors appointed by them) and the TDR Shareholder (or any of the
directors appointed by it). These include amendments to the organizational documents of any member of the Group, variations
to the rights attaching to the shares in any member of the Group, the declaration or payment of any dividend or distribution by
any Group company (other than to Optima Bidco or another Group company which is wholly-owned by Optima Bidco), a
material change in the nature or scope of the Group’s business and the winding up or dissolution of Optima Bidco or any other
Group company.

The Shareholders’ Agreement contains certain restrictions on the transfer by any shareholder of its shares in Optima Bidco or
any other member of the Group, including an obligation on the Individual Shareholders and the TDR Shareholder to first offer
any shares to the other before offering them for sale to a third party.

The TDR Shareholder is entitled to control the timing and manner of any exit event involving Optima Bidco, including the sale
of its shares in Optima Bidco; the sale by Optima Bidco or any other member of the Group of all or substantially all of its
business, assets and undertaking; any public offering in respect of any shares in Optima Bidco or any other Group company;
the reorganization of Optima Bidco or any other Group company and the winding up of Optima Bidco in each case, on specified
terms and subject to the occurrence of certain conditions.

On October 31, 2023, Zuber Vali Issa, Mohsin Issa and Optima Group S.à r.l. entered into a letter of intent regarding the
potential sale to Zuber Issa of the Retained UK&I Business, excluding the ‘evpoint’ business, the Cooplands business, the
Starbucks Business and the KFC Business. The sale remains subject to contract and financing and there can be no assurance
that a definitive agreement will ultimately be entered into; any such transaction would be entered into on arm’s length
commercial terms.

**CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS**
We enter into transactions with our shareholders, other entities owned by, or affiliated with, our direct and indirect shareholders,
and joint ventures and associates in the ordinary course of business. These transactions include, among other things, the sale
and purchase of real estate. See “Risk Factors— _We may enter into transactions with related parties on terms that are less_
_favorable to us than would be the case if such transactions had not been with related parties.” We believe that these transactions_
with our affiliated entities were made in the ordinary course of business, on fair terms and at arm’s length. We may, from time
to time, enter into similar arrangements with affiliated entities in the ordinary course of business and on terms that we believe
are no less favorable than those that could reasonably have been obtained at such time from an unaffiliated party.

Our related party policy, adopted pursuant to IAS 24 and the Companies Act, requires any individuals who hold significant
control or influence, or key management personnel, to avoid situations where they have potential or actual conflicts of interest,
declare any potential or actual conflicts of interest, and declare any interest in an existing transaction or arrangement. The
Group General Counsel & Company Secretary undertakes reviews of the disclosure to determine any potential or actual
conflicts with a related party that may require approval from the Board pursuant to the Companies Act, our articles of
association, and any applicable legislation or regulation. Where a potential or actual conflict or related party transaction arises,
details are recorded and reported to the Board. The Board reviews all relevant information and either approves or disapproves
entry into the related party transaction, based on whether the transaction is, in good faith, not inconsistent with the interests of
the Group and its shareholders.

_Transactions with Asda relating to the UK Disposal to Asda_

On May 30, 2023, we announced our binding agreement to sell a substantial majority of our Fuel, Foodservice and Grocery
and Merchandise business in the United Kingdom to Asda, which was completed on Oct 31, 2023 for consideration of £2
billion. See “The Transactions—The UK Disposal to Asda—Sale and Purchase Agreement.”

In relation to the UK Disposal to Asda, we have entered into, or are in discussions with Asda to enter into certain agreements
to facilitate our continued operation of our Retained UK&I Business. These arrangements include transitional service
agreements pursuant to which we will agree to continue to provide access to all centralized shared services (such as IT, HR,
accounting, payroll, compliance and tax functions), that were, in the 12 months prior to Completion, provided to the Target
Group by us, for a transitional period. The Seller and the Target have agreed to enter into a transitional brand license agreement
which will take effect immediately following Completion. An affiliate of the Seller will also grant a transitional sublease of
part of the Group’s head office building located at Waterside, Blackburn that is currently occupied by employees of the
Disposed UK Business, Retained UK&I Business and Group’s non-UK businesses, to the Purchaser for a period of two years
following Completion. For more information on TSA, see “The Transactions—The UK Disposal to Asda—Ancillary
_Agreements”._

Moreover, the freehold properties upon which the Starbucks Business sits will be sold as part of the UK Disposal to Asda.
However, the Starbucks Business will remain part of the Retained UK&I Business and we, as tenant, will pay rent to Asda in
connection with these leases. In addition, we will retain all EV chargers currently deployed across our network in the United
Kingdom as part of the Retained UK&I Business. In relation to EV chargers on forecourts that will be sold to Asda as part of
the Disposed UK Business, we are in discussions with Asda to enter into right to occupation agreements which will replace the


-----

transitional licenses to occupy currently in place, pursuant to which we will pay Asda to continue to operate our existing EV
chargers from their forecourts as well as for future installations. The amount payable, once agreed, may be in the form of a
variable percentage of revenues, margin, net income or other metric being payable to Asda. For further detail, see “The
_Transactions—The UK Disposal to Asda—Ancillary Agreements.”_

Upon the occurrence of the Conditions Satisfaction Date (referenced below), the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement will be
further amended to reflect arrangements agreed in the Consent Letters (the “A&E Amendment”). The “Conditions Satisfaction
Date” is the date upon which certain conditions set out in the Consent Letters are satisfied, including, among others: (i) the
condition that the Parent apply cash proceeds received from certain transactions (including the UK Disposal to Asda and the
U.S. Sale and Leaseback), towards repayment, no later than December 31, 2023, of no less than 40% of the senior secured term
loans under the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement as at the date of the Consent Letters; (ii) the condition that the UK Disposal
to Asda completes on or prior to December 31, 2023 generating cash proceeds in an aggregate amount of not less than
£2,000,000,000 (or its equivalent in other currencies); (iii) the condition that the Parent pay, or procure the payment, of certain
fees and original issue discounts payable in relation to certain Revolving Credit Facilities, Letter of Credit Facilities and
Tranche C Term Facilities (each such term as is defined below); and (iv) the condition that, upon satisfaction of the other
conditions, no more than 20% of the aggregate principal amount of term senior secured indebtedness outstanding on the date
of the Consent Letters shall be outstanding under Tranche A Term Facilities (each such term as is defined below).

**_Interest and Fees_**

Loans under the Senior Credit Facilities will bear interest at rates per annum equal to EURIBOR in respect of loans denominated
in Euro, BBSY (BID) in respect of loans denominated in Australian dollars, compounded SONIA (subject to a credit adjustment
spread) for loans denominated in GBP and compounded SOFR (subject to a credit adjustment spread) for loans denominated
in USD, plus an applicable margin, which in each case (x) with respect to the Tranche A Term Facilities, the Tranche B Term
Facilities, the Revolving Credit Facilities and prior to the occurrence of the Conditions Satisfaction Date, the Tranche C Term
Facilities, will be subject to a decreasing margin ratchet based on the ratio of consolidated senior secured net debt to
consolidated pro forma EBITDA (each as defined in the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement) (the “Senior Secured Net Leverage
Ratio”), provided that, immediately upon the occurrence of the Conditions Satisfaction Date, the decreasing margin ratchet
will only apply to the Revolving Credit Facilities.

If EURIBOR is less than zero, EURIBOR shall be deemed to be zero in respect of loans made under the Senior Term Facilities
denominated in Euros and the Revolving Credit Facilities (as applicable). If BBSY (BID) is less than zero, BBSY (BID) shall
be deemed to be zero in respect of loans made under the Senior Term Facilities denominated in Australian dollars and the
Revolving Credit Facilities (as applicable). If the aggregate of the Daily Rate and the applicable Credit Adjustment Spread with
respect to sterling is less than zero, the Daily Rate shall be deemed to be such a rate that the aggregate of the Daily Rate and
the applicable Credit Adjustment Spread is zero in respect of loans made under the Senior Term Facilities denominated in
sterling and the Revolving Credit Facilities (as applicable). If the aggregate of the Daily Rate and the applicable Credit
Adjustment Spread with respect to USD is less than zero or less than 0.5 per cent. (as applicable), the Daily Rate shall be
deemed to be such a rate that the aggregate of the Daily Rate and the applicable Credit Adjustment Spread is zero or 0.5 per
cent. (as applicable) in respect of loans made under the Senior Term Facilities and the Revolving Credit Facilities (as applicable)
denominated in USD.

A commitment fee will be payable on the aggregate undrawn and uncancelled amount of the Revolving Credit Facility from
the Additional Facility Commencement Date applicable to the relevant Revolving Credit Facility to the end of the availability
period each as applicable to the Revolving Credit Facility at a rate of 35% of the applicable margin for the Revolving Credit
Facility. Commitment fees will be payable quarterly in arrears and on the date the Revolving Credit Facility is cancelled in full
or on the date on which the relevant lender cancels its commitment.

A fronting fee of 0.125% is payable on the outstanding exposure under each letter of credit under each Letter of Credit Facility
(other than the Murray Letter of Credit Facility, with respect to which a 0.4% fronting fee is payable) which is counter
indemnified by other lenders (which are not affiliates of the relevant fronting bank) and which is not cash collateralized, repaid,
prepaid or cancelled, for the period from the issue of the relevant letter of credit until its expiry date (or the date of its repayment,
prepayment or cancellation, if earlier), and a letter of credit fee computed at the rate equal to (x) prior to the Conditions
Satisfaction Date, 2% per annum, or (y) on or after the Conditions Satisfaction Date, 3% per annum, is payable on the
outstanding amount of each letter of credit under the relevant Letter of Credit Facility for the period from the issue of the
relevant letter of credit until its expiry date (or the date of its cancellation, if earlier).

Default interest will be calculated as an additional 1% on the defaulted amount.

A ticking fee is payable in respect of the Tranche C Term Facilities within 10 business days of the occurrence of the Conditions
Satisfaction Date, computed by reference to each lender’s commitments under the Tranche C Term Facilities as at June 30,
2023 for the period commencing on (and including) the date of allocation of the Tranche C Term Facilities and ending on (but
excluding) the Conditions Satisfaction Date and equal to the difference between the margin applicable prior to, and following,
the occurrence of the Conditions Satisfaction Date. No ticking fee shall be payable if the Conditions Satisfaction Date does not
occur.


-----

A ticking fee is payable in respect of Tranche D Term Facilities within 10 business days of the occurrence of the date of first
utilization of the Tranche D Term Facilities (“Tranche D Closing Date”), computed by reference to each lender’s commitments
under the Tranche D Term Facilities, for the period commencing on the date of allocation of the Tranche D Term Facilities and
ending on the Tranche D Closing Date, and the number of days that have elapsed since the date of allocation of the Tranche D
Term Facilities. No ticking fee shall be payable if the Tranche D Closing Date does not occur.

In connection with the Amend and Extend and the utilization of Tranche D Term Facilities, we will pay certain fees costs and
expenses totaling $170 million.

**_Mandatory Prepayment_**

The Senior Credit Facilities Agreement will permit mandatory prepayment in full or in part in certain circumstances on at least
a pro rata basis together with any other Indebtedness ranking pari passu with the Senior Credit Facilities, including:

  - on an initial public offering which does not constitute a change of control (with the percentage of proceeds to be
prepaid subject to a ratchet based on the Senior Secured Net Leverage Ratio) (a “Listing Prepayment”); and

  - unless otherwise agreed by the majority lenders under the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement, for each financial year
(beginning with the financial year commencing on January 1, 2018), a percentage of excess cash flow in the event that
excess cash flow exceeds a minimum threshold amount, which percentage decreases as the Senior Secured Net
Leverage Ratio decreases (an “Excess Cash Flow Prepayment”).

Upon the occurrence of a change of control (as defined in the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement) or an initial public offering
which results in a change of control, each lender shall be entitled to require prepayment of its commitments within a prescribed
time period. A change of control shall include:

  - any person or group becoming the beneficial owner of more than 50% of the voting power of the Parent, subject to
certain conditions;

  - on a disposal of substantially all of the assets of the Group.

At the election of the Parent, amounts required to be prepaid pursuant to a Listing Prepayment or an Excess Cash Flow
Prepayment may instead be applied in repayment of any other indebtedness of the Group ranking pari passu with the Senior
Term Facilities.

**_Guarantees and Security_**

_Guarantor Coverage Test_

The Senior Credit Facilities are currently guaranteed by the Guarantors, EG Holdings (France) SAS and EG Retail (France)
SAS, and are secured by the Collateral and by security interests over certain assets of EG Holdings (France) SAS and EG Retail
(France) SAS.

Subject to certain adjustments and agreed security principles in the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement, the Parent is required
to ensure that members of the Group that generate at least 80% of Consolidated EBITDA (as defined in the section entitled
“Description of the Notes”) and that hold at least 80% of the aggregate gross assets of the Group are guarantors (the “Guarantor
_Coverage Test”) under the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement within 60 days of the date on which the annual financial_
statements of the Parent are required to be delivered to the agent under the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement.

Subject to certain adjustments and agreed security principles in the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement, the Parent was required
to ensure that material real property representing at last 85% of the total aggregate net book value of the material real property
located in the United Kingdom was subject to Transaction Security no later than sixty (60) days following February 7, 2018
and that any material real property acquired by any member of the Group is made subject to Transaction Security within six
(6) months of the acquisition thereof, _provided that for these purposes, material real property is defined as (i) freehold or_
heritable property with a reinstatement value in excess of £1.0 million, and (ii) any leasehold property (including any ground
lease and building rights) that has an unexpired term of twenty-five (25) years or more from February 7, 2018 or, if acquired
after February 7, 2018, from the acquisition of such leasehold property interest (and excluding any leasehold property in respect
of which a rack rent is payable), in each case that is located in the United Kingdom and excluding any unregistered real property
which, if subject to any security, would be required to be registered under the relevant land registry laws (provided that such
real property shall only be excluded for so long as it remains unregistered).

of the two, as described in the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement (with each of the foregoing defined terms in this paragraph

facilities or any amounts utilized to fund any original issue discount or flex related payments, fees or expenses) exceeds 40%

Conditions Satisfaction Date, in addition to being for the benefit of the lenders participating in a Revolving Credit Facility, the
Financial Covenant shall also be extended for the benefit of the lenders participating in an Letter of Credit Facility expressed
to benefit from such financial covenant.

The Senior Credit Facilities Agreement contains an equity cure provision enabling the shareholders of the Parent to make
shareholder injections by way of debt and/or equity to the Parent to (i) increase the consolidated pro forma EBITDA under the
Senior Credit Facilities Agreement (an “EBITDA Cure”), (ii) decrease consolidated senior secured net debt as defined in the
Senior Credit Facilities Agreement, or (iii) prepay the relevant Revolving Credit Facility so that the Revolving Test Condition
is no longer satisfied. The EBITDA Cure right may not be exercised on more than two occasions during the term of the Senior
Credit Facilities. The equity cure rights may not be exercised on more than five occasions during the term of the Senior Credit
Facilities, may not be exercised on more than two occasions in any financial year and may not be exercised in consecutive
financial quarters.

does not constitute a change of control) where the Group’s Senior Secured Net Leverage Ratio (adjusted as if the proceeds of
that listing have been or will be applied in prepayment of the facilities) does not exceed 4.00:1; (ii) the Parent (or any holding
company of the Parent) having a long-term corporate credit rating equal to or better than Baa3 according to Moody’s Investor
Services Limited or BBB- according to Standard & Poor’s Rating Services; or (iii) the Senior Term Facilities (and any
additional facilities which are term loan facilities) have achieved and maintained investment-grade status. On and from the
Conditions Satisfaction Date, the intended fall away provisions mentioned above shall cease to be operative, such that certain
agreed covenants and other provisions of the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement will not fall away on the satisfaction of the
release conditions referred to in sub-paragraphs (i) through (iii) above.

**_Events of Default_**

The Senior Credit Facilities Agreement provides for substantially the same events of default as under the Notes. In addition,
the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement provides for additional events of default, subject to customary materiality qualifications
and grace periods, including (i) breach of the financial covenant subject to cure rights, provided that, in the event of such breach
which is not cured, (x) prior to the Conditions Satisfaction Date, only a majority of the lenders under each Revolving Credit
Facility shall initially be entitled to take enforcement action, or (y) on and from the Conditions Satisfaction Date, in addition
to the majority lenders under each Revolving Credit Facility, a majority of the lenders under each Letter of Credit Facility
expressed to benefit from such financial covenant shall initially be entitled to take enforcement action; (ii) inaccuracy of a
representation or statement when made; (iii) invalidity and unlawfulness of the Senior Credit Facilities financing documents;
and (iv) material failure to comply with the Intercreditor Agreement.

restrictive covenants, events of default and related definitions scheduled to the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement will be

(including, among others, if all or substantially all of the properties or assets of the Issuer and certain of its subsidiaries taken
as a whole are sold, transferred or otherwise disposed of, or if any person acquires the majority of voting power of the Issuer),
holders of the Existing Notes have the right to require the Issuer to repurchase all or any part of their Existing Notes at a
purchase price equal to 101% of the principal amount of the Existing Notes repurchased, plus accrued and unpaid interest to
the date of purchase. In the event of certain asset sales, after which the proceeds are not reinvested in the form envisaged by
the Existing Indenture and as a result of which such proceeds exceed €70 million, the Issuer is required to make an offer to
repurchase the Existing Notes, as applicable, at 100% of the principal amount.

The Existing Notes contain various events of default, including, among others, non-payment, breach of certain covenants,
breach of other obligations set forth in the Existing Indenture, any security interest under the security document in an amount
greater than €100 million ceases to be in full force and effect after a grace period of 10 days, any guarantees of a Significant
Subsidiary cease to be in full force and effect, a cross-default in relation to certain indebtedness aggregating €150 million or
more at any time outstanding not being paid prior to the expiration of the grace period provided in such indebtedness or
indebtedness becoming due and payable before its specified maturity, failure to pay final judgments in excess of €150 million
following a grace period, and certain events of bankruptcy and insolvency, the occurrence of which, with respect to certain
events of default, would result in the Existing Notes becoming due and payable or, with respect to certain other events of
default, would allow holders of the Existing Notes to declare the Existing Notes due and payable.

The offerings of the Existing Notes were not registered under the Securities Act or any U.S. state securities laws. The Existing
Notes were offered and sold within the United States only to qualified institutional buyers as defined in Rule 144A under the
Securities Act and to non-U.S. persons outside the United States in reliance on Regulation S under the Securities Act. The
Existing Notes are listed on the Official List of the Exchange.

**Second Lien Credit Facilities Agreement**

**_Overview and Structure_**

The Parent, on April 6, 2018, entered into the Second Lien Credit Facilities Agreement (as amended and restated pursuant to
an amendment and restatement agreement dated December 24, 2021) with, among others, Barclays Bank PLC as agent and the
security agent, and Bank of America Merrill Lynch International Limited, Barclays Bank PLC, Deutsche Bank AG, London
Branch, Lloyds Bank plc, Morgan Stanley Bank International Limited and UBS Europe SE (formerly UBS Limited), as
mandated lead arrangers. On March 21, 2021, the Parent, together with EG Finco Limited as the borrower and Barclays Bank
PLC as the additional facility lender and the agent, entered into the Second Lien Additional Facility Notice. The Second Lien
Additional Facility Notice, established pursuant to the Second Lien Credit Facilities Agreement, provided for a second lien
term loan facility in an aggregate principal amount of €610,000,000.00 (the “Additional Second Lien Facility”for the purposes
of this description). The Additional Second Lien Facility refinanced all other facilities incurred pursuant to the Second Lien
Credit Facilities Agreement such that from the date of establishment of the Additional Second Lien Facility, the Additional
Second Lien Facility constitutes the only indebtedness outstanding pursuant to the Second Lien Credit Facilities Agreement.
As described under the heading “Capitalization”, the U.S. dollar-equivalent amount of indebtedness outstanding under the
Second Lien Credit Facilities Agreement (as supplemented by the Second Lien Additional Facility Notice) as of June 30, 2023
is $663 million.

The Additional Second Lien Facility has been utilized by EG Finco Limited and was originally applied in or towards (directly
or indirectly): (i) satisfaction of the consideration payable for (x) the acquisition by Euro Garages Limited of certain shares (the
“Asda Forecourt Target“) sold by Bellis Property Newco Limited pursuant to an acquisition agreement dated 3 February
2021 (the “Asda Forecourts Acquisition”) (including any interest payments, completion amount related adjustments and
purchase price adjustments (however structured)) and any other amounts payable in relation to the Asda Forecourts Acquisition
and/or (y) the OMV Acquisition (including any interest payments, completion amount related adjustments and purchase price
adjustments (however structured)) and any other amounts payable in relation to the OMV Acquisition, (ii) refinancing or
otherwise discharging any existing indebtedness of the Asda Forecourts Target and its subsidiaries and/or the entities acquired
pursuant to the OMV Acquisition and those entities’ subsidiaries (including backstopping or providing cash-cover in respect


-----

of any letters of credit, guarantees, performance bonds or ancillary, revolving, working capital or local facilities or other
arrangements) and paying any fees, costs and expenses (including any breakage costs, redemption premia, make-whole costs)
payable in connection with the Asda Forecourts Acquisition and/or the OMV Acquisition and/or paying any Transaction Costs,
(iii) refinancing or otherwise discharging any indebtedness under a £137,000,000 additional term facility and/or the
£750,000,000 bridge facility made available to Bellis Acquisition Company 3 plc and, in each case, paying any related breakage
costs, redemption premium, make whole costs and other fees, costs and expenses payable in connection with such refinancing,
(iv) refinancing or otherwise discharging any existing indebtedness of the Group under the Second Lien Credit Facilities
Agreement and paying any related breakage costs, redemption premium, make whole costs and other fees, costs and expenses
payable in connection with such refinancing, (v) funding such surplus into the Group balance sheet to be applied towards the
general corporate purposes and/or working capital requirements of the Group (including, without limitation, the financing or
refinancing of capital expenditure, any permitted acquisitions, transaction costs, investments and joint ventures, operational
restructurings and reorganisation requirements of the Group, financing or refinancing financial indebtedness of the Group or
any acquisition target, any required original issue discount fees or any additional original issue discount fees or funding any
market flex, any ticking fees required to be paid in connection and any interest accruing on the Secured Debt Documents (as
defined below) (including any related intercompany loans) or any additional original issue discount or other fees and any related
fees, costs and expenses).

Capitalized terms used but not defined herein have the meanings given to them in the Second Lien Additional Facility Notice
and/or the Second Lien Credit Facilities Agreement, as the context requires.

**_Conditions Precedent_**

The utilization of the Additional Second Lien Facility was subject to customary conditions precedent.

**_Interest and Fees_**

Loans under the Additional Second Lien Facility will bear interest at rates per annum equal to EURIBOR in respect of loans
denominated in Euro plus an applicable margin.

If EURIBOR is less than zero, EURIBOR shall be deemed to be zero in respect of loans made under the Additional Second
Lien Facility.

Default interest will be calculated as an additional 1% on the defaulted amount.

**_Repayments_**

The loans made under the Additional Second Lien Facility will be repaid in full on 30 April 2027.

**_Mandatory Prepayment_**

Substantially the same as the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement; provided that all ratios as set 0.25x wider than the equivalent
ratios for the Senior Credit Facilities and provided further that any requirement to make a mandatory prepayment of the
Additional Second Lien Facility shall be subject to first making prepayments of the Senior Credit Facilities and in any event
subject to the Intercreditor Agreement.

**_Guarantees and Security_**

Substantially the same as the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement.

**_Representations and Warranties_**

Substantially the same as the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement.

**_Covenants_**

Contains various covenants which limit our ability to, among other things:

  - incur or guarantee additional indebtedness or issue certain preferred stock;

  - make certain restricted payments and investments;


-----

  - transfer or sell assets or enter into sale and leaseback transactions;

  - enter into transactions with affiliates;

  - create or incur certain liens;

  - make certain loans, investments or acquisitions;

  - create or incur restrictions on the ability of our subsidiaries to pay dividends or to make other payments to us;

  - take certain actions that would impair the security interests in the Collateral granted for the benefit of the lenders; and

  - merge, consolidate or transfer all or substantially all of our all of our assets.

**_Events of Default_**

Substantially the same as the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement provided that all baskets are set 1.2x wider.

**_Governing Law_**

The Second Lien Credit Facilities Agreement, the Second Lien Additional Facility Notice and any non-contractual obligations
arising out of or in connection with such documents, are governed by, construed in accordance with and will be enforced in
accordance with English law although the information undertakings, restrictive covenants, events of default and related
definitions scheduled to the Second Lien Credit Facilities Agreement or the Second Lien Additional Facility Notice will be
interpreted in accordance with New York law (without prejudice to the fact that the Second Lien Credit Facilities Agreement
and the Second Lien Additional Facility Notice is governed by English law).

**Intercreditor Agreement**

**_General_**

To establish the relative rights of certain of our creditors under our financing arrangements, each of the Parent the Guarantors,
the Issuer and the Trustee are party to an Intercreditor Agreement originally dated February 6, 2018 between, among others,
the Parent, the agent, arrangers and lenders under each of the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement and the Second Lien Credit
Facilities Agreement and the Security Agent.

By accepting a Note, holders of the Notes will be deemed to have agreed to, and accepted the terms and conditions of, the
Intercreditor Agreement.

The Intercreditor Agreement is governed by English law and sets out various matters governing the relationship of the creditors
to our group including the relative ranking of certain debt of the Issuer, the Guarantors and any other person that becomes party
to the Intercreditor Agreement as a Debtor or Third Party Security Provider, when payments can be made in respect of debt of
the Debtors or Third Party Security Providers, when enforcement action can be taken in respect of that debt, the terms pursuant
to which certain of that debt will be subordinated upon the occurrence of certain insolvency events and turnover provisions and
provisions related to the enforcement of shared security.

The following description is a summary of certain provisions contained in the Intercreditor Agreement. It does not restate the
Intercreditor Agreement in its entirety and we urge you to read that document because it, and not the discussion that follows,
defines certain rights of the holders of the Notes and of the Trustee. Capitalized terms used but not defined herein have the
meanings given to them in the Intercreditor Agreement.

For the purposes of this description:

References to the “Senior Secured Notes” shall include the Notes and any other notes, securities or other debt instruments
issued or to be issued by or in relation to which a New Debt Financing (as defined below) has been made available to or by a
member of the Group which are designated by the Parent as Senior Secured Notes under the Intercreditor Agreement and
references to the “Topco Notes” shall include any notes, securities or other debt instruments issued or to be issued by or in
relation to which a New Debt Financing has been made available to or by a Topco Borrower (as defined below) which are
designated by the Parent as Topco Notes.


-----

The Intercreditor Agreement uses the term “the Company” to refer to the Parent, “Topco” to refer to EG Midco 1 Limited and
“Senior Secured Notes Liabilities” to refer to the Notes and certain other indebtedness of the Issuer.

**_Ranking and Priority_**

_Priority of Debts_

The Intercreditor Agreement provides that the liabilities owed by the Issuer and each other debtor under the Intercreditor
Agreement (together, the “Debtors”) (other than any member of the Group which is designated as a Topco Borrower under the
Intercreditor Agreement (a “Topco Borrower”)) shall rank in right of priority and payment in the following order and are
postponed and subordinated to any prior ranking liabilities as follows:

(i) first, liabilities owed to (i) the lenders, issuing banks and ancillary lenders in relation to the Senior Credit
Facilities Agreement or any future senior secured facilities agreements (a “Permitted Senior Secured
Facilities Agreement”) (the “Senior Lender Liabilities”), (ii) the lenders, issuing banks, and ancillary lenders
in relation to any future super senior facilities agreement (a “Permitted Super Senior Secured Facilities
Agreement”) and any hedge counterparty under a hedging agreement that is designated by the Parent as super
senior (together the “Super Senior Liabilities” and creditors thereof being the “Super Senior Creditors”), (iii)
the Trustee and any trustee in relation to future senior secured notes (each a “Senior Secured Notes Trustee”)
(other than certain amounts paid to it in its capacity as trustee), the Senior Secured Notes and the Security
Agent in relation to the Senior Secured Notes (the “Senior Secured Notes Liabilities”), (iv) the lender under
any future loan made by the issuer of any Senior Secured Notes (if so designated by the Parent in its discretion
and not including, for the avoidance of doubt, the Parent) to a member of the Group for the purposes of on
lending the proceeds of any Senior Secured Notes together with any additional or replacement loan made on
substantially the same terms (the “Senior Secured Notes Proceeds Loan Liabilities”), (v) the arrangers,
agents, issuing banks and lenders under any cash management facility (a “Cash Management Facility” and
the liabilities under a Cash Management Facility being the “Cash Management Facility Liabilities”), (vi) the
hedge counterparties in relation to any hedging agreements that are not Super Senior Liabilities (together
with the hedging designated by the Parent as being Super Senior Liabilities, the “Hedging Liabilities”), (vii)
the lenders in relation to the Second Lien Credit Facilities Agreement and the lenders in relation to any future
second lien facility agreement (together with the Second Lien Credit Facilities Agreement, a “Second Lien
Facility Agreement” and the liabilities to the lenders under a Second Lien Facility Agreement being the
“Second Lien Lender Liabilities”), (viii) any second lien notes trustee (other than certain amounts paid to it
in its capacity as trustee), the holders of any future second lien notes and the Security Agent in relation to
any second lien notes (such second lien notes being “Second Lien Notes” and the liabilities in respect of such
Second Lien Notes being the “Second Lien Notes Liabilities” and together with the Second Lien Lender
Liabilities, the “Second Lien Liabilities”), (ix) any agent or trustee under any finance documents relating to
any of the aforementioned liabilities, any agent or trustee under the Topco Liabilities (as defined below) and
to any agent or trustee in relation to certain other unsecured liabilities (together the “Agent Liabilities”) (in
each case together with the applicable liabilities owed to any arranger under the Debt Documents (as defined
below) (the “Arranger Liabilities”)), _pari passu_ and without any preference between them and (x) the
Security Agent; and

(ii) second, all liabilities owed (i) to the trustee (other than certain amounts paid to it in its capacity as trustee),
and the holders of any future notes issued by or in relation to which a New Debt Financing has been made
available to or by a Topco Borrower and designated by the Parent as Topco Notes and the Security Agent in
relation to such Topco Notes (the “Topco Notes Liabilities”), (ii) under any future loan facility made available
to any Topco Borrower (a “Topco Loan”) (the “Topco Facility Liabilities” and together with the Topco Notes
Liabilities, the “Topco Liabilities”), and (iii) the liabilities owed under any future loan (a “Topco Proceeds
Loan”) made by any Topco Borrower for the purpose of on lending the proceeds of any Topco Notes or
Topco Loans (the “Topco Proceeds Loan Liabilities”), pari passu and without any preference between them.

The Intercreditor Agreement provides that the liabilities owed by any Topco Borrower to the Secured Parties (as defined below)
shall rank pari passu in right and priority of payment and without any preference between them in respect of (i) the Senior
Lender Liabilities, (ii) the Super Senior Liabilities, (iii) the Senior Secured Notes Liabilities, (iv) the Cash Management Facility
Liabilities, (v) the Hedging Liabilities, (vi) the Second Lien Lender Liabilities, (vii) the Second Lien Notes Liabilities, (viii) the
Topco Liabilities, (ix) the Topco Proceeds Loan Liabilities, (x) the Agent Liabilities and (xi) the Arranger Liabilities.


-----

The Intercreditor Agreement provides that the intra-group liabilities owed by one member of the Group to another member of
the Group (other than any Senior Secured Notes Proceeds Loan Liabilities or Topco Proceeds Loan Liabilities) (the “IntraGroup Liabilities”) will be subordinated to the liabilities owed by the Debtors and Third Party Security Providers to the creditors
under the Senior Lender Liabilities, Super Senior Liabilities, Senior Secured Notes Liabilities, Cash Management Facility
Liabilities, Hedging Liabilities, Second Lien Lender Liabilities and Second Lien Notes Liabilities, Agent Liabilities, Topco
Liabilities and Topco Proceeds Loan Liabilities (such creditors, together with the Security Agent, any receiver or delegate, any
creditor of the Agent Liabilities and any arranger with respect to the Secured Liabilities, the “Secured Parties”).

The Intercreditor Agreement also provides that the liabilities owed by any member of the Group (other than any Topco Proceeds
Loan Liabilities) to a holding company of the Parent or to any other person who becomes a subordinated creditor (a
“Subordinated Creditor”) under the Intercreditor Agreement (the “Subordinated Liabilities”) will be subordinated to the
liabilities owed by the Debtors and Third Party Security Providers to the Secured Parties and to the Intra-Group Liabilities.
